HEADLINE: United Way Is Reporting 3.8% Increase in Donations 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The 1,400 local United Ways raised $3.91 billion in the year ended June 30, an increase of $140 million or about 3.8 percent over a year earlier, Ellie Ferdon, chairwoman of United Way of America, the national organization, will announce today. It is the fifth consecutive year that giving to the fund-raising organizations increased faster than inflation.
 The modest real growth in donations to the nation's largest private financier of social services comes as demand for the services is rising and as President Bush promotes the idea that charities are better suited than government to provide many social services. 
 The United Ways in New York City and Los Angeles County reported larger increases than United Ways overall, with gifts of at least $10,000 more than offsetting the continued erosion of gifts by rank-and-file workers. 
But there are signs that the fund-raising drives that will begin next month face major obstacles in matching the latest results.
In San Jose, Calif., gifts of appreciated stock dropped 90 percent in the first three months of this year, a result of the drop in the technology market, said Greg Larson, the president of the Silicon Valley United Way. The charity also expects unfilled pledges from payroll giving, known as shrinkage, to rise to 6.5 percent from 5.9 percent last year because of layoffs in the high technology industry. Still, the Silicon Valley United Way raised $22.4 million this year, up $100,000 over 2000.
But United Way member agencies in the Silicon Valley will get less money this year because of what Mr. Larson called "a dark cloud on the horizon." That cloud is the trend of donors designating which charities will get their gifts, often agencies with no United Way affiliation.
Mr. Larsen said 45 percent of gifts in the year just ended were designated for specific charities, up from the high 30 percent range in earlier years.
Alarmed at the growth of donor-designation, several United Ways, following the lead of the statewide United Way in Delaware, have stopped promoting designations as a giving option.
Another sign of coming woes tied to job losses appeared in Rochester, home of the nation's richest United Way. Its spring campaign fell $1.8 million short of its $38 million goal. Becky Cania, a spokeswoman, attributed the shortfall to the closing of one big employer, Genesee Hospital, and continued layoffs at Eastman Kodak, Xerox and other employers.
United Way of Tri-State, an umbrella group for 32 agencies in metropolitan New York, raised $108 million from major employers, an increase of less than 1 percent. Its campaign was hurt by layoffs and job transfers at AT&T, Exxon Mobil, Lucent and Verizon. 
"We all face tough challenges this fall," said Kirk Sapa, Tri-State executive vice president.
Nationally, giving was up 68.9 percent at Delta Airlines; 42.4 percent at Honeywell, which merged with Allied Signal; 30.3 percent at Pfizer; and 24.8 percent at J. P. Morgan Chase.
Giving dropped 51.2 percent at Pillsbury; 36.2 percent at Sara Lee; 33.2 percent at Kmart; 24.2 percent at Motorola; 21.9 percent at Lucent; 18.2 percent at PG&E, the utility in California that has filed for bankruptcy protection; 17 percent at Aetna; and 14.5 percent at Verizon.
United Ways traditionally depended on workers, especially factory workers, giving through payroll deduction to support social service agencies from Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts to the Red Cross and Family Service Associations.
In the last decade, this support has slipped because of layoffs at the largest corporations, a trend toward small workplaces that are costly to organize and anger over disclosures in 1992 that William V. Aramony, the longtime president of United Way of America, was living a lavish lifestyle and embezzling money. Mr. Aramony is expected to be released from prison late next month, which will no doubt prompt articles that may rekindle some of that anger.
The number of United Way donors is down more than 25 percent in the last decade, but the steady decline in payroll giving has been offset by a growing emphasis on major gifts from the wealthy.
Donations raised in gifts of $10,000 and more, which United Ways call the Alexis de Tocqueville society, have grown 167 percent since 1995, a period when overall giving rose just 24 percent.
In New York City, the local United Way raised $44.5 million, up 13 percent from the $39.4 million raised the previous year, said Kathy Walling, a spokeswoman. Givers of $10,000 or more increased to 210 from 153 the year before and their gifts more than doubled to $6.2 million from $3 million, she said.
In Los Angeles, giving by those who have donated $1 million or more in their lifetimes increased sharply in the last year, to $12.1 million from $4.6 million the previous year, said Dominic Ng, chief executive of East West Bancorp. in San Marino, Calif., who chaired the campaign.
The $7.5 million increase in such huge gifts was greater than the overall increase in giving of $5 million, illustrating the declining role of rank-and-file givers.
Gifts of $10,000 or more provided 28 percent of the money raised in Los Angeles.
"My vision was to see United Way better reflect the diversity of Los Angeles not just in which charities we distribute funds to, but who gives," Mr. Ng said. "Los Angeles, like New York, is a city of immigrants and many of the newcomers are not participating in the traditional philanthropic activities, but we are changing that."
He said the agency was able to develop new support among immigrant entrepreneurs, high technology firms and venture capitalists. 
"The only industry where we were not successful was the entertainment industry," Mr. Ng said. He said he encountered worries about both Mr. Aramony's crime and a 1986 scandal involving secret loans to Los Angeles United Way executives in which two who paid the money back were forced out, but three others who made only token payments were promoted.
Mrs. Ferdon said that Mr. Aramony's pending release should remind donors that the organization dealt effectively with him. "Our latest results show that United Way is a strong brand," she said, "and donors see us as a premier organization."
In Chicago, giving rose to $96.2 million, up 1.2 percent from the previous year. Giving at the $10,000 and larger level now accounts for 6 percent of all gifts to United Way in Chicago, up from 4 percent in 1998, said Jim Kales, a spokesman.
Many United Ways, including those in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York, have not posted campaign goals, or results, on their Web sites. These and many others also do not have current financial information posted at their Web sites nor copies of their Form 990 tax returns, which are public record. 
Mrs. Ferdon said that posting campaign goals and results, as well as current financial reports, was not among the standards that the local organizations must meet to use the United Way brand.

HEADLINE: Productivity Still Gaining Despite Slump 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Even in a sharp economic slowdown, the new economy seems to be surviving. It just may not be as big a deal as many of its most optimistic proponents had predicted.
 In the second quarter of this year, companies managed to become more efficient despite the near absence of economic growth, the government reported yesterday. That unusual feat offers further evidence that, with the help of technology, the economy has emerged from a 20-year productivity slump that began in the mid-1970's and contributed to a decline in inflation-adjusted wages for most workers, economists said. 
 Nonfarm productivity rose at a healthy 2.5 percent annual rate in the quarter, as businesses produced roughly the same output using less labor, the Labor Department said. The growth was similar to the rate during the boom years of the late 1990's and significantly higher than the 1.5 percent average during the previous 20 years.
Productivity -- the amount that a worker produces in an hour -- is considered one of the most important government statistics because it indicates how quickly the economy can grow over a long period. When productivity rises rapidly, both corporate profits and workers' earnings can grow without causing inflation to accelerate.
But the Labor Department also gave some reason for caution yesterday, saying that it had overestimated productivity growth in the three previous years. The productivity gains of the late 90's now look less impressive than those of the 1960's to mid-70's, when people flocked to universities and the government built new highways and airports.
From 1997 until 2000, productivity grew 2.6 percent, not 3.2 percent, as the government had initially reported in March.
"Everybody is giving a little haircut to their long-run growth projections," said Ethan Harris, a senior economist with Lehman Brothers. But, he added, "by no means does this overturn the idea of a new paradigm of higher productivity growth."
Productivity typically increases in an economic expansion, as companies try to make enough products to meet rising demand, and economists have been engaged in a detailed debate about whether the recent increases would outlast the cycle.
The second quarter offered support to the optimists, who include Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. The 2.5 percent increase was a significant improvement over the gain in the first three months of the year, when productivity rose just 0.1 percent. (The government had initially said that it fell 1.2 percent in the first quarter but reported the new number yesterday as part of its regular revisions.)
In recent months, companies became more efficient by dismissing employees or reducing the number of hours they worked, while sustaining virtually the same level of output. They have been announcing large layoffs since late last year, but only since March has the overall number of jobs in the American economy been declining, as early budget cutters, like Whirlpool, actually made their layoffs and other companies, like Eastman Kodak, followed.
Because unemployment remains historically low, inflation-adjusted hourly compensation still rose 1.6 percent, on annual basis, in the second quarter, the government said yesterday. But pay growth has slowed from the roughly 3 percent annual gain between 1997 and 2000 -- the best three-year period for workers since the late 1960's.
If the productivity gains are more than a cyclical phenomenon, and do reflect a country made more efficient by computers and the Internet, the long-term average growth of the economy may be about 3.5 percent, economists said. Previously, many analysts believed it was closer to 3 percent and that inflation would accelerate once growth exceeded that mark.
As believers in the new economy, Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the Fed decided not to raise interest rates during much of the late 90's, even as growth accelerated. In speeches, some members of the Fed have said that they were able to cut interest rates rapidly over the last seven months because the new economy made inflation less of an immediate threat.
"By all of the evaluations that we make, we are only part way through a technological expansion," Mr. Greenspan said last month, while testifying before the Senate. That expansion will keep productivity growth strong, he said.
Still, recent data has brought some warning signs. Earlier this month, the government said that companies' investment in new equipment and software had fallen 14.5 percent in the second quarter, the worst decline in 19 years.
Many economists saw the investment in equipment and software as the force behind the efficiency gains. As companies cut back, those gains could recede, said Joel Prakken, the chairman of Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis.
"There's a pretty significant change here," Mr. Prakken said. "The economy's growth potential is somewhat lower than we thought."

HEADLINE: Budget Crisis, Still Burning, Has Already Left Casualties 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
A plan to open pre-kindergarten classes in thousands of schools this year is dead. Housing construction for homeless people will sputter. The same could happen to day care programs for tens of thousands of poor children.
 Groups that help people with AIDS take their medications stand to see their budgets evaporate. So do those that build housing for the homeless. Thousands -- possibly hundreds of thousands -- of homeowners will get property tax increases. 
 All of these effects, and many more, are likely to come to pass if the $80 billion, stripped-down budget enacted last week is the only budget the state gets for the fiscal year that began April 1. If the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki can agree on a supplemental budget, a cloudy prospect at best, some of the harm to programs can be averted, but in other places, the damage is done until next year.
"The situation for us is completely devastating," said Brad Williams, executive director of the New York Independent Living Council, an alliance of organizations that help disabled people. "I have no idea how we're going to survive."
The Democrat-led Assembly and the Republican-led Senate, frustrated by Mr. Pataki's refusal to negotiate, agreed last week to a bare-bones budget that leaves out programs they all care deeply about. They hope the resulting pain is so acute that interest groups from hospital administrators to welfare mothers will pressure Mr. Pataki to bargain with them on a multi-billion-dollar supplemental budget.
It is a risky strategy, and many legislators are afraid that it could backfire, leaving the budget cuts in place. A prominent Democratic lawmaker described their approach to the governor this way: "We're cutting ourselves and bleeding all over him."
So far, it does not appear to be working. The governor has spent the past several days barnstorming the state, holding two or three news conferences a day to accuse legislative leaders of being irresponsible and hoping that they, not he, will be blamed.
For groups that provide services to the poor through state grants, the mechanics of spending make the cuts even deeper than they appear at first. Often, money is included in the budget but not spent until the next year. The spending then must be authorized a second time, a "reappropriation." But to turn up the heat on the governor, the Legislature has cut off all re-appropriations, totaling billions of dollars, effective Sept. 15.
The governor's budget proposed leaving out social service programs or cuts in their funding, knowing that lawmakers would later restore the money. But the Legislature refused to make those additions in the bare-bones budget, leaving programs at the governor's lower levels.
That spells disaster for programs like the state's Homeless Housing Assistance Program, which gives money to nonprofit groups to build or renovate housing.
Last year's budget allocated $30 million for the program, but none of that money was to be delivered until October. All of it is a reappropriation and, barring a new budget deal, all of it will evaporate. In addition, the program stands to lose its customary $10 million addition from the Legislature, money that would be spent next year.
"We could be denied all of last year's money and one-third of this year's," said Jennifer Flynn, executive director of New York City AIDS Housing Network, a coalition of groups that apply for the money. "Waiting lists for housing would get longer, our member groups would lay people off, services at existing housing would be cut back. People need to understand, this is a crisis."
The centers for the disabled that Mr. Williams represents stand to lose a $10.5 million reappropriation, most of their budget for the year, plus a $1 million legislative addition for next year. Hundreds of social service groups tell similar stories.
Some nonprofits are in worse straits because their budgets rely on additions by the Assembly.
The Fortune Society, which runs a variety of social service programs and helps former convicts stay out of trouble, faces a $725,000 shortfall for programs to counsel parents of troubled youths, to steer convicts into drug treatment rather than prison, and to help single fathers find jobs and pay child support.
The Legal Aid Society will lose $8 million to represent poor women in domestic violence cases, elderly people who lose Social Security benefits, and people fighting evictions. Prisoners' Legal Services, which files lawsuits for inmates, faces elimination of its $3.5 million budget.
For the biggest area of dispute, aid to schools, the impasse has already had an irreversible effect. Education officials say that even with more spending, it is too late to hire new teachers or find classroom space.
This year, several hundred districts were to become eligible, for the first time, for a state program that pays for prekindergarten classes for 4-year-olds and reduced elementary class sizes.
But Mr. Pataki left more than $200 million for that effort out of his proposed budget, and the Legislature did not restore it. Legislators and school officials concede that, with the start of school a month away, there will be no expansion of the program.
Overall, the governor proposed a $382 million increase in state aid to schools, just enough to keep up with inflation. The Senate wanted $900 million, the Assembly $1.7 billion.
By law, most districts must draft their budgets in May, forcing them to guess how much state aid they would receive. In its bare-bones budget, the Legislature accepted Mr. Pataki's figure, leaving districts with far less aid than they expected.
Most districts send out property tax bills in mid or late August. Education officials say that many districts will raise taxes to make up for the difference. New York City schools and some other cities do not levy their taxes, so they must either find other ways of making up the money or simply do without.
The deepest cuts were at a favorite agency of the governor's, the Empire State Development Corporation, which offers grants and loans for business development. Its operating budget was reduced from $243 million to $4,100, and its $221 million carried over from previous years was eliminated. The Pataki administration is hunting for ways to keep the agency running and pay its staff.
The state's hospitals and nursing homes, which face a difficult round of labor negotiations, are also affected. The budget guarantees that Medicaid payments to them will fall about $500 million short. It also fails to allocate about $250 million in Federal aid to enroll Medicaid recipients in managed care plans.
"We are going to have a real crisis," said Jennifer Cunningham, executive director of the Service Employees International Union, New York State Council, which represents health care workers. "This isn't just the frills. This is the meat and potatoes of financing the health care industry."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Bcom3 Agencies Merge and Plan Layoffs

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
The Bcom3 Group in Chicago said yesterday that it is merging two agencies that specialize in digital communications and advertising, Giant Step in Chicago and Novo in San Francisco.
 "The merger will allow Bcom3 to strategically consolidate its online capabilities in the U.S. and maximize the value it brings clients as technology-enabled marketing evolves," Bcom3 said in a statement. 
 "In conjunction with the merger and as a result of the difficult economic environment," Bcom3 said, the merged agency will cut about 30 percent of its staff. 
The new agency, called Novo, will have 222 employees and offices in Chicago, Detroit, New York and San Francisco. Kelly Rodriques, chairman and chief executive at Novo, San Francisco, will lead the combined agency. Steve Weinswig, president at Giant Step, Chicago, will lead its Chicago offices.
In April, Giant Step dismissed 52 of 227 employees.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Connecticut Calls It Nouveau Jersey

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: DARIEN, Conn. 

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY!" the man at the garden supply center said in a tone he might use if you had a geranium growing out of your head. "Who even thinks of New Jersey?"
 Keith Barker, owner of the Gardener's Center and Florist, was responding in typical Connecticut fashion to news that New Jersey was celebrating the release of a census figure this week indicating that the Garden State is wealthier than Connecticut. "New Jersey's not seen as competition," Mr. Barker said. "I didn't even know New Jersey came into the picture." 
 The picture, as far as Connecticut is concerned, includes very little other than Connecticut, and most certainly not New Jersey. Not that people in Connecticut feel threatened, mind you. "I don't think they see themselves in competition with anyone," said Patricia Krusen, the manager of a children's clothing store here.
New Jersey, of course, sees itself in competition with everyone, including itself, or at least its reputation. That may explain why there was such hoopla in New Jersey about a Census Bureau survey showing that New Jersey had the nation's highest annual median household income, edging out Connecticut, $54,226 to $53,108.
Of course, Connecticut still has the highest per capita income and the highest percentage of people whose money is earning money while they're wearing Docksiders.
Incomewise, New Jersey and Connecticut have been competitive for some time, since both are largely suburban, feeding off the nectar of New York City and their own ubiquitous corporate headquarters. But culturally, they're about as similar as pearl earrings and silver tongue studs.
"They've always had that inferiority complex," said Ed Redding, manager of a Darien framing shop. "Remember, they always wanted to get the Statue of Liberty, saying it was technically theirs."
"Nouveau riche, as they say," said Mr. Redding, looking over his reading glasses.
In Nouveau Jersey, home of the supposedly uncouth, no one was half as harsh as the supposedly refined residents of Connecticut.
"They may be WASPy kind of people" was the worst Frank Alliotts, an Alpine, N.J., developer, could say of the criticism. 
New Jersey may be the only place that actually cheers census data. "It's good for us, I think for the image," said Pat Garbe Morillo, of Closter, N.J. "People think of New Jersey as asphalt."
Connecticut likes having everyone imagine that the whole state is Westport, while New Jersey is forever trying to convince people that the whole state isn't Bayonne. 
Martin Krasniqi, the owner of Original Ray's Pizza in Closter, summed up Bergen County this way: "Very nice people. Very rich area. Nobody asks you how much is a slice." (If you're from a depressed area, say Fairfield County, and need to ask, it's $1.42 for regular, $1.60 for Sicilian and 50 cents for each additional topping.)
Jeff Koffler, a psychiatrist in Stamford who was fueling up at a local Starbucks, had the detached view you would expect from a mental health professional. "It's all averages anyway," he said, pointing out that the rich were offset by the poor in both places.
But then, without warning, he was analyzing New Jersey's psyche to explain why its people would crow about income statistics. "They have to have something to say now that they lost Christie Whitman and they have that guy who's not running again," he said, referring to the tumult surrounding Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco.
BUT the psychiatrist, unconsciously, fell into Connecticut's habitual avoidance behavior. Had he forgotten what's been tumbling out of Connecticut's closet?
The mayor of Waterbury promises to return to work just as soon as he's sprung from jail on charges of luring young girls into sex acts. Bridgeport is on a corruption-indictment-of-the-week plan. And Greenwich has found yet another legal strategy against an awful summer hazard: outsiders presumptuously asserting their right to use the town beach. Connecticut acts as if none of that exists, just as it acts as if New Jersey isn't in the picture.
But New Jersey's tough. It can take it. So what if, after all the statistics are taken into account, the state isn't No. 1 in income? O.K., maybe it's No. 1 1/2. But don't believe Connecticut when it says New Jersey's no competition. Everyone in New Jersey knows what's happening behind those solid New England stone walls.
Ask Glen Davis, a camera store owner in Englewood, N.J., and he says, "They're jealous."

HEADLINE: Suburb Approves Adding 3rd Runway At Cleveland Airport 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: BROOK PARK, Ohio, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
Residents of this blue-collar suburb of Cleveland voted today in favor of a deal to raze 468 homes and clear the way for an expanded Cleveland Hopkins International Airport.
 Nearly 48 percent of the registered voters showed up to approve the plan, 3,623 to 2,943, the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections said. 
 "This is an important vote because reason triumphed over emotion," said Dennis Eckart, chief executive of the Greater Cleveland Growth Association. "Every big-league city has to have a big-league airport."
The issue divided the community, which may be best known as the home of two Ford Motor Company plants astride Interstates 71 and 480 at the edge of the airport.
The agreement was struck by Mayor Thomas Coyne of Brook Park and Mayor Michael R. White of Cleveland to free up land to add a third runway at the airport, which is owned by Cleveland, while compensating Brook Park.
The Brook Park Council had unanimously opposed the deal, saying it lacked detail, and backed citizen groups fighting the ballot issue.
"We were probably outspent 20 or 30 to one," Councilman Brian Mooney said. "We were hit almost every day with one, sometimes two pieces of glossy literature."
He said the council must closely watch to make sure Cleveland follows through on promises like paying fair market value for the homes and moving expenses.
Mr. Coyne said opponents ignored the wider issues of what airport expansion would mean to northeast Ohio and its economy. Supporters say that growing businesses often demand access to good air service and that another runway will be needed by 2015.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Yale Names a Vice President

BYLINE:  By Karen W. Arenson 

 BODY:
ROBERT L. CULVER, the new vice president for finance and administration at Yale University, has a background more varied than most. He has worked in business and in education, at universities and public schools, and as a university trustee and school board member. 
He worked for the Cambridge, Mass., school system in the early 1970's, and moved into higher education in 1990, as senior vice president and treasurer of Northeastern University.
 In between, he worked as a consultant and partner at Coopers & Lybrand, and for the last few years he served as executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Cabot Corporation. 
 His education was equally eclectic. A graduate of the State University of New York at Buffalo, he holds a master's degree from the London School of Economics and an M.P.A. from the Kennedy School at Harvard, and he completed an intensive nondegree program in modern and classical Chinese language and history at Cambridge University in England. He served on the Boston School Committee in the early 1990's, and is currently a board member of Northeastern University and the New England Conservatory of Music.
 Karen W. Arenson

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
They May Not Be Dot-Com Zillionaires, but They're Still Working

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The Internet bubble rose and burst, taking tens of thousands of jobs with it, but computer network managers -- the people who keep company computer systems running and make the Internet work -- have continued to thrive.
 Their numbers have risen steadily and their average wage is better than that of most Americans. 
 Still, not all is sunshine and roses. A survey released today of more than 12,000 network managers shows that there is a gender pay gap in this group.
The survey, conducted by TechTarget, a company that creates Web sites for technology specialists, also found a growing sense of job dissatisfaction. More than 36 percent of the managers said they were less satisfied now than they were last year, and 88 percent said they would be willing to switch jobs in the next year. The primary reasons cited for their willingness to take a new job were: better salary (45 percent), the opportunity to work with new technologies (20 percent) and a desire to be more challenged in their job (13 percent).
"The survey shows these guys are very hard-working and underappreciated," said Greg Strakosch, chief executive of TechTarget. "The only time they get recognition is when the network goes down." DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Cisco Earnings Drop Sharply But Match Expectations 

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
Cisco Systems reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings today in line with analyst expectations, but the company, a bellwether for investors, suggested a global malaise in technology spending could continue at least through the end of the calendar year.
 John Chambers, Cisco's chief executive, said the economic environment in Europe and Asia in particular might worsen before it improves, though he said there were signs of recovery in the American market. 
 Still, Cisco projected that its revenue for the coming quarter -- its fiscal first quarter -- would be flat or down 5 percent, a result that would continue a slide that began in January and that puts a fine point on the sharp turnaround this year in the fortunes of Cisco and its competitors.
"We'd like to say that the bottom has been viewed in our industry, but we don't think we're there yet," Mr. Chambers said. "We're cautiously optimistic that it'll happen in the next" one or two quarters. 
For its fourth quarter, which ended July 28, Cisco reported pro forma net income of $163 million, or 2 cents a diluted share. Those figures compare with $1.2 billion, or 16 cents a diluted share, in the period a year ago -- a drop of 86 percent.
The per-share figure was in line with a consensus industry estimates. The company's revenue for the quarter, $4.3 billion, was at the low end of industry analysts' projections, and it was down 25 percent from the $5.72 billion that the company reported for the period a year ago.
Cisco shares fell 28 cents, to $19.26, in regular trading and slipped to $18.93 in after-hours trading.
Analysts called the results mixed. Tim Luke, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said the company's returns met expectations, though at the lower end, but he noted that the company's gross profit margins -- revenues minus the cost of manufacturing goods -- were lower than expected.
On a pro forma basis, those gross margins for the quarter were 52.3 percent, compared with 54.5 percent in the third quarter. The figures are down from around 64 percent before the company began to falter and lower than the 60 percent range the company aspires to achieve, according to Larry Carter, the company's chief financial officer. 
This spring, the company, based in San Jose, Calif., took prompt steps to deal with the downturn by taking a one-time charge of an extraordinary $2.2 billion in excess inventory. The company said at the time that it did not expect to be able to use or sell the products and wanted to take the inventory off of its balance sheets.
 Some critics asserted that Cisco would later seek to sell or use the products and enhance its returns because it would appear to gain revenue from selling the products without accruing any associated expense, such as purchasing the raw materials.
 Cisco did say today that it had managed to accrue about $187 million from sales or other disposal of the products. But Mr. Carter said the company was not figuring that benefit into its gross margin and thus is "not taking credit" for the revenue. 
 In a general sense, while Cisco's year ended in a much more sour way than it began, the returns were not nearly as calamitous as those experienced by other telecommunications equipment providers like Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks.
 In late July, for example, Lucent announced that it lost $3.25 billion in its third fiscal quarter, ended June 30, and said it cut an additional 20,000 jobs. In June, Nortel said it would lose $19.2 billion in its fiscal second quarter.
 Industry analysts pointed out, however, that Cisco was different from some competitors in several respects. Notably, the bulk of its customers were in a variety of fields as opposed to being telecommunications service providers like phone companies. Also, analysts said that Cisco had a strong cash position, and was not saddled with debt.
 And while Cisco has fared better because of its different product mix, it nevertheless has seen a severe change in its fortunes over the last year.
Lissa Bogaty, an industry analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said early indications during the fiscal year suggested Cisco's revenue would be 50 to 60 percent higher than it had been in fiscal 2000. In the end, the increase was more like 18 percent. "There was a big change in the middle of the year," she said.
 Added Mr. Chambers of the company's fiscal 2001, "It was like two different years."
And he said Cisco was effectively planning for two different years for fiscal 2002. He said the company had essentially broken down the year for budgeting purposes into two halves: a conservative half that supposes the economy will not improve and that will extend until January, and a second in which the company will re-evaluate its plan based on economic conditions.

HEADLINE: Outcry Grows Over Police Use of Force in Genoa 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
More than two weeks ago, Susan Hager received a telephone call in Portland, Ore., about her daughter, a student who had stopped off in Genoa to join protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting on her way to a junior year abroad program in Siena.
 "Her friend had found her bloody belongings" at the Armando Diaz school complex in Genoa where protesters had been staying, Mrs. Hager said. There, in the early hours of July 22, 92 young people were dragged from their beds by squads of Italian anti-riot police officers who beat and jailed them. 
 Sixty of those demonstrators -- originally described by Italian officials as marauding anarchists but in more recent official reports as mostly peaceful -- were injured in the raid. At least two dozen were hospitalized, including Mrs. Hager's daughter, Morgan, and two other Americans. 
Witnesses described students crouching as they were kicked, pummeled with clubs and thrown down stairs, and emergency room doctors said a number of the injured would have died without treatment. Television crews arriving on the scene later filmed pools of blood and teeth knocked out during the raid.
It was a day or two "before we knew our daughter wasn't in a coma," Mrs. Hager said. But Morgan Hager, 20, an honors student at the University of Oregon, had cuts and bruises from her ankles to her neck and three broken bones in her hand.
Almost as painful as the news about her daughter, Mrs. Hager said, was the sense that most Americans remain unaware of the brutality of the raid, which Italian officials originally justified by saying that protesters at the school -- made available to nonviolent demonstrators -- had been harboring members of the violent Black Bloc anarchists.
Four Americans remain in jail, including Susanna Thomas, a Bryn Mawr student and Quaker from Warren, N.J., who was arrested with an Austrian theater group as it was leaving Genoa. 
Outrage about the police behavior has built across Europe, where the issue has become a major embarrassment for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. Thousands of people have marched in protest, governments have expressed concern and newspapers have been filled with accounts of police brutality. One young Italian man was shot dead in the protests at the summit meeting, about 200 people were injured and some 300 were arrested.
There have been major demonstrations in Paris, London, Geneva, Rome, Berlin, Belgrade and Athens, where riot police officers used tear gas to disperse several thousand people en route to the Italian embassy. In Amsterdam last week, about a dozen protesters managed to take over the Italian consulate and hung a banner out front: "Italy Tortures G-8 Detainees."
Spain's European Affairs Secretary, Ramon de Miguel, called the scenes a replay of fascism. Hans-Christian Strobele, a European deputy from Germany, said the Genoa police reminded him of "the military dictatorship in Argentina."
Hermann Lutz, chairman of the European Police Union, told the German television network ZDF that as he watched the riots on television he thought "it had to have been in some kind of dictatorship or in Eastern Europe or in Cuba, but not among us in the middle of Europe."
Germany's Foreign Minister, Joschka Fischer, a left-wing activist in his younger years, has called his Italian counterpart, Renato Ruggiero, to urge the Italian government to investigate police actions. Twenty-one Germans are among the 39 people still being held in Italian jails.
One German who was also arrested in the raid at the school in Genoa, a man who asked that he not be identified, described his ordeal in a statement issued by his lawyer, Dagmar Vogel, in Oberhausen, Germany: "I was hit in the head, the back, and the legs and a hard hit on the head. My skull flattened. I bled badly. I lay in my own blood bath and didn't move at all." After 2 a.m., he was arrested while still in the hospital, and was not allowed to sleep or make telephone calls, he said. During four days of detention, he said he was forced to stand with his hands against a wall for hours, harassed about going to the bathroom and taken from one location to another.
Ms. Thomas was arrested along with two dozen members of the Austrian group Publix Theater. According to the respected Austrian weekly Profil, the conservative Austrian government initially dismissed reports of police brutality and sent Italian officials reports in which Publix performers had been characterized as violent anarchists. But Profil said those reports predated an economic summit meeting in Salzburg in July at which the group protested peacefully with street performances. After reading a full investigation by the Austrian consulate general in Milan, Foreign Minister Benita Maria Ferrero-Waldner is reported to have requested that Italy transfer home the 16 remaining Publix members.
In a summary of the Austrian consulate's report to the Austrian Foreign Ministry, posted on Profil's web site (www.profil.at/aktuell), several members of Publix described being arrested at gunpoint, strip searched, beaten and berated by officers who shouted in English, "I break you!" and "You monster!"
Ms. Thomas's family has complained that the United States government has not done nearly enough in speaking out against what went on.
"The U.S. is conspicuous by its absence in the list of nations that have protested to the Italian government over the imprisonment and the behavior of the Italian police in their handling of the protests in Genoa," her father, Rick Thomas, said in a message on the family's web site.
A spokesman for the American Consulate in Milan said, "We're doing all we can."
Even some members of Italy's center-right coalition now concede that something went terribly wrong in Genoa, though they continue to point fingers at the left, saying that the former center-left government was responsible for planning security for the summit meeting.
Italian courts have opened at least half a dozen separate investigations into various allegations of police brutality, and a parliamentary inquiry began today.
Testifying at a Senate hearing in Rome, Genoa's leftist mayor, Guiseppe Pericu, said Mr. Berlusconi's government should shoulder the full blame for police misconduct.
Mr. Berlusconi has also been criticized recently for suggesting that he would like to get out of being host to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, scheduled to meet in Rome in November.
Interior Minister Claudio Scajola has removed three top police officials who ran security operations at the summit meeting, but has not apologized. "A state must never lose the monopoly on the use of force," he said recently, "and the ability to guarantee the safety of a summit."
But other members of the government coalition have criticized Mr. Berlusconi directly.
"It is not possible that the head of government goes to Genoa four times, and preoccupies himself only with flower pots, dirty laundry and building facades," Domenico Fisichella, a senator of the far-right Alleanza Nazionale, said in a radio interview on Monday, referring to Mr. Berlusconi's comments before the meeting that the city was unsightly.
"Who was taking care of the problems of public order?" Mr. Fisichella asked. "Who evaluated the impact? Why were necessary precautions not taken? It's too easy to liquidate a few functionaries and consider the question closed."

HEADLINE: P.& G. Reports Net Loss After Cost of Revamping 

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
Fourteen months ago, A. G. Lafley replaced a chief executive who had sought a radical transformation of Procter & Gamble.
 Although Mr. Lafley's touch has been softer and his approach evolutionary, he seems to have accomplished more than his predecessor, Durk I. Jager, who had offered to buy Gillette, considered remaking Procter into a pharmaceutical company and tried to speed the pace of innovations. 
 Yesterday, Procter posted its fiscal fourth-quarter results, and even though it reported a net loss, analysts praised the report and said it showed the beginnings of Mr. Lafley's efforts to shed many of Procter's food businesses, expand its personal care lines and rebuild declining market share. 
The company's loss came to $320 million, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter ended June 30, mostly because of a $1.16 billion restructuring charge. That is in contrast to net income of $516 million, or 36 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell to $9.58 billion from $9.66 billion.
The loss was expected, and the charges were part of Mr. Lafley's drive to lower costs by jettisoning underperforming brands and cutting jobs. 
Excluding the revamping charges, which included shutting the $88 million Olay Cosmetics business, profit rose 7.7 percent, to $837 million, or 60 cents a share, compared with $777 million, or 55 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Analysts had expected Procter to earn 59 cents a share on that basis, according to Thomson Financial/ First Call.
With fair warning that the loss was coming, analysts were pleased with Procter's results, especially the new strength of dental products, including Crest Whitestrips, and better-than-expected growth in the Iams pet food business.
Sales could be off in the next quarter from those in the period a year earlier because of the slowdown in the United States economy, Mr. Lafley warned. But analysts suggested that Procter was better positioned to come through the sluggish economy, in part because it was realizing savings from Mr. Lafley's plan more quickly than expected.
Mr. Lafley has been trying to sharpen the company's focus, making it more like Colgate-Palmolive by putting the emphasis on building its biggest brands. He has tried to bring out innovations under the names of its existing brands and pushed high-margin products like Olay Daily Facials, disposable wipes infused with cleansers that generated more than $71 million in sales in their first year.
"What we might say about Procter & Gamble before Lafley took over was that they were trying to push through changes fast and furious," said Sally J. Dessloch, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. "Now we have a more measured pace and more focus on core categories."
Mr. Lafley envisions a Procter that emphasizes health, beauty and fabric care products. He added to the hair care portfolio by agreeing to buy Clairol, and to put Crisco shortening and Jif peanut butter up for sale.
"We are making steady progress," Mr. Lafley said in a conference call with analysts. "Strategies and action plans we put in place in the last year are getting P.& G. back on track."
But Mr. Lafley warned the year ahead would not be any easier. Foreign currencies are unpredictable, the economies of many of Procter's markets have slowed and the company faces aggressive competition.
"It's a company that is in reasonable shape and headed in a better direction than it was a year ago," said Henry Asher, president of the Northstar Group, which has a little less than 1 percent of the $145 million it manages invested in Procter but is considering adding to the holdings.
Mr. Asher said he was pleased with Procter's joint venture with the Coca-Cola Company to sell chips and juice. Although that partnership is widely seen as a good deal for Procter, some analysts have said Coke is getting cold feet.
Mr. Lafley said yesterday he was confident that the deal would go through but added that the companies wanted to make sure they designed an agreement that was fair to the shareholders of both companies.
Despite the progress, Procter officials said yesterday that they would not be able to meet their long-term goals of 5 percent sales growth and at least 10 percent earnings growth in the next fiscal year. Amy Low Chasen, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs said Mr. Lafley should continue to find ways to continue to drive down costs in line with those of Procter's rivals.
"I think they are making some good progress," Ms. Chasen said. "They are early days yet. This is not a six-month turnaround, nor should it be a six-month turnaround. He is doing what he said he would do."

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron 

 BODY:
A Good Dish Is Worth Its Price
 Time to ask a former aide about that eight-figure book deal. 
 GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS had a four-word reaction -- "Hey, good for him" -- to former President Bill Clinton's $10 million advance, which is roughly three and a half times the $2.8 million that Mr. Stephanopoulos was paid for his own memoir. 
Mr. Stephanopoulos, now a political analyst for ABC News, was ready with advice for the first-time author. The challenge of writing a memoir, he said, is in "choosing what deserves to be in the narrative." In Mr. Clinton's case, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "All he has to do is say what he saw, what he said and what he felt."
But Mr. Clinton won't be spending all his time writing.
According to The Guardian in London, Mr. Clinton has been offered a visiting professorship, with salary, by the London School of Economics. The invitation is well timed, since the Clintons' daughter, Chelsea, will be entering Oxford in the fall.
A spokesman for the London School of Economics confirmed that Mr. Clinton would be giving a lecture late this year, but would not comment on the possibility of a professorship. If the job happens, the salary -- the equivalent of about $14,000 -- will seem like a tip compared with the book deal.

Comedy From Tragedy
A former jewelry wholesaler who started a foundation in memory of his son is worried that the film "Bubble Boy" -- which stars SWOOSIE KURTZ and JAKE GYLLENHAAL and is scheduled to open on Aug. 24 -- will hit too close to home. The film is about a boy born with immune-system problems who grew up in a plastic bubble that was supposed to protect him from germs. But the film is billed as a comedy.
"It's like a punch in the stomach," said FRED MODELL, a founder of the Jeffrey Modell Foundation, named for his son, who died in 1986 of a form of pneumonia his body was unable to conquer. "This is surely not something that I think can be dismissed with a silly comedy."
Mr. Modell has been circulating a letter that a 10-year-old boy with the disease wrote to MICHAEL D. EISNER, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, whose Touchstone Pictures unit is distributing "Bubble Boy." "I spend many hours a month getting transfusions at the hospital so I can try to stay healthy," the boy, SCOTT McGUIRE, wrote. "It would make me really sad to think while I am at the hospital, lots of people are sitting in a movie theater laughing about a serious disease." A Disney executive maintained the film would not make light of the disease or of people who suffer from it.

Pucker Your Lips and Paint
The trumpeter HERB ALPERT, whose Tijuana Brass had Top 10 hits alongside the Beatles in the 1960's, has just opened his first museum show. We are talking paintings here -- more than 75, as well as 40 bronze sculptures.
"I was overwhelmed by the whole show myself," Mr. Alpert said of the show, which opened on Friday at the State Museum in Nashville. "It was the first time I'd seen so much of my work together. I had it stored in various places around L.A."
"I've always had a little reservation about showing," he said yesterday in New York. "I didn't want people to say, 'Oh, yeah, Herb Alpert, we know this guy, he probably paints on Sundays.' I wanted to make sure the work was received on its own merits. There's a built-in danger of people recognizing you for something else, I think."
But he is recognized for something else. So?
"I'm blowing the horn every day," he said. "I'm in the mood for flamenco jazz."

A Rebate of a Rebate
Don't ask the octogenarian real estate developer SAMUEL J. LEFRAK how he is spending his federal income tax rebate, the $300 check from President Bush's $1.35 trillion tax-cut plan.
"I did not get mine," Mr. Lefrak said. "I got my Social Security check on the first of the month but I didn't get a refund." If the check comes, though, Mr. LeFrak has a plan. "I'm going to endorse it and send it right back. What am I going to do with $300? If you want to talk about taxes, all I know is, the minute I put the key in the door of my office, 50 percent of what I earn, I send to Washington."

HEADLINE: TURF; 
Prairie Home Impresarios

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

DATELINE: BONAPARTE, Iowa 

 BODY:
ONE summer morning, a middle-aged man slowly pedaled a shiny silver Schwinn along the dusty main street here. He passed freshly painted Victorian facades gleaming in the 9 o'clock sunshine. He passed store windows with "For Sale" signs in them.
 Twenty minutes went by. No one else appeared. 
 In this former mill town in southeastern Iowa, about three hours' drive from Des Moines, the population is 462 and dwindling. Tufts of grass grow in lots at either end of the main street, known here as First Street; a stucco filling station, built in the 1920's, is open but never busy. The nearest stoplight is in the next county. There's only one place for visitors to stay downtown: a tiny cabin with a sign that reads "The Cottage: Bed and Make Your Own Breakfast." 
But do not be deceived by appearances. 
This spring, the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a nonprofit group in Washington, named Bonaparte one of its 12 Distinctive Destinations. The award is given to "vacation spots" with "strong, vibrant downtowns."
"We were worried when we won that one," said Steve Adam, a mild-mannered city councilman, sitting at his kitchen table. "We were worried that if anybody showed up, they'd be disappointed. What will anyone do here?"
The inhabitants of Bonaparte have developed a skill that most other rural towns lack: they know how to fill out applications. 
"You've got to sell yourself," said Rebecca Reynolds, 52, a state representative and former mayor of Bonaparte, who refined the art of prairie grantsmanship and then passed it on to her successors. "You've got to put it out in the first two pages. You've got to get your message out on the cover sheet."
While other rural towns struggle to subsist, Bonaparte has learned to promote itself as a buzzing destination, gambling that the reality will live up to their pitch.
Fourteen years ago, when Ms. Reynolds, a nurse with five grown children, became mayor, the little town with the empty storefronts started winning grants and prizes. In 1988, the year after she took office, Bonaparte was granted local-government status, which allowed it to seek state money. Bonaparte's riverfront downtown was also placed on the National Register of Historic Places. 
"It looks good when you apply for grants," Connie Meek, the town clerk, explained. 
The next year, the downtown was designated for urban revitalization, freeing up tax credits to rehabilitate the 19th-century storefronts. In 1990, Ms. Reynolds ran for county supervisor and won. Her gift for grants has been perpetuated by Mrs. Meek.
In 1991, Bonaparte got a state grant to replace First Street's tangle of crisscrossing electrical wires, to erect reproduction gas street lights and to replace the aging sidewalks. When the Des Moines River buried the town in mud in 1993, Bonaparte received $1.3 million in relief grants.
Altogether, the town, whose budget this year totals $225,000, has netted $2.2 million in assorted fix-up funds, plus a handful of morale-boosting titles, including All-America City Finalist (1997) and a Great American Main Street Award (1996).
But of all its prizes, the one that surprised its citizens most, including Ms. Reynolds, was the National Trust award. What did she think of the part about the "vibrant downtown"?
"Well, I didn't write it!" the former mayor replied, laughing.
So far, there hasn't been an onslaught of sightseers, although since the destinations award, some say, the traffic has picked up on weekends. But there still aren't many places to stay: the closest national-chain motel is at least 35 miles away. By contrast, Red Lodge, Mont. (pop. 2,500), another of this year's Distinctive Destinations, has nine chain motels, one 19th-century hotel, 17 bed-and-breakfasts and dozens of rental condominiums.
Many people in Bonaparte say they don't know how they earned the award. Nor do they recall the National Trust ever visiting.
"No, they didn't come here," said Lee Kephart, the current mayor. "But I believe they had some pictures."
Kennedy Smith, who directs the trust's Main Street program, said the mayor was mistaken. "I've been there a dozen times," she said. The new mayor may not have been aware of her visits, she explained, because the last one was "two or three years ago."
She said she had nominated Bonaparte for the Distinctive Destinations list because it had improved so much since the flood of 1993.
Asked how Bonaparte could plausibly be a tourist destination with lodging for only one family, she replied: "It doesn't say national tourist destination. It could be a regional tourist destination."
Like for day-trippers?
"That's right," she said.
It doesn't matter much to the people of Bonaparte how they came to be a destination. Like the citizens of River City in "The Music Man," they have come to believe in themselves. Like Scarlett O'Hara and Little Orphan Annie, they believe in tomorrow. They are boasting of their latest award on their Web site, www.bonaparte-iowa.com.
While the main street sleeps, the Web site is humming. This spring, the home page announced that "nearly half of the Historic Buildings are available." And that "they are stabilized and ready for business development." By June, the site had adopted a slicker design, with a picture from the sixth annual historic cemetery tour. It now offers tourists "a new flavor of potential for those with discriminating tastes."
It has been a while since the town thrived. Bonaparte peaked shortly after 1878, when a four-story gristmill was built. Back then, the town supported four doctors, four grocers, four dry-goods stores, three milliners and two hotels. But by 1895, the population had fallen 37 percent from the decade before: the beginning of a manufacturing recession from which the town has never recovered.
Last year, the Fairfield Glove Company's factory, situated in a brick structure with delicate iron tracery on its metal awning, moved its operations back to Fairfield, Iowa. Today, only glove-making machinery and empty wooden boxes marked "Good Luck Gloves" are visible through the front windows. Only a couple of trucking companies, and Riverside Plastics, up on the hill, remain.
Almost a decade ago, Marilyn Thomas and her husband, Donald, bought an abandoned pottery and began cleaning out the old shards and dirt in preparation for paying tourists. A hand-lettered sign "Admission -- $3" is now posted at the back door entrance. Along with the $3 tour, Ms. Thomas also sells a $12 history of the pottery, bound in blue paper.
Bonaparte has also been picked for a far grander enterprise. Brock Womack, a performance artist and stained-glass maker from Des Moines, has optioned 1,200 acres of farmland on the edge of town for a Renaissance theme park and jousting festival. Mr. Womack, who has a Shakespearean goatee and shoulder-length hair, said he planned to raise $10 million to buy the land and build a jousting arena, castle, museum and walled keep.
There is guarded optimism about the plan. "We've been burned before, with so many investors coming in saying, 'We'll do this and we'll do that,' " said Jacki Gunn, 38, president of Bonaparte Main Street, a local development group. "But he's been here a year and a half. I'm not willing to write it off yet." 
She's more concerned, she said, with the fate of the Township Stores -- the grocery, drugstore and medical buildings rescued from destruction in 1987 by the sale of ownership shares to citizens at $2,000 apiece. There aren't many shoppers in the Township Grocery aisles, and the shelves look a little bare. "There's only 400 people, and they only buy so much," said Michael T. Gunn, president of Township Stores and one of its initial backers. 
"A lot of them go to Burlington," Mrs. Thomas said. "It's about 45 minutes away, but there's shopping malls and that type of thing."
If the store was truly in danger of closing, Mrs. Thomas said, she and a lot of citizens would pitch in. "They'd just open it up again, and we'd all give our $2,000 again."
For all its near-death experiences, there is a certain defiant spirit in Bonaparte. "History tells us that all these small towns are going to disappear," said Charles Easter, a retired security guard and another one of the Township Stores' original backers. 
"But I think Bonaparte is going to hang on longer -- just because the damned people aren't going to give up!"

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1725 words

HEADLINE: Romanov Style At Peasant Prices 

BYLINE:  By JOHN VAROLI 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG 

 BODY:
WHEN Michael Rundell, an artist and interior designer in London, cast about for a second home eight years ago, he dismissed Europe's well-known capitals as too expensive and too, well, developed. Even in Barcelona, he said, "I became tired of how everything is meticulously designed there, right down to the fire hydrants." 
 So Mr. Rundell, like other restless urban pioneers, turned to the rundown historical center of St. Petersburg, a 298-year-old city where both architectural innovation and standard building maintenance, came to a halt nearly a century ago. 
 Inspired by a vision of Russian aristocratic beauty -- and aided by a large pool of cheap skilled labor -- Mr. Rundell, 43, now owns four remodeled czarist-era apartments, with plans to buy two more. He and his family spend several days a month at one of his new apartments, which overlooks the Fontanka Canal. Before the Revolution, it belonged to Modest Tchaikovsky, brother of the composer Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky. 
"I wanted to go where there was a total absence of design, but a rich past and culture to draw from," he said. "St. Petersburg proved to be the ideal answer because it has fantastic pre-1917 architecture, and when you see these structures crumbling, you just want to rebuild them." 
From as far as California and Australia they come, a new class of globe-trotting urbanites, drawn by 12-foot ceilings, gorgeous views and cut-rate prices. There are no official statistics on the St. Petersburg renaissance, but hundreds of foreigners have joined a new Russian elite in reviving the 25-square-mile historical district. Now that Soviet restrictions on foreign residents and investment are gone, anyone with $50,000 can have a piece of St. Petersburg's past. Americans are highly visible, but the newcomers also include Britons, Italians and others.
"The opportunities in St. Petersburg are enormous," said Richard Blinder of Beyer Blinder Belle, an architectural firm that worked on restoring Grand Central Terminal. At a conference here in June on saving historical city centers, he described St. Petersburg as having one of Europe's largest concentrations of architecturally impressive 18th- and 19th-century buildings.
The city's architecturally aware emigres include August Meyer, 38, who quit his job as a deputy public prosecutor in San Diego two years ago and moved here to pursue a career as real estate developer and aspiring innkeeper. He now owns six apartments in the city center and plans to rent five of them to tourists. 
"Where else in the world would I have this?" he asked, gesturing out the window of a 2,150-square-foot apartment, bought in December for about $54,000, on the winding Griboyedov Canal. He has spent more than twice that on renovations, tearing down walls to make one 1,290-square-foot room and putting in parquet floors with floral patterns like those in the czar's Winter Palace.
"The opulence you can acquire here is vastly cheaper" than in other cities, Mr. Meyer said. "I fully intend on dying here. Just think how fabulous this city will be as it develops."
Most newcomers soon discover that remodeling requires a good deal more than scraping off wallpaper and pulling up shag carpeting. During 85 years of Soviet rule, imperial apartments were converted into poorly maintained warrens. When Mr. Rundell bought his 3,350-square-foot apartment in 1993, two dozen people were living there, sharing two kitchens and one bathroom. 
The prospective owner can take possession only after giving each tenant a cash payment or buying each one a new one-room apartment. That usually costs $35,000 to $60,000, total. But the paperwork is staggering, taking at least three months, and it is bewildering to non-Russians. 
"People think that because it's so cheap to buy an apartment, it's a great deal," said Katya Galitzine, a sculptor, who is buying an apartment and is the author of "St. Petersburg: The Hidden Interiors" (Vendome Press, 1999). "But they don't understand how difficult the process can be. Still, I like the rules and the bureaucracy because it protects the city heritage." 
Because of the way the apartments were chopped up in Soviet times, few original details survive. "But foreigners often want to create a palace they couldn't afford in the West, one with marble and perfect parquet floors," said Ilmar Karuso, an Australian interior designer who moved here three years ago and has half a dozen foreign clients. "Most are not interested in restoring the apartment as it used to be but prefer to gut the place and start anew." 
Douglas Boyce, an American who is helping to revive the Imperial Porcelain Factory, bought a center-city apartment five years ago. He tore down the interior walls and hired a Russian designer to create three rooms with strong angles and geometries, a look he said was inspired by the Constructivist avant-garde in 1920's Russia.
Rooms that have lost their original glory can often be brought back by artisans who -- until the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union -- rebuilt palaces damaged during World War II. Mr. Rundell, for example, had no trouble commissioning things like wood doors and kitchen tiles. "The artisans I hired had been working restoring the Catherine Palace in Pushkin," he said. "They were unemployed, and I just snapped them up" -- at about a tenth the cost of skilled labor in London.
It took them four years to do four rooms, among other things creating a pair of glass doors inlaid with real butterflies, using a technique Mr. Rundell developed with Damien Hirst, the British artist.
The workers are up to the kitchen. Mr. Rundell has ordered handmade tiles with a hammer-and-sickle motif: "very 1930's and 1940's Stalinist Soviet kitsch," he said. "The tiles," he added, "will be complemented by a work surface with mosaics of other Soviet-era proletarian propaganda motifs -- tractors, airplanes, blast furnaces, Soviet flags."
Sometimes one great apartment leads to another. Five years ago, Gen. Gianalfonso d'Avossa, 61, retired from the Italian Army in Milan and moved into a spacious 19th-century apartment overlooking the Neva River. Now he's hunting for a second place for visiting friends. 
General d'Avossa has decorated his apartment with ornate 18th-century Neapolitan chairs and sofas and other antiques. "Some of these items have been all over the world with me, and now they are here in Russia for good," he said. He hired local artists and craftsmen to add classical touches, including plaster torsos to flank the gas fireplace. There is now a painting of Mars, the Roman god of war, on the ceiling of the main room. The floor of the balcony has a mosaic of his family's coat of arms and the words strength, courage, intelligence and love in Italian.
Though construction workers in Russia were raised on decades of Soviet propaganda about class warfare, most are happy to see well-to-do expatriates fix up buildings that "would otherwise continue to decay," said a craftsman, who would give only his first name, Maksim. 
Yekaterina Bogolubova, an analyst with the St. Petersburg Association of Realtors, said most Russians believe that when foreigners buy historical properties, "everyone wins." Artisans and construction workers find employment, and former tenants get their first private apartments after decades of tightly shared quarters. 
Members of the new elite meanwhile enjoy the role of patriarchs. "The new owners sometimes feel themselves to be a new noble class inheriting former luxurious czarist-era apartments," Ms. Bogolubova remarked. 
While foreigners are the most conspicuous new residents in the historical district, Russians are also contributing to the renaissance. Sergei Bugayev, 35, a performance artist, has turned his three-bedroom apartment into a showcase for his vast collection of 19th-century rural furniture and Soviet kitsch. He has also installed new furnishings with Soviet motifs. 
Another Russian artist, Aleksandr Arkhipenko, 49, has an apartment inside a 40-foot tower atop an early-20th-century building. He is turning it into a triplex with views of the State Hermitage Museum and of the fortress of Peter and Paul, which serves as the family crypt for the Romanov czars and czarinas. 
A great hall on the windowless first floor of the tower has a four-foot fireplace suitable for roasting meat on a spit, and empty 18th- and 19th-century picture frames hang alongside abstract paintings by Mr. Arkhipenko. A spiral staircase climbs to the second floor, which is flooded by light from 12 windows. 
"In my childhood, it was always my dream to live in a castle, and when I saw this place I knew I had to live here," Mr. Arkhipenko said. 
Anastasia Melnikova, an actress, also has a view of the onion dome on the Church of the Resurrection of Christ. Descended from Russian nobility, she borrowed heavily from friends four years ago to buy one of the finest early-19th-century apartments in the city, at the intersection of the Moika and Griboyedov canals.
"When I saw this place, with its view, I knew I had to live here, no matter what the cost," she said.
So far, working on her own and with advice from friends who are designers, Ms. Melnikova has only been able to tear down the flimsy internal walls and put in new windows. Several rooms are so unfinished that they are impossible to enter. 
But when money allows, she hopes to decorate one room in the simple style of Peter the Great's era, when Russian architecture and decor were influenced by the Dutch. She would like another room to reflect the style of Czar Paul I, who straddled the 18th and 19th centuries, and a third to adopt the Empire style of Napoleon's time, popular in Russia in the early 19th century. 
"My place won't be a museum because it has to be livable," Ms. Melnikova said, "but I think these various styles can be made to work together." 
It's not historical preservation in conventional American terms, but closer to a freewheeling architectural relief effort. But with the 300th anniversary of St. Petersburg just two years off, a more coordinated effort may soon begin. The Russian government has announced plans to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the city infrastructure. As some of that money finds its way into the historical center, it will meet improvement efforts by individuals who are fixing up downtown St. Petersburg, one room at a time.

HEADLINE: Economy Remained Slow in June and July, Fed Reports 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 

 BODY:
The economy remained sluggish in June and July as the slide in manufacturing began to spread to other sectors, the Federal Reserve said today.
 "Reports from most Federal Reserve districts point to slow growth or lateral movement in economic activity in June and July," the Fed said in its anecdotal survey of national economic conditions, also known as the beige book. 
 Weakness in the factory sector was seen in almost all regions, the central bank said. "Sustained weakness in the manufacturing sector spilled over to other businesses, with many districts indicating declines in demand for office space and trucking and shipping services," the Fed said. 
The report, compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and based on information gathered before July 30, will be used by the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-setting arm of the Fed, when it next meets to set interest rates on Aug. 21.
Analysts said the generally grim tone of the report lent support to the idea of further cuts in interest rates.
"It confirms the notion that the economy was weak headed into the third quarter," said Richard Berner, chief economist at Morgan Stanley in New York.
Some of the report's bleakest anecdotal detail dealt with factory activity, which has borne the brunt of the economic slowdown this year. In July, manufacturing shed 49,000 workers. It has lost 837,000 jobs the last 12 months.
"Reports of reduced work hours, lost overtime, forced furloughs, planned shutdowns and layoffs were pervasive," the report said. It noted specific weakness in clothing, computers, semiconductors, steel and telecommunications gear production.
"In addition to conditions in the domestic economy, districts attributed the current malaise in manufacturing to softening international demand for U.S. goods, particularly in Europe and Asia," the report said.
Retail sales were also sluggish and frequently below expectations during the survey period, despite discounts intended to lure shoppers to stores.
Some retailers asked manufacturers to hold onto goods until existing inventories had been sold, and the pessimistic retailing mood also showed up in the form of lower back-to-school and Christmas orders, the Fed said.
The continued weakness in the economy did, however, have a brighter side in the form of reduced pressure to increase prices.
"Continued slow economic growth loosened labor markets and eased wage pressures in most districts in June and July, but rising benefit costs continued to add to compensation costs," the Fed said. Employers were trying to trim those benefit expenses. The Kansas City Fed said area companies were looking at ways to cut free parking and health club perks.
Falling production costs and stiff competition also kept consumer-level prices in check, the report said.
A separate government report showed that inventories on wholesalers' shelves fell slightly in June while sales tumbled, mainly because of slower sales of durable items.
Wholesale inventories fell 0.2 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted $302.3 billion, after posting a revised 0.3 percent gain in the previous month, the Commerce Department said. The inventory decline was slightly larger than expected.
Sales, however, fell 0.9 percent, to $226.83 billion, after a 0.5 percent drop the previous month. The sales numbers were pulled down by the durable goods category, which fell 1.3 percent compared with a decline of only 0.2 percent in May.
The stock-to-sales ratio -- a measure of how long it would take to deplete stocks at the current sales pace -- was 1.33 month's worth in June compared with 1.32 in May. This is the highest ratio since 1.34 in February 1999.

HEADLINE: Ontario's New Welfare Rule: Be Literate and Drug Free 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: ETOBICOKE, Ontario 

 BODY:
The province of Ontario is taking a tougher stance on welfare than has ever been tried before in Canada. It plans to make passing a literacy test mandatory for receiving public assistance and it will screen recipients for drug or alcohol problems, cutting off benefits to those who refuse treatment.
 In a country where government compassion toward the disadvantaged is widely considered a national trait, the strict new measures to be imposed this fall have been characterized as mean-spirited, overly harsh and possibly in violation of Ontario's human rights code. 
 But officials defend the measures, contending that they are necessary in order to push people still receiving assistance toward independence. Years of whittling down the welfare rolls have left only the "hardest to serve" clients still receiving assistance, they say. 
"Our welfare caseload has decreased 60 percent over the last six years, but it has not disappeared," said John Baird, Ontario's minister of community and social services. "The question now is, what is it going to take to get the rest of the recipients from welfare to work?"
Mr. Baird said experts had identified illiteracy and addictions as among the greatest obstacles keeping longtime welfare recipients from entering the work force. Although there is no evidence that people on welfare have a higher incidence of those problems than other people, Mr. Baird said that someone who could not read a business memo or function with alertness because of an addiction would always be shut out of the job market. 
"If someone has a problem with literacy or addiction and refuses to get help, I don't know what else Ontario can do for them," Mr. Baird said. 
The province intends to start screening for literacy and addiction problems by October. People who fail the literacy test will be required to enroll in workfare programs like the Preparatory Training Program, which operates from the second floor of a building in a strip mall here in this western Toronto enclave. 
The government of Premier Mike Harris of the Progressive Conservative Party has won two terms promising that welfare reform will help reduce spending and cut taxes in Ontario, Canada's most populous province. Six years ago, more than a million Ontario residents received welfare. The Harris government has phased in workfare programs similar to those used in the United States, and rolls have shrunk by more than 580,000, reducing annual costs by more than $5 billion. 
But as with the American programs, Ontario's have reached the point at which reducing welfare rolls further is far more difficult. The remaining recipients have been on welfare for many years and often have problems that keep them from finding work even in a robust economy. 
The literacy test, requiring clients to fill in a brief answer sheet, does not strictly measure reading skills but rather measures a facility with words and numbers required for basic work skills, officials said.
In the literacy training program here, which the government sees as a model for an expanded, mandatory program, about 100 students, all on welfare, learn how to write memos, do basic accounting and provide customer service. One student, Sandra Neil, 44, recently began a class on how to operate a cash register. 
Miss Neil, a mother of four, has been on welfare since she lost her job as a janitor at a local college five years ago. She said that forcing people like her to take a literacy test in order to receive public assistance would be unfair because she never finished high school.
"I don't have the education for it," she said. "I'd fail every time."
Other welfare recipients who were born outside Canada are worried that they will be at a disadvantage because they do not know English well enough to pass the test. 
"It's not good when you have to force people to do it," said Mercedes Ubiera, 39, who came to Canada from the Dominican Republic 15 years ago not speaking a word of English. 
Another woman in the class, Fardousa Hassan, 26, came from Somalia nine years ago and has already attended English classes. She said she was not worried about being forced to take a literacy test but she was worried that if she did find a job she might not find day care for her four children. 
Like Mrs. Hassan, critics of the government are concerned about the lack of day care and other social services to help welfare recipients get back on their feet. They say welfare clients are coming under this pressure because it is a politically popular thing to do.
"I do not believe for a second that the goal here is to help these people," said Michael Gravelle, a legislator with the Ontario Liberal Party. "The real goal is finding another way of kicking people off welfare." 
Mr. Gravelle said he especially objected to the drug screening, in large measure because mandatory programs like this have not proved effective. 
Similar efforts to link drug treatment to welfare reform have been struck down in the United States because they required mandatory testing of all welfare applicants. Ontario officials said they carefully studied the situation in the United States and avoided similar problems by requiring screening, not chemical testing, as a first step.
Under the Ontario system, trained social workers would look for evidence of an addiction, like needle marks or incoherence during an interview. If the screener concluded that a welfare recipient had a drug problem, the person would be required to enroll in a treatment program, or risk having welfare benefits cut off. If the person disagreed with the screener's conclusion, the only option would be to submit to chemical testing. 
While Ontario has tried to avoid a clash with the courts, the drug screening may still violate the province's human rights code, said Keith C. Norton, chief commissioner of the Ontario Human Rights Commission. In the province, alcohol or drug dependency is considered a disability, and Ontario's human rights code prohibits discrimination against disabled people.
"There is a great risk that the test will be challenged and shot down by the courts," Mr. Norton said. 
But the province insists that it will proceed with plans to have a pilot program for literacy testing and addiction screening running by October. 
"If we backed down on welfare reform every time someone threatened to take us to court," said Mr. Baird, the social services minister, "we wouldn't have accomplished anything."
