HEADLINE: TALKING POLITICS: Bushwick and Williamsburg; 
In a Poor Hispanic District, Housing Is Voters' Priority

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
In just under a decade, Rafael and Milagros Hernandez have found in New York City many of the everyday comforts that eluded them back home in the Dominican Republic: clean water, reliable electricity, steady jobs and, in the last few years, safer streets for their children.
 Like many others in the city, Democrats and Republicans alike, the Hernandezes attribute much of their good fortune to the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is stepping down Dec. 31 at the end of his second term. Six men -- four Democrats and two Republicans -- are running for the job. 
 The Hernandezes, who hope to become United States citizens shortly so they can vote this fall, do not know the names of any of the six mayoral candidates or the promises they are making. Yet, after eight years in which their lives have improved -- crime is down, subways are cleaner, the landlord has just renovated their apartment -- the couple expect the next mayor to continue to better their lives. 
The question, then, is what do they want the most?
"A three-bedroom apartment," said Mr. Hernandez, 39. 
"Cheap," Mrs. Hernandez, 34, chimed in. "Cheaper than this."
The Hernandez family pays $550 for a tiny two-bedroom apartment on Scholes Street, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Lack of space, for them, means not having a room for their boys, 11, 10 and 3, to play indoors on cold days, a place to put a desk for them to do homework or even to put a table to gather around for family dinner.
In their quest for a bigger and better apartment, the Hernandezes are hardly alone in this working-class slice of northwest Brooklyn, the area in the shadow of the J, M and Z subway lines in Bushwick and Williamsburg. 
In dozens of interviews, residents talked about what they expected from the next mayor. Their biggest concern by far was housing: clean, spacious, cheap homes, free of mice and roaches. 
It is a common request in a city where some people live in apartments that elsewhere would be considered oversized closets. But it is a particularly vexing problem for Bushwick and Williamsburg, where 70 percent of the population is Hispanic and many are on public assistance. 
"I represent one of the poorest districts in the state," said Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, whose district, the 53rd, includes Bushwick, Williamsburg and parts of Greenpoint. "Whoever is the next mayor of New York City needs to make a real commitment to delivering services to minorities in poor communities."
A little more than half of the residents in Mr. Lopez's district are registered to vote, but only 29 percent did so in the last mayoral election, compared with 40 percent citywide. Because so many of the potential Hispanic voters there are not registered, the 53rd District is ripe territory to nurture one of the fastest-growing segments of New York City: young Latinos who have inherited no political allegiances from their parents and whose loyalty is up for grabs. Mr. Giuliani did not carry the district in 1997, but it was close. He lost to Ruth Messinger by only 315 votes.
Many longtime residents in the district are Puerto Rican, but those who have arrived in recent years are from all over the Americas, including the Dominican Republic, El Salvador and Mexico. The district is not devoid of diversity: 13 percent of the population is non-Hispanic white, 8 percent is black and 5 percent Asian.
Mr. Lopez, a Democrat, boasts that, on his watch, 1,800 homes and apartments subsidized by the city and state have been built, with 500 more due to be built soon. 
"And we can't keep up with the demand," he said. 
Just a few years ago, few people wanted to live in the district. Crime was high. Drug dealers were recruiting customers alongside mothers walking their children to school. There were 1,500 abandoned buildings or empty lots in the area, the result of years of arson and looting that began after the citywide blackout in July 1977, Mr. Lopez said. The empty lots were a magnet for youth gangs, drug users and rats.
Today, he said, all but 50 of the lots have given way to new homes. Drugs, though still present, are no longer part of the daily landscape. For the most part, youth gangs have been chased away by aggressive policing. Many Bushwick residents said they were pleased that they knew the name or face of the police officer who patrols their streets every day on foot.
But some residents say they know them too well. Carlos Ramos, 34, was sitting with a friend on the steps of a building on Central Avenue. Asked what he wanted from the next mayor, Mr. Ramos quickly said, "To keep the cops off of us."
Mr. Ramos, who works as the manager of a health club, said the police had stopped him countless times. He was arrested once on trespassing charges, but those were dropped. He believes he is a victim of some sort of profiling. He wears a ponytail, a gold chain around his neck and gold hoops in his ears. He has a tattoo on his beefy left arm. 
Echoing the comments of many of his neighbors, Mr. Ramos said he was not sure whom he would vote for this year. That he is Puerto Rican and a Democrat, he said, does not necessarily mean that he would vote for Fernando Ferrer, the Puerto Rican Bronx borough president who, polls show, is a favorite among Hispanics in the city. Some of the candidates have visited churches in Bushwick on Sundays this summer, but Mr. Ramos has neither seen them nor been inspired by their messages. 
"I've got to see what they each bring to the table," Mr. Ramos said. "There are too many issues: schools are overcrowded, kids have nothing to do, there are not enough parks for kids to play in. Meanwhile, everybody is trying to make a better life for themselves, and they can't."
Ramon Rodriguez, 65, has lived and worked in a corner building at Broadway and Whipple Street in Williamsburg for 24 years. He runs a bridal shop on the second floor and lives with his son, Raymond, 14, on the third floor.
Mr. Rodriguez, who says he votes in every election, is distraught at the slow pace of progress. "Why don't they give away the old, abandoned buildings?" he asked. "The private sector can create housing for those who need it and we won't have to look at those abandoned lots anymore. Things are better than 10 years ago, yes, but not yet where they should and could be."
The improved neighborhoods and drop in crime have had an unintended effect, Mr. Rodriguez said. In some areas of the district, rents have gone up, forcing out residents whose incomes did not keep pace.
"Those who can, leave the neighborhood," he said. "Those who stay, don't have anything. So we are always dealing with the poorest of the poor."
Vicente Tarrax says he has no choice but to stay in a dilapidated, tiny apartment on Wilson Street in Bushwick. Retired at 65, after 27 years as a seaman, he said he had been unable to get his building's landlord to fix the water leaks that have stained his walls a dull gray and worsened his chronic arthritis. Last winter, the heat was cut off, he said.
In his shirt pocket Mr. Tarrax keeps pictures of his apartment, which he shows to anyone who cares to look at them. He said he had gone to several municipal offices looking for help, but to no avail. Still, Mr. Tarrax said, he likes what Mr. Giuliani has done for the city and for Bushwick.
"They say he has shown excessive force in dealing with the problems of the city, and that the police are out of control," he said. "But I have been to just about every country in the world and I have seen what an out-of-control police can do to its people, and this is not it."
Still, Mr. Tarrax said, he wished he had a better apartment to go home to after his daily game of dominoes and his occasional fishing outings.
"If I had the money, I'd never return to that place," he said.
Carlos Vega, 29, works two jobs as a security guard, in a public hospital and for a private security company. He said he and his wife, who works as a waitress, can hardly make ends meet with two children and a monthly rent of $800 for a two-bedroom apartment on Leonard Street in Williamsburg.
"And we've been told that it's going up to $1,200 at the end of January," Mr. Vega said, pulling family-size cooking-oil containers and liquid laundry detergent from his car. "How can they expect working families to continue to live in these neighborhoods?"
Mr. Vega, who said he disliked Mr. Giuliani for cutting the budgets of the public hospitals, says the mayor has done little for his community. Yes, the streets are cleaner and safer, but in the park where his children play, maintenance workers sweep up dozens of empty crack vials every morning. And his neighborhood fared less well than the rest of the city in the economic boom of the 1990's, he said.
Carmen Rivera, 40, agrees. A lifelong resident of public housing in Williamsburg, Ms. Rivera said she wished she could move out of the project, where she raised two children, now 19 and 16, and is raising a 2-year-old, but she cannot afford it.
"There is more housing, yes, but people can't pay for it," said Ms. Rivera, who works as an after-school-program coordinator in a public school and as a supervisor in a city-financed summer camp.
Ms. Rivera, who says she plans to vote but does not yet know for whom, has other concerns besides housing. She said the state of the public schools sometimes kept her awake at night.
"Teachers have lost all control of the students," she said, as she kept an eye on her charges playing in Lindsay Park, at Leonard and Boerum Streets. "And if you can't control the classroom, you can't teach. It's not like it was when I sent my two oldest to school."
Marlene Burey, 43, a nurse's assistant who just bought her first home in Bushwick, said her main concern was the poor state of the public schools. With four children, all of them still in school, Ms. Burey said she was particularly worried about the quality of the teachers.
"Giuliani didn't do enough for teachers," she said. "They get so little money that the best teachers get discouraged and go elsewhere." She suggested raising teachers' salaries.
Ms. Burey, who was born in Jamaica, plans to vote for the first time in this election, but does not yet know for whom. 
Ms. Rivera does not have a favorite either, but may not need to. She has other plans. Asked what the next mayor should do for the schools, Ms. Rivera shrugged and said: "Hopefully, I won't be here to see what the next mayor will do. By the time my son is ready for school, I plan to be in Florida."

HEADLINE: School-Building Switch Rejoins What Was Split 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The idea of taking the Board of Education out of the business of school construction first came to Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy some seven years ago when Ramon C. Cortines was chancellor and Mr. Levy headed a special panel on improving school maintenance.
 "I urged him to give the capital planning function away," Mr. Levy said Tuesday. "I told him that he didn't come here to be the chancellor of maintenance; get it off your plate." 
 Now, Mr. Levy is taking his own advice. On Tuesday, after noting that the school construction budget overrun appears to have grown by nearly $1 billion, he recommended switching all responsibilities for the planning, building and renovation of schools from the board's Division of School Facilities to the School Construction Authority, an independent agency.
In doing so, he would reunite two functions, the planning and the execution of new school construction, that were split in 1988 when the Legislature created the construction authority. Such a move would create one agency that could be held responsible for building schools according to a budget and opening them on time. But it is far from clear that such a move would solve the difficulties that have plagued the school construction effort for decades. 
While several other large cities or states have drawn on New York's example of setting up a separate agency to control school construction, many of them have lines of accountability that are clearer and more direct than New York's, where power is shared equally by the chancellor, the mayor and the governor. The chancellor is one of the agency's trustees, and the other two are appointees of the mayor and the governor. 
Whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki agree to the chancellor's plan could well depend on whether the chancellor is willing to turn over some authority. Ultimately, any discussion about where the responsibility for planning and budgeting for school construction should lie turns into a discussion about the governance of the school system as a whole.
Since he took the job, Mr. Levy has steadfastly refused to comment on whether he believes the mayor should control the school system, a change that is supported by both Mayor Giuliani and Governor Pataki. At the least, the chancellor might be pressured to lend his support to the idea that the mayor should control the school construction budget.
Yesterday, Mr. Levy said he believed the consolidation of the school facilities division and the construction authority could be accomplished through a "memorandum of understanding" between the two, and therefore would not require legislation. The law that created the construction authority in 1988 called for such a memorandum. But one was never agreed to by the two agencies.
"This originally was all one agency," Mr. Levy said yesterday. "It was pulled apart as a legislative matter. What I'm proposing is, go closer back to that original effort, and bond these two things together so that they'll function collaboratively, cooperatively."
Mayor Giuliani said yesterday that he agreed with the idea of transferring much of the responsibilities of the school facilities division to the construction authority. But, he added, the removal of Patricia Zedalis as head of the division of school facilities, announced on Tuesday, is not likely to solve the problem.
"I also think there is a degree of scapegoating going on," Mr. Giuliani said. "These decisions were not all made by one person. It may well be the case that the person selected to take the responsibility was really just carrying out their orders."
Asked yesterday about Ms. Zedalis, Mr. Levy said, "This is not about hanging anyone out to dry."
Rather, he said, "It's about putting a better management structure in place and making sure that the people being put into these positions have real accountability."
Mr. Levy appears to be conceding that there is far more to the construction cost overruns than simply the rising cost of construction in a booming economy, the rationale that board officials previously used for much of the new expense. 
New estimates from the construction authority show that it would need as much as $2.8 billion in additional money to complete the projects outlined through June 2004. 
Details about the new estimates will be released in the near future, Mr. Levy said, and it is likely that, in the absence of additional financing, some projects will have to be delayed until 2005 or later.
Whether the construction authority will be any better at estimating costs or adhering to a budget, however, is also far from certain. As long as the construction authority answers to two elected officials and one appointed one, there will remain a lack of strict accountability for decisions about school construction.

HEADLINE: Senate Leader to Challenge Bush Today on Missile Defense 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 

 BODY:
Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, plans to continue his challenge to President Bush on missile defense by accusing the president of taking a "single-minded approach" to national security, according to an advance text of a speech Mr. Daschle is to deliver on Thursday.
 The South Dakota Democrat argued in the speech that Mr. Bush's policies increase the risk of nuclear weapons spreading to countries that do not now have them and uses money that ought to be spent on more pressing security threats. 
 Mr. Daschle's remarks, to be made in a speech to the Woodrow Wilson Center , are part of an effort by prominent Democrats to portray Mr. Bush as a unilateralist. They set the stage for a struggle in September when Senate committees, under the control of Democrats, begin considering Mr. Bush's request for $343.3 billion for military programs for the new fiscal year, including $8.3 billion for missile defense.
Trying to paint Democrats as more responsive than Mr. Bush to the broader needs of the American military, Mr. Daschle said the $8.3 billion would represent a 57 percent increase for missile defense, at the expense of other security programs.
"We support an increase in both the Pentagon budget and in missile defense," he said, according to an advance text of the speech. "But a 57 percent increase this year -- along with the prospect of hundreds of billions of dollars in future years -- would cannibalize the personnel and force structure that deal with the threats we are likely to face."
Last month Mr. Daschle, who as the Senate majority leader is now the most powerful Democrat in Washington, was rebuked by the White House for calling Mr. Bush's foreign policy isolationist just as the president was embarking on an overseas trip. Republicans accused Mr. Daschle of ignoring the maxim that "politics stops at the water's edge.
But Mr. Daschle has not backed off. Noting that the administration has recently found fault with six international agreements, he said, "Instead of asserting our leadership, we are abdicating it."
With the cold war over, he argued, "Fear of a common enemy no longer keeps our allies by our side. Our allies will follow us only if we use our unparalleled strength and prosperity to advance common interests. Only then will our power inspire respect instead of resentment." 
As Democrats have stepped up such charges, the president's senior advisers have replied that the administration would apply the standard of American national interest in determining whether to support or reject international accords.
In the case of global warming, administration officials say, for example, that the pact would endanger the American economy and harm global financial health. On relations with Russia, the administration has stated that the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty is outdated and stands in the way of coupling historic reductions in nuclear arsenals with a new defense against ballistic missiles.
While Mr. Daschle said in the text of his speech that Democrats could under "the right circumstances," support a limited missile defense system, he accused Mr. Bush of putting far too much emphasis on a defense shield and of looking at complex relationships with Russia and China through the distorting prism of missile defense alone.
"What else could explain for example, President Bush's personal embrace of Russia's president Vladimir Putin -- while avoiding any public mention of Putin's crackdown on Russia's free press and their continuing atrocities in Chechnya?" he said.
Setting the stage for a battle over Pentagon priorities, Mr. Daschle described the chief threats to the United States as coming not from intercontinental ballistic missiles, but from "biological and chemical weapons and bombs that could be smuggled in a cargo container, bus or backpack" as well as attacks on such infrastructure as computer systems.
"National missile defense," Mr. Daschle said, "is the most expensive possible response to the least likely threat we face." 
His speech cited a list of tradeoffs that could be made if Congress provides the missile defense program with only a 10 percent increase in the next fiscal year, freeing up $2.5 billion for other programs that he says will address "more imminent, more immediate threats."
Among his recommendations were restored funding to help Russia control and destroy nuclear weapons, training for emergency workers to deal with chemical or biological attack, an increased counterterrorism budget, reinforced border patrols, increased research into cruise missile defense, and funding to help control North Korea's nuclear fuel production and re-engage it on ending its missile program.
"These are all here and now threats," he said, "and we could fund all of these programs at levels necessary to start addressing them without shortchanging our troops, the weapons systems they rely on or missile defense."

HEADLINE: Crouching Rowers, Spectacular Dragons, in Races in Queens 

BYLINE:  By SANDEE BRAWARSKY 

 BODY:
The 250-meter dragon-boat race doesn't take much more than a New York minute. In a long, narrow boat with a colorful dragon head at the bow and a spiky tail at the stern, 18 paddlers, seated two by two, dig their wooden paddles into the murky waters of Meadow Lake. Forcefully they pull back, as a 19th team member pounds a drum to keep their rhythm, and a 20th steers at the back with a long oar. They aim to move in perfect sync, propelling the boat across the finish line like an arrow. 
 This weekend Meadow Lake, created as part of the 1939 World's Fair in what is now Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, is to become an international aquatic racecourse as part of the 11th annual Hong Kong Dragon Boat Festival in New York. More than 1,000 men and women on 93 teams in several divisions will paddle at lengths of 250, 500 and 1,000 meters. The races run toward the north end of the lake, where the Unisphere is always in view. The Open Championship Race, offering a $10,000 cash prize, is scheduled for Sunday, rain or shine. 
 Onshore dragon dancers will lead a parade of teams tomorrow morning, opening the festival. Henry J. Stern, New York City parks commissioner, and Jacqueline Ann Willis, Hong Kong's commissioner to the United States, will have the honor of painting the red eyes on a fabric dragon, to symbolically bring to life the hand-crafted dragons attached to the boats. The activities surrounding the races reflect the ethnic diversity of the contestants, about half of whom are of Chinese descent. In between cheering on the boaters, spectators can hear Vallenato music of Colombian folklore or the songs of the New York Boys Choir; watch kung fu demonstrations; snack on Italian sausages, sushi or rice dumplings; and learn basic Chinese calligraphy and paper cutting.
This is a festival with a 2,000-year history. In the third century B.C., Qu Yuan, a minister in the Chinese kingdom of Chu, was popular among the people but disliked by the king, who banished him. During his exile he wandered, writing poetry expressing his love for his country. Soon after hearing that the capital of Chu was invaded in 278 B.C., Qu Yuan jumped into the Mi Lo River and drowned himself.
According to legend, local fishermen raced out onto the river to try to save him but couldn't. To distract the fish from devouring his body, they thrashed their paddles in the water and beat drums. They also threw rice dumplings to honor his spirit (and feed the fish). The dragon-boat races, held in many cities in China and around the world, commemorate the rescue attempts and honor this man, who was perhaps the first known of China's great poets.
In Hong Kong, Tuen Ng, or Dragon Boat Festival, is a public holiday, with many people drawn to the island's shores to watch the races. Several of the Hong Kong-born New Yorkers who are to race this weekend recall being part of the festival as youngsters, learning about Qu Yuan in school and especially eating jong, or rice dumplings. Although according to the lunar calendar the date of the race usually falls in June, the New York festival, the largest of several in the United States, is held in August because of weather.
Dragon boats, ubiquitous in Asia, are less recognizable in New York waters. But commuters on the No. 7 train regularly pass a stained-glass mural depicting such a boat at the 33rd Street station in Sunnyside, Queens. The teak vessels, made by hand in Hong Kong and modeled after centuries-old fishing boats, weigh 2,000 pounds each. Before the festival the boats are repainted, some with dragon scales on their sides.
Depending on the number of teams entered in a specific division, there may be preliminary heats before the finals. Usually four boats race at once. The shortest distance, 250 meters, takes less than a minute from start to finish line. The 1,000-meter race takes about four minutes. The races are often very close, and Ian Brooks, known as "the voice of the New York Road Runners Club," is to comment on the races and announce the winners above the roar of the crowd, expected to number more than 30,000. 
Teams come from all over New York City, as well as from around the United States and Canada, including a group of police officers and auxiliary police and corporate-sponsored squads and athletic clubs. Beginners are welcome on many teams.
Some of the more advanced New York City squads also race in the national championship in Philadelphia and the international championship in Hong Kong. The minimum age for racers is 18; there's no maximum, and some participants are over 65. Among aficionados there's a lot of talk -- and wishful thinking -- that dragon-boat racing will be named a demonstration sport at the Beijing Olympics in 2008. 
"Timing, timing, timing" is what most competitors say when asked about the necessary skills behind successful dragon-boat racing. They also mention strength and endurance, but there are no individual heroes, and no one tries to stand out.
"During the race you're all beating as one heart," Good Jean Lau, a member of the New York Wall Street Dragons, explains. "You need to mirror the stroke of the person diagonally in front of you. And you need to trust that the people in front are going to be in sync with the people in front of them. Competition keeps your spirit going."
Mrs. Lau, a dual-language resource specialist at P.S. 1 in Chinatown, who has taken part every year and is now active in getting young people involved in the sport, adds, "Once dragon boats are in your blood, it's hard to let go."
Each team has its own techniques; some raise their paddles out of the water with a twist, while some catch (hit the water) more aggressively. Kin Ng, coach and manager of the DCH team, named for Dah Chong Hong USA, its corporate sponsor, encourages team members to breathe at the same rate and to pull and then relax between strokes.
Mr. Ng, a prosecutor in the Brooklyn district attorney's office who used to race, explains that the people in the first three rows are technically the best paddlers, and they set an even, consistent pace. At the center are the largest team members, who have the longest strokes. ("They're the engine," he said.) The people in the back have the most aggressive strokes.
"It's a sprint race for the most part," he said. "The whole thing revolves around getting a good start so you can pull ahead early on and keep a psychological edge."
"Beside the sport itself, it's a tie for me back to my Chinese heritage," Mr. Ng said about dragon-boat racing. Two years ago he returned to Hong Kong for the first time in 20 years for a competition. In Chinese culture dragons are not evil, he noted, but symbolize energy, benevolence and good luck. "Dragons originated from water and contain mystical power," he said. "They bring good luck."
Raymond Fan, director of the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office in New York, explained that the Dragon Boat Festival was introduced to New York City in 1991 "as a project to raise Hong Kong's profile in New York City." Mr. Fan, who grew up in Hong Kong, organized the first festival, which was held on the Hudson River, with 3 boats, 10 teams and training help from the New York Fire Department. But the river was busy, and the water was choppy, "not conducive to very proper competition," he said, so the festival was moved to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.
In 1994 the festival was spun off as a separate project from the Trade Office, and the following year Henry Wan, a real-estate developer and builder in Flushing who sits on the boards of several community groups and has been involved with the festival since its beginning, was named chairman.
If Mr. Fan is the festival's father, then Mr. Wan, also born in Hong Kong, is its doting uncle and ambassador. Every Sunday since early June he has been out at the dock at Meadow Lake, coordinating practice for the teams. "Momentum is growing for the sport," he said, "and the festival gets larger every year."
On a recent Sunday, Team Library, sponsored by the Queens Borough Public Library, emerged from the water after a rigorous session. Rob Waters, the team's captain and steersman for the last six years, who serves as director of capital program management and facilities planning the library, was wearing the team's signature black tank top festooned with a dragon and splashed with lake water. He said he always tried to keep his teammates focused on working together.
"This is a venue with all the right stuff," he added, "without all the rancor and ego-driven competitiveness that goes along with athletics." 
When asked about team rituals, Nils Johnson, president of AsiaTone, a New York company that sponsors three crews under the name Xtreme NY, responded as he headed toward the boat for practice, "Our ritual is to go out for dim sum every Sunday." The only non-Chinese squad member, he is now his second year paddling, and he's "totally hooked," he said. "This is killing my summer in the Hamptons," he added. "Now it's summer in Flushing Meadows."
To get a closer look at the paddlers in action, I rode out on a motorized chase boat with Eric Young, a law student who has worked for the festival for several years. To keep up with the dragon boats, Mr. Young revved up the boat's eight-horsepower engine to full throttle.
"C'mon guys, this boat is not moving," a drummer called out to her teammates, who responded by paddling harder and faster, trying not to get much water into the boat, which would slow them down.
Several team members had dragon tattoos on their upper arms; some had them on their backs, peeking from behind life preservers. Since this was the beginning of their practice cycle, their motions were not yet fluid. Their paddles had Hong Kong spelled out in Chinese and English on opposite sides of the blades. Over the sounds of the team members' shouting and their paddles slicing the water, Mr. Young explained, "It's a lot harder than it looks." To this summer camp canoeist it never looked anything but difficult. 
A few New York teams own their own boats and practice in the nearby World's Fair Marina, sometimes five times a week during the season. In the parking lot on a recent evening the members of another team, Women in Canoe, in trim uniforms, did stretches and a kind of group meditation before boarding their boat. As they set off, their boat glided on the water, skimming the surface. Picking up speed, they created a wake of white water in front and behind.
Among the members of Women in Canoe are a banker, a detective, a lawyer, a doctor and a newscaster. "It's like a sisterhood," Elaine Roman, the team captain, explained. "We watch out for each other on and off the boat." 
Last weekend in Philadelphia's dragon boat race, they participated as the United States National Women's Crew, and this weekend they are to compete on Meadow Lake.
To passengers in the low-flying airplanes approaching La Guardia Airport the boats might resemble centipedes, but those creatures lack elegance. The dragon boats move with an unusual mixture of power and grace. My father, a Navy veteran who served on P.T. boats in World War II, came to watch the practice and was "impressed by the amazing speed" of the 18 synchronized paddlers. 
New Yorkers who want to begin their celebration today might head to May May Chinese Gourmet Food Center, at 35 Pell Street in Chinatown, where the Hong-Kong born owner, John Hung, prepares 15 varieties of jong, the traditional rice dumplings wrapped in bamboo leaves and tied beautifully with colored string. Sticky rice surrounds a savory filling, which varies according to the Chinese province. The most popular variety is from Hong Kong, with peanuts, green beans, egg yolk and pork. Several types of May May's jong will also be available at the festival.
Mr. Hung learned the intricate process of making jong from his parents, who once owned a shop in Hong Kong. He has taught a worker to prepare the delicacies. I watched his hands masterly combining ingredients, forming and folding the leaf packet and tying it. It takes less time to win a dragon-boat race.

Getting There

BY CAR: Take the Long Island Expressway to the Van Wyck Expressway south; then stay on the service road to Flushing Meadows Park; follow signs to Meadow Lake.

BY SUBWAY: Take the No. 7 train to Main Street, Flushing; then take the free shuttle bus to the park (leaving from outside St. George's Church on 39th Avenue and Main Street), or get off the No. 7 train at Shea Stadium and walk or take the trolley to Meadow Lake.

HEADLINE: Italy Reports Slowdown In Economy As Sales Fall 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
Evidence mounted today that Europe is slowing down, as Italy reported that its economy contracted in the second quarter from the first quarter. The figures signaled that a decline in manufacturing and farming began to infect other areas, producing the first quarter-to-quarter fall in output in three years.
 Over all, gross domestic product in Italy, the third-largest economy in the euro region after Germany and France, declined 0.1 percent from the first quarter, the government statistical office reported, as falling demand from the rest of Europe and the United States took its toll. Year to year, output grew 2 percent. 
 Italy is struggling in particular with weakening sales to two major trade partners, Germany and the United States. The seriousness of the slowdown in Germany became evident on Tuesday when it reported a decline in industrial output in June. That followed a report of a fall in industrial orders, suggesting that economic activity is softening.
"The impact of the external slowdown probably became more immediate during the second quarter," said Carmen Nuzzo, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, of Italy's contraction. She said the figures were "definitely not very surprising," given a drop in first-quarter manufacturing in Italy, and the fact that the second quarter had fewer calendar days, a factor not compensated for in today's figures. 
The difficulties in Italy and Germany are increasing the pressure on the European Central Bank to cut interest rates and stoke growth. The bank has been loath to do that for fear of unleashing inflation. But in its monthly report today, the bank gave what some analysts saw as a hint that its thinking was shifting. The bank noted that "risks relating to the outlook for growth in the second half of the year remain sizable" and said it would "closely monitor developments" that might lead it to change its mind about the right level of interest rates.
Italian stocks fell for a second consecutive day. The benchmark Mib30 index fell 1 percent, to 36,491.
Italian companies rely heavily on exports. The last downturn in the economy came after the 1998 meltdown in emerging markets in Eastern Europe and elsewhere. Fiat Auto, the car division of Italy's biggest corporation, has said it will furlough roughly one-third of its 50,000 workers in Italy for a week in September because of slowing demand. Pirelli, the cable and tire maker, announced an unexpected fall in profits in the second quarter and said the third quarter would be difficult as well. 
Some economists now look to domestic consumption to buoy Italy's economy. Vincenzo Guzzo of Morgan Stanley said "in this kind of environment, it's hard to think of a pickup in investment spending," but that spending on services seemed to be holding up. 
Today's gloomy figures cast doubt on a pledge of tax cuts by the fledgling government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, which was based on a forecast of 2.4 percent growth this year. Economists now expect 2 percent at most. While small-scale tax relief may be possible, Mr. Guzzo said, major cuts will probably have to wait until late 2002.

HEADLINE: Even Paradise Needs Basic Maintenance 

BYLINE:  By Fred Moody; Fred Moody is the author, most recently, of "The Visionary Position."

DATELINE: SEATTLE 

 BODY:
Seattle, long a self-styled paradise, is in serious trouble. The clearest manifestation is its traffic jams. Perennially at or near the top of various "most livable cities" lists throughout the 1980's and 1990's, Seattle placed second this spring on the national list of cities with the worst traffic, after chronic offender Los Angeles. The city's 20-year-long Silicon Rush has sent the population skyrocketing, with huge suburbs sprawling east from Lake Washington, spawned largely by Microsoft and its tech-industry descendants.
 The Highway 520 bridge connecting Seattle with the massive suburban population across the lake is 38 years old, too small for current traffic, and crumbling. Its sister bridge to the south, a floating bridge on pontoons, had to sink some years ago before anyone cared enough to repair it. The city has been so intent on building cyberspace that it has failed to notice the collapse of its physical space. 
 This summer, the State Legislature, facing traffic so bad that entire political campaigns are now run on "the transportation mess," was forced to show it recognized the problem. (Boeing, in moving its headquarters to Chicago this year, cited the horrendous traffic as one of its discontents.) But every proposed solution runs into well-organized opposition: Conservatives oppose spending on mass transit, liberals oppose bigger freeways. And since the State Legislature is virtually evenly divided -- the House has 49 Democrats and 49 Republicans, and Democrats hold a one-seat majority in the Senate -- nothing much ever gets accomplished.
Gridlock on the highways has become a metaphor for political gridlock, which has multifarious causes. Most of Washington is rural, and the rural residents care little for the problems in the Seattle area. Seattleites, for their part, are oblivious to the needs and problems in rural Washington, where people remain relatively poor, the technology boom having passed them by.
But the essential problem is that no one here is willing to pay for anything. During the biggest economic boom the Northwest has ever experienced, antitax sentiment has become positively New Hampshireesque. In 1999, voters approved Initiative 695, which repealed the longstanding motor vehicle excise tax that had provided nearly all of the state's transportation funding. Since then transportation repair and construction have ground to a halt.
The consequence of that spasm of antitax madness is that politicians in both parties now are terrified of taking responsibility for raising taxes to do anything. 
Washington's governor, Gary Locke, and some lawmakers were willing to push for a tax package that would have raised $8.5 billion over 10 years for road and bridge improvements. Governor Locke even called the Legislature into special session three times this year but got nowhere -- a state record for political futility. The public got wind of the tax increases involved -- a 9-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax and a few other fees -- and the package was killed.
It was really no surprise that state leaders declined to levy taxes that they know are necessary. But anti-tax sentiment is only part of the reason for Seattle's fall from grace. Far worse has been a form of environmentalism here that is little more than denial. Attempts to address population growth have been resisted by antigrowth forces moved more by a refusal to acknowledge growth than by a genuine sense of environmental stewardship.
Underlying this denial is a profound sense of entitlement. We've lived with the idea of free things -- good water, natural splendor, abundant exploitable resources like fish and timber. Even the 1990's technology revolution that pumped billions into the local economy was in large part a something-for-nothing phenomenon. Actually paying for public goods -- like a functioning highway system -- now seems like a quaint idea.
In some ways, the collapse of the transportation effort last month is instructive. Ron Sims, the King County executive, says that this state "operates on government by catastrophe." But that's not entirely correct. For a long time, it was government by good fortune. What set this region apart for liveability was not that the politicians and citizens were enlightened (though some were); it was that Seattle and its suburbs were so much younger than the rest of the country.
In time, the Northwest's adolescence was bound to end, and the crumbling roads are proof positive that it has.

HEADLINE: Unrest Intensifies in Struggle to Control Zimbabwe Farms 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: CHINHOYI, Zimbabwe, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
With the government vowing to step up its seizures of white-owned farms and Western countries weighing punitive steps, tension has flared across Zimbabwe in recent days, and this city north of the capital has been one of the hottest flash points.
 Clashes on Monday night between white farmers and poor blacks who had occupied a farm touched off the latest surge in tensions, and landed 22 white men, all but one of them farmers, in jail here, charged with causing public violence. 
 Today, as more than 100 government loyalists chanted angrily outside the courthouse where the men who had been arrested were to appear, dozens of white families were fleeing their homesteads after confrontations with black squatters, the Commercial Farmers Union said.
At least four houses were looted and at least two white farmers were shot at, said David Rockingham-Gill, regional executive of the farmers union. 
"Nothing has been worse than today, not in this province," Mr. Rockingham-Gill said.
George Charamba, a spokesman for President Robert Mugabe, said the increase in confrontations in recent days was driven by the white farmers in a ploy to win sympathy in the United States and among the Commonwealth nations. 
Foreign ministers from several Commonwealth countries will meet next week in Nigeria to try to make some progress on Zimbabwe before a meeting of heads of government scheduled for October in Australia. 
"What they want to do is convince those ministers that there is lawlessness, that there is violence, and what's more that they are victims of that violence," Mr. Charamba said in an interview tonight. "Unfortunately that trick is not working because it's quite clear, in all the cases, that the commercial farmers did initiate the confrontations. These guys have been coexisting for months and it's just now that you have this."
But opponents of the president said another wave of government-sanctioned intimidation is under way in Zimbabwe as the government finds itself under mounting international pressure and the economy founders ahead of next year's presidential election.
"The weaker they feel, the more aggressive they become," said David Coltart, a member of Parliament from the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, "and I think this escalation in violence is a result of them feeling increasingly isolated internationally. I think they're realizing that the net is closing in terms of the Commonwealth, in terms of South Africa losing patience. And they've decided that the only way out of this jam is to provoke a hostile response from white farmers."
The confrontations come as the government has pledged to step up its program to redistribute white-owned land to poor blacks. After saying for months that the state planned to acquire about 12 million acres of white-owned land, Agriculture Minister Joseph Made announced last week that the government now plans to take 20 million acres, and warned commercial farmers to avoid antagonizing the black squatters occupying white farms.
The first clash erupted here on Monday, when a group of white farmers came to the aid of a colleague who they believed was being attacked by a black squatter, the farmers union said. In the melee, both blacks and whites apparently were hurt, and the sight of the injured blacks in the state-owned media prompted a spate of revenge attacks this week by supporters of the governing party on whites around Chinhoyi.
Today, as they had done the day before, when they chased away local and foreign journalists, young party loyalists barred all reporters but those working for the state media from the proceedings in the courthouse.
A journalist from The Daily News, Zimbabwe's only privately owned daily newspaper, fled in a car when several young party activists walked toward him. A foreign journalist, who was surrounded and menaced by the same men, had his notes torn up and was warned by a policeman watching the encounter that he was "going to be assaulted."
While most of the people attacked and killed in Zimbabwe's political violence over the last 18 months have been black, the targeting of whites has stirred particular interest in the West, and in the coming months Zimbabwe could find itself even more isolated.
In the United States, the House is expected to take up legislation, recently passed by the Senate, that could freeze overseas assets and restrict the travel of Mr. Mugabe and some of his closest aides while setting strict conditions for resuming the international assistance Zimbabwe desperately needs.
Zimbabwe has criticized the bill as an attack on its sovereignty, and Mr. Charamba, the presidential spokesman, said the world underestimates the determination and fortitude of this former British colony.
"The psychology here is a psychology of struggle," Mr. Charamba said, "a psychology that we may have to go through some of the same circumstances we endured during our liberation struggle."

HEADLINE: Initial Claims For Joblessness Rose Last Week 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
After a three-week decline, new claims for unemployment insurance rose last week.
 The number of workers filing new applications for jobless benefits increased by a seasonally adjusted 33,000, to 385,000, for the workweek ended Aug. 4, the Labor Department reported today. 
That pushed claims to their highest level since mid-July. 
 Claims had fallen sharply in the prior three weeks, offering hope that the rash of layoffs seen in recent months might be moderating.
This time of year, the claims figures usually bounce around a lot as automobile plants temporarily shut down to retool for new models and then call workers back, economists say. That volatility can make seasonal adjustments difficult, analysts say.
Given that, economists tend to focus on another number as a barometer of the labor market's health, the more stable four-week moving average of jobless claims. The moving average, which smooths out week-to-week fluctuations, fell last week to 380,000, the lowest level since the end of March, a sign that layoffs could be easing. The four-week moving average has been down three weeks in a row.
In an effort to avert the first recession in the United States in 11 years, the Federal Reserve has cut short-term interest rates six times this year, totaling 2.75 percentage points. Many analysts say the Fed will cut rates again at its next meeting Aug. 21. 
The yearlong economic slowdown has led companies to scale back production and capital investment and lay off workers. In July, the unemployment rate held steady at 4.5 percent as businesses cut fewer workers than in June.
For the workweek ended July 28, 13 states and territories reported an increase in jobless claims, while 39 reported a decrease. The state data lag the national figures by a week and are not seasonally adjusted.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Retailers' Sales Rise 2.4% As Shoppers Grow Cautious
In malls and Main Streets across the country, shoppers appear to be closely watching how and where they spend their money, with retail sales rising just 2.4 percent over all in July.
 Discount retailers posted the strongest gains, with Wal-Mart and Kmart doing better than expected, but other merchants had disappointing sales. Gap, for example, said that sales in stores open at least a year fell 12 percent, steeper than expected. Page C3. 

Toyota Vows to Improve Diversity
Threatened with a boycott backed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Toyota said that it would commit nearly $8 billion over the next decade to diversify its work force and reach out to more minority suppliers and customers. The United States affiliate of Toyota said that it would spend millions more with black and Hispanic advertising agencies, work to expand the number of minority dealerships, create new career training programs for minorities and invest some of its capital with minority-owned asset management companies. C3.

U.S. and Mexico Agree on Workers
The United States and Mexico agreed in principle to an expanded temporary worker program that would include a limited plan to allow some of the three million Mexicans living in the United States unlawfully to earn permanent legal residency over time. A4.

Money Manager Faces New Charges
Alan B. Bond, a Wall Street money manger who is scheduled to stand trial in November on charges he took illegal kickbacks from brokerage firms, was arrested on separate fraud charges, federal prosecutors said. C4.

Flooz.com Considers Closing Down
Flooz.com, an Internet company that offered online currency that could be used at dozens of Web sites, has shut its Web site and is considering closing its operations, executives close to the company said. C5.

Stocks End Mostly Unchanged
Stocks ended an uneven session nearly unchanged. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.04 points, to 1,963.32. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.10 of a point, to 1,183.43, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.06 points, to 10,298.56. C5.

AT&T to Sell Some Cablevision Stock
Cablevision Systems agreed to permit AT&T to sell as much as $1 billion of its stake. AT&T owns 30 percent, or 48.9 million shares, of Cablevision, the New York City area's largest cable provider. The deal clears the way for AT&T to sell 18.6 million shares, or an 11 percent stake. It plans to use the proceeds to reduce its debt. Cablevision also plans to sell as much as $1 billion in stock to the public. Separately, the company posted a second-quarter profit because of a big gain, but sales slipped. Shares of Cablevision fell $2, to $51.85. C2.

Sanctions Rejected in Cendant Case
A federal appeals court has overturned sanctions imposed against a New York lawyer accused of breaching a confidentiality order in class-action cases against Cendant. C3.

Economy Contracts in Italy
Evidence mounted that Europe is slowing down, as Italy reported that its economy contracted in the second quarter from the first quarter. World Business, Section W.

United Cuts Fares on Some Flights
United Airlines, trying to win back passengers from big rivals and to ward off competition from discounters, said that it was reducing fares on some flights between Chicago and other large American cities. C10.

HEADLINE: Ovitz, Hollywood Giant of a Few Years Ago, Comes on Hard Times 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
Three years ago Michael S. Ovitz, one of Hollywood's titans in the 1980's and early 90's, formed a management company to produce films and television programs as well as represent stars, directors, writers and sports figures. The venture was intended to place Mr. Ovitz firmly back in the Hollywood firmament after several years of setbacks.
 Today, Mr. Ovitz is facing serious economic strains that threaten the future of his project and represent personal and financial embarrassment to a power broker who was once feared in Hollywood and could seemingly do no wrong. 
 Mr. Ovitz -- who committed as much as $100 million of his own money to the company, the Artists Management Group -- may have lost tens of millions of dollars. 
The long-rumored financial problems became public late Wednesday when 18 employees of the television arm of the venture, the Artists Television Group, were laid off.
The dismissals, of half the group's employees, touched off speculation among network executives that the unit -- which had been designed in some ways as the financial heart of the overall operation -- was withering after Mr. Ovitz had failed to find investors for it. He had been seeking at least $150 million to finance just the television division.
What went wrong for Mr. Ovitz? According to rivals in talent management and to entertainment industry executives, Mr. Ovitz miscalculated the high rate of failure in the television business -- especially in today's shifting market, and spent huge amounts of money on deals and expenses without creating a sturdier foundation at the company.
Mr. Ovitz has lost his powerful perch, at least for the moment, and over the years he has made numerous enemies who are almost eager to see him fail. No power broker in Hollywood matches Mr. Ovitz for the number of powerful people -- whether it is Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company; David Geffen, the entertainment industry billionaire; Ron Meyer, the president and chief operating officer of Universal Studios, or the partners at Creative Artists Agency -- who actively dislike him.
His financial straits are indeed embarrassing for Mr. Ovitz, a founder of the Creative Artists Agency, less than a decade ago Hollywood's most powerful talent agency.
In recent years, he has suffered highly publicized blows -- including his dismissal after one year from the presidency of Walt Disney, even with a $100 million severance package. There have also been failed efforts to bring a professional football team back to Los Angeles and to become a Broadway powerhouse by gaining control of the theatrical production company Livent, but then asserting that the company was riddled with accounting fraud. The former executives of Livent denied the accusations.
By all accounts, Mr. Ovitz had been putting his own money into the television company as well as his management company as he sought -- and was unable to find -- investors from Hollywood studios and networks, or companies like AT&T.
At the same time, the company, which had more than 200 people on its payroll in a 40,000-square-foot office in Beverly Hills, is clearly facing financial difficulties because of its high overhead. Entertainment industry executives estimated that the overhead might run as much as $50 million to $60 million a year.
Mr. Ovitz said late today that making the staff cuts "was a very hard decision for me."
"A lot of time and emotion was involved," he said. "We're in a pretty rotten television economy." He said he was unsure about the future of his television business, adding: "That's what we're working on now. It's always been a high-risk venture. We're trying to assess what to do now. But we're still operating."
Mr. Ovitz insisted that the serious problems in his company's television side would have no effect on his other lines of work -- talent and sports management, and making movies. "All these businesses are set up separately, operate separately," he said. "From a pure business point of view, our people are doing great. We've got over 70 projects in development in the film area. On the human side, it's difficult."
And he said that the cuts were necessary for one reason:"We just wanted to cut the overheard."
In scaling back the television operations, the company kept the chief operating officer, Eric Tannenbaum, and several top associates. But executives in business, finance and production were laid off. Two top network executives, who insisted on anonymity, maintained that unless Mr. Ovitz soon found a financial partner, the company's television business would be in tatters.
At one point, the company spent as much as $60 million on television deals with top writer-producers like Darren Star, Barry Levinson and Tom Fontana, and with Adam Chase, a former co-executive producer of the NBC show "Friends." Now, agents said, the company is seeking to come to terms with some of the writers by ending their deals and paying them, perhaps at 50 cents on the dollar.
Mr. Ovitz gambled on finding a big television hit quickly that would, essentially, pay the bills. It did not happen. Only two of his new shows were picked up by the networks this fall -- CBS ordered a comedy, "The Ellen Show," starring Ellen DeGeneres, and the WB Network has a so-called reality program, "Lost in the USA."
Last year, in its first year of operations, the television unit had an impressive debut. It produced four prime-time series -- ABC's "Madigan Men," NBC's "Cursed," Fox's "The Street" and the WB Network's "Grosse Pointe." But none of the shows was picked up for a second season. This left the Artists Television Group with substantial deficits or losses.
A top television agent who has had many dealings with the Artists Television Group said today: "They're in a state of limbo. They're not making any new deals with people. And I think buyers are skeptical of their future."
Of the impact on the overall management company, the agent said: "When a portion of the company goes out of business, it spreads enormous doubt through the rest of the company. It puts everything up in the air."
Mr. Ovitz began the management company with Rick Yorn and his sister-in-law, Julie Silverman Yorn, who brought in star clients like Leonardo DiCaprio and Cameron Diaz. But even with these stars and others, the commissions on their deals were paid for several years to the former company at which the Yorns had worked.
Mr. Yorn said today that the company was disappointed in the downturn in its television business but that the layoffs would have no effect on the management of actors and writers and directors. "If anything, we're in amazing shape there," he said, adding that the company hoped that a business partner would bolster the television business.
"If not, if it doesn't happen, it'll be weaned downward," Mr. Yorn said, adding, "It's ultimately good for the company." 
It was Mr. Ovitz who helped bring in stars like Robin Williams and directors like Martin Scorsese. Separate sports, music and comedy representation units were also set up. The company represents the tennis star Pete Sampras and the rock group Buckcherry. 
But the television group was, at least at the outset, intended to serve as what the head of one talent agency called "the hard asset base of the firm upon which they were looking to raise money."
He added: "Without that, it becomes a far less attractive situation. It has a huge impact."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael S. Ovitz has again sought to produce films and television programs and to again represent top talent. His TV venture is now at risk, but Mr. Ovitz considers the other businesses on solid footing. (Reuters)

He said that private research had produced more than 60 genetically diverse stem cell lines that could reproduce themselves indefinitely and that he had decided to allow federal money to be used for research on the existing lines. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
San Francisco Office Dismisses 15 Employees

BYLINE:  By Patricia Winters Lauro 

 BODY:
The San Francisco office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising said yesterday that it had laid off about 15 employees, or about 5 percent of its staff of 250.
 The San Francisco office "has been having a very good year, but the economy is soft," said Susan Irwin, a spokeswoman for McCann-Erickson, confirming reports of the layoffs in the online editions of Advertising Age and Adweek. 
She said the dismissals affect all levels at the San Francisco office, and were caused by budget cutbacks by clients. 
 In April, the San Francisco office laid off four or five employees. In May, McCann-Erickson in New York laid off 35 to 40 employees, or about 3 percent of its staff of 1,300. McCann-Erickson is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

HEADLINE: Seeking to Regain Fliers, United Cuts Chicago Fares 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
United Airlines, trying to win back passengers from big rivals and to ward off competition from discounters, said today that it was reducing fares on some flights between Chicago and other large American cities.
 United, the operating unit of the UAL Corporation, also removed a Saturday-night stay requirement. 
 The lower fares, from its O'Hare International Airport hub to cities including New York and Los Angeles, will be available for travel starting on Sept. 5 and will be nonrefundable. As examples, some seats on some flights will cost $296 round trip from O'Hare to LaGuardia Airport in New York, $328 round trip to Denver and $376 round trip to Los Angeles,
United, operating like its rivals American Airlines and Delta Air Lines in a soft economy, is trying to regain passenger good will lost in delays and cancellations. 
It particularly wants to win back business travelers lost to American, an AMR unit, which also uses O'Hare as a hub.
And United is seeking to thwart discounters like American Trans Air, which now operates from Midway, Chicago's other major airport. Southwest Airlines, the nation's leading discount carrier, also flies into and out of Midway. 
The airline industry had losses in the first and second quarters of 2001, mainly because of sharply reduced business travel linked to the economic slowdown. The slowdown has hurt United more than some rivals because of service problems it had last year, some labor-related, that put off customers.
American Airlines and Northwest Airlines said today that they were studying the announcement, deciding whether to match United's move.
In trading, shares of UAL fell 34 cents today, to $33.96.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Key Gauges Make Little or No Headway in Uneven Session

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The stock market ended an uneven session nearly unchanged yesterday, as persistent fears about sluggish growth and a mixed batch of retail sales dampened investors' appetite for stocks.
 Abercrombie & Fitch reported a bigger-than-expected drop in July sales and warned that its second-half earnings would disappoint. Banks and brokerage firms limped lower on fears the weak stock market would hurt earnings, and technology stocks closed within a whisker of a four-month low. 
 "The weak economic data and the lousy earnings season we went through have pushed hopes for recovery out further," said Erik Gustafson, a portfolio manager who helps oversee $4 billion for Stein Roe & Farnham Inc. The action yesterday shows a market still churning downward, he added. 
The economic outlook was no less grim, with jobless claims rising to 385,000 in the week ended Aug. 4 from a revised 352,000 for the prior week. The downbeat beige book summary of regional economic conditions on Wednesday already had painted a picture of lagging growth.
"There are all these incremental pieces of news showing that the economy is still slowing -- there's nowhere to run to and no place to hide," said Donna Van Vlack, director of trading at Brandywine Asset Management.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.04 points, to 1,963.32, its fifth consecutive losing session. Yesterday it ended just 4 points shy of a four-month closing low.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.10 of a point, to 1,183.43, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.06 points, to 10,298.56.
Worries that the weak economy and struggling stock market will bite into profits at Wall Street's biggest firms buffeted brokerage stocks, sending a crucial index of financial shares to its lowest level in nearly a month. The American Stock Exchange broker-dealer index fell 2.5 percent, its fifth consecutive day in negative territory and its lowest close since July 11.
"Financial stocks are always very correlated with the markets, and the markets are bad," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "And there is a lot of macro-economic pessimism out there about when there could be a recovery."
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was off $2.16, or 3.7 percent, at $56.09.
Nortel Networks slipped 6 cents, to $7.56. Nortel, a telecommunications equipment supplier, sold $1.5 billion of seven-year convertible senior notes to help stabilize its balance sheet amid a steep slide in demand for its products. A convertible bond is a hybrid security that can be converted into company stock, potentially diluting the stock's value. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after the government's $5 billion bond sale drew below-average demand, fueling speculation that bonds might not rally much more as the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates.
Bonds have "already acknowledged a ton of slowing in the economy" and "there's a lot of stimulus in the pipeline" after six Fed rate reductions, said Todd Abraham, who helps invest $1.5 billion in bonds at Federated Investors Inc. in Pittsburgh. He is keeping most of his holdings in non-Treasury debt for the extra yield it provides, he said.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 12/32, to a price of 99 25/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.03 percent from 5.07 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 9/32, to 97 23/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.52 percent from 5.51 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Thomson 2nd-Quarter Net Rises 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug 9 

 BODY:
The Thomson Corporation, the financial, legal and scientific publisher, said today that its second-quarter income increased because of acquisitions but warned that a slowing economy could hurt its bottom line in the second half. 
 Thomson, which provides specialized information through online channels, CD-ROM's, software and printed materials, said its trademark business had slowed and sluggish financial markets could turn things a little sour in the rest of the year. 
 "Our trademark businesses are dependent on trademark filings, and of course as the economy has slowed, companies in the United States and Canada and Europe have reduced the amount they have invested in new product development, reducing the number of trademarks they've needed," Brian Hall, the president of Thomson's legal and regulatory division, said in a conference call. 
For the quarter ended June 30, Thomson's earnings from continuing operations rose to $110 million, or 18 cents a share, up from $74 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding a one-time gain from the sale of Jane's Information Group, earnings were $84 million, or 13 cents a share.
Total sales rose nearly 7 percent, to $1.6 billion.
Officials said that despite the slowdown, they expected revenue to grow 15 percent this year and earnings before income taxes, depreciation and amortization to increase 17 percent. 
The forecasts excluded the effect of its Harcourt division. In July, the English-Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier bought the publisher Harcourt General and sold Harcourt's professional and higher education publications to Thomson for $2.06 billion.

HEADLINE: Italy's Leader Defends Police Actions at Genoa Summit Talks 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, today defended police actions at the Group of Eight summit conference in Genoa last month, declaring the meeting "a political and diplomatic success" even as officials elsewhere in Europe continued to question the heavy use of force against demonstrators there.
 At a news conference on his way out of town for a summer vacation, Mr. Berlusconi looked at several nodding aides rather than at reporters as he said, "Instead of putting the police on trial it would be better to put on trial the violent organizations that have already announced that they will be involved with the next summits." 
 Not that it was a tough crowd. None of the half-dozen questions the prime minister took from reporters, in a hall where some journalists were on his payroll as employees of the various news outlets he owns, dealt directly with either the allegations of police brutality or the resulting criminal and parliamentary investigations. 
The July 20-22 summit meeting became an international embarrassment for Mr. Berlusconi's center-right government after the police shot one demonstrator dead and were accused of beating scores of peaceful protesters. Earlier this week, President Thomas Klestil of Austria formally petitioned Italy to release members of a group that demonstrates through street theater. 
Sixteen Austrians and four Americans remain in Italian jails, including Susanna Thomas, a Bryn Mawr College student and practicing Quaker from New Jersey, who had been working on her senior thesis on nonviolent social protest.
"It all makes Italy look bad, like, 'Oh, well, this is how fascists act,' and of course the intelligentsia here is appalled," said a senior executive with an Italian company. 
But the opposition does not have the votes to bring down the government. Polls show that a majority of Italians generally agree with Mr. Berlusconi about the way the police handled the demonstrators. And the left remains both fragmented and wary trying to capitalize politically on problems at a summit meeting it had helped plan before losing the elections this year.
"There is no doubt the police reaction was excessive," said Sergio Romano, a conservative former minister who writes a column for Corriera della Sera. "But the damage done was excessive, too. We saw pictures of people attacking gas stations to get bottles for their Molotov cocktails, so people are not as impressed as they perhaps should be."
And after a bomb went off in a Venice courthouse around 3 this morning, causing no injuries, some local political commentators saw the explosion as politically beneficial to Mr. Berlusconi, a confirmation of his view that there is leftist violence that must be answered. (So beneficial, in fact, that one leftist group immediately issued a statement accusing government officials of having planted the bomb themselves to justify the police conduct in Genoa.)
Mr. Berlusconi has stayed mostly in the background since the summit meeting, but called the news conference today to grade himself on his first 100 days in office. And, like the American president he so admires, he gave himself high marks.
"We have finished our program for the first 100 days in advance," he said.
When a reporter pointed out that he had failed to keep his promise to come up with a conflict-of-interest bill that would address the fact that his vast holdings necessarily do business with the government he runs, he said he had been too busy but would get to it after the summer break.
"I will present it when I return, but I'm also taking 10 days off, if that's all right with you," he said. "I have a family -- at least I hope I still do -- and so I'm going to be with them."
Meanwhile, government officials said they hoped the storm abroad over the violence in Genoa would pass.
"I hope that we will be able to overcome this moment," Communication Minister Maurizio Gasparri said in an interview this evening. 
Asked about reports of abuse, he said they had been exaggerated.
"There were a few little problems, nothing huge," he said. "For example, the shooting of the young man has been declared to be in self-defense."
Television crews videotaped the young man heaving a fire extinguisher at a police jeep as he was shot and then run over.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Mexico Talks Produce Agreement on Immigration Policy 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
The United States and Mexico agreed in principle today to an expanded temporary worker program that would allow some of the estimated three million Mexicans living here unlawfully to earn permanent legal residency, officials from both governments said.
 After meeting for nearly two hours, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Attorney General John Ashcroft joined their Mexican counterparts, Jorge G. Castaneda and Santiago Creel, at a news conference to announce what Mr. Powell called a "shared commitment" to employ a "humane, family-friendly" migration policy. 
 While much work lies ahead on specific details, Mr. Powell made it clear that some Mexicans living in this country illegally -- those who have jobs, pay taxes and rear children who are American-born United States citizens -- would be included in an expanded temporary worker program. 
"The program will rest on a carefully worked-out partnership between the sending and receiving countries, one that recognizes also the contributions that undocumented Mexicans are making in the United States and that brings together willing workers and willing employers," Mr. Powell said.
The American and Mexican cabinet officers met here to begin laying the groundwork for a meeting in early September between President Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico.
Aides on both sides, who had recently held out hopes that the presidents could announce a detailed framework agreement in September, sought today to play down expectations of any quick accord.
Tacitly acknowledging the policy complexities as well as the political hurdles to clear, Mr. Powell said that putting together a well-designed temporary worker program that enjoyed public support could not be rushed.
"We're in no hurry," Mr. Powell told reporters. "We have to do this right. We have to do this in a careful way, a way that will be seen as fair and equitable by both nations, by the people of both nations."
State Department spokesman Richard Boucher was more categorical, telling reporters later that, "I wouldn't expect that it'll all be finished by the time the presidents get together."
Mexican officials, whom some Americans had privately accused of pushing the legalization plan too aggressively in recent months, also sounded a cautionary note today.
"We are making important progress," said Mr. Castaneda, adding that the overall goal is "to achieve a good agreement in whatever time frame is necessary, and that takes into account the needs of the economy in the United States and the rights that Mexicans need."
But Mr. Creel appeared to voice more of the private satisfaction Mexican officials said they felt after today's talks. "We have taken a very important step on an issue that is essential for Mexico, finding a solution for our countrymen who work and live in the United States," he said.
There is now a small-scale, cumbersome plan that allows "guest workers," mostly agriculture laborers, to get temporary visas. Under proposals discussed today, an expanded pool of new migrants employed in service jobs like hotels and restaurants could apply for temporary work permits with the possibility of earning permanent residency over time.
And at least some of the illegal Mexicans already in the United States could earn permanent lawful status if they could certify that they had been living and working in the country for a specified time, and had been paying taxes.
"There is broad agreement in principle about how and what kind of program we want to design," Mr. Boucher said. "We got into the discussion of the various factors and elements that need to be worked in and balanced as we go into that program. The senior experts and officials that are going to try to work out the details of the program have a lot more structure and guidance."
