HEADLINE: Home Prices Are Up, but Not as Much 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
SHOWING a degree of resilience in the face of the national economic slowdown, the residential real estate market in the New York metropolitan region clung to its penchant for price increases in the first half of the year, even as buyers became more choosy (or wary) and sellers lost a bit of their swagger.
 Though more moderate than during the frenzy of recent years, price increases were recorded in most precincts of the city's suburban ring and in the boroughs outside of Manhattan. At the same time, sales volume remained strong in some areas while slipping in others -- with brokers, exuding their seemingly inherent optimism, citing low inventory as the culprit. 
 If there were clear signs of a leveling off, they were most apparent in the upscale environs of Manhattan -- a market particularly affected by Wall Street worries and the winnowing of the high-technology sector.
Some real estate observers said they were seeing a more rational market, as well as a seeming paradox: people increasingly interested in the security of buying a home instead of stocks while also being deliberate in their search for the right property rather than charging into bidding wars for fear of being priced out of the market. 
"It's the safe port in the economic storm," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. Dr. Hughes pointed out that interest rates remain low, near 7 percent; that an unprecedented concentration of the population is in the age range of peak housing consumption, and that nationwide sales of existing homes are on track to surpass 2000 as the second-best year ever.
At the same time, the senior regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Rae Rosen, saw cause for some concern, particularly because of layoffs in manufacturing and an increase in the number of people falling behind in their mortgage payments. "We didn't get the kind of decline in foreclosures that you would expect during a strong expansion," Ms. Rosen said. "And in recent months there have been sharp declines in manufacturing jobs. So there could be further weakness in the residential market."
"Prices seem to be holding in the metropolitan area," she said. "But it takes longer to sell, and volume has slipped" -- a pattern evident, with some exceptions, from county to county in the region.
For example, the multiple listing service covering Westchester and Putnam Counties reported that the median, or midpoint, price for single-family houses in the second quarter was $465,000, up 12.8 percent from $412,000 in the same period in 2000. But the number of single-family houses sold in the second quarter was 1,296, down 10 percent from the 1,447 sold in the same period last year -- just before the stock market tumble. More encouragingly, the listing service reported that the 1,296 single-family houses sold from April through June represented a 29 percent increase over the 1,004 transactions in the first quarter of 2001.
In Morris County, N.J., the median price just in June was $290,000, up 3.6 percent from $280,000 in June 2000. But the number of sales in June was 635, down 14 percent from 739 in June 2000. For Sussex County, N.J., the median price in June was $175,000, up 9.4 percent from $159,950 in June 2000. But sales for the month stood at 282, a 7.8 percent drop from the 306 in June 2000.
There is no central source for statistics in Fairfield County, Conn. But according to data compiled from three large brokerage houses, the median price for Fairfield (not including Greenwich and Darien) was $360,000 from May to July, a 7.4 percent increase over the $335,000 median in the same period in 2000. And while, by way of illustration, 141 sales have gone into contract in Stamford since May 1, there were 237 contracts in the same period last year.
The pattern was more robust in three of the four boroughs outside of Manhattan (the Bronx Board of Realtors does not compile sufficient data). In some instances, local realty boards were asked to provide statistics on contracts rather than closed deals because, while they are less firm, contracts provide a more current snapshot of the market.
According to the Staten Island Board of Realtors, for example, 1,941 deals went into contract in the first six months of this year, compared with 1,783 in the same period in 2000 -- an 8.8 percent increase. The average price for those contracts also rose, by 10.9 percent, to $243,792 this year from $219,852 in 2000.
And in Queens, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors, which covers the borough, there were 388 transactions in contract in June, an 18.3 percent increase over the 328 contracts in June 2000. At the same time, the median contract price for Queens in June was $245,000, up 22 percent from $200,500 in June 2000. A similar pattern was evident in Brooklyn.
Only in Manhattan -- a market that in recent years has been characterized by dizzying price leaps and seemingly insatiable demand -- have both prices and sales volume shown signs of leveling off. 
According to the Douglas Elliman Report, the most comprehensive survey of the Manhattan market, the average price for closed sales in the second quarter was $894,617, a 2 percent increase from the first quarter's average of $876,612. The survey covers sales from Battery Park to West 116th Street and East 96th Street.
"Over the past two years, we've seen quarter-to-quarter changes as high as 29 percent, so this 2 percent increase seems indicative of the early stages of price stabilization," said Jonathan Miller, president of the Miller Samuel appraisal company, which prepares the Elliman report. Tracking sales volume, the Elliman report recorded 2,039 closings in the first quarter and 1,829 in the second quarter, a 10 percent decline.
Examining median prices, which factor out the extreme ends of the price range, the Manhattan median in the second quarter was $540,000, an 8 percent increase over $500,000 in the first quarter. "What's interesting is that the median is usually viewed as a more conservative indicator," Mr. Miller said, "but in this case the 8 percent increase is skewed upward due to the decline in transactions that occurred in the smaller apartment categories." In the first quarter of 2001 there were 704 one-bedroom sales, while in the second quarter there were 447, a 37 percent decline. "That moves the midpoint upward," he said, "which makes it look like a greater change than the average price does." 
To gauge the most current indicators, Mr. Miller also examined contracts. In the first quarter, there were 315 deals under contract, and in the second quarter, but extended through July 10, there were 270, a 14 percent decline despite the additional two weeks. The median price for those deals in the first quarter was $498,000, compared with $525,000 in the extended second quarter, a 5 percent increase.
In the rarefied heights of the Manhattan market -- where money, it seemed for several years, was no object -- sales volume has held fairly firm, but prices have taken a bit of a breather.
Kirk Henckels, director of Stribling Private Brokerage, said there were eight co-op closings in the $10-million-or-more category in the first six months of 2000, for a total of $121 million, or an average of $15.1 million. And while there were also eight closings in that category in the first six months of 2001, their total dollar value was $96.4 million, or an average price of $12.1 million. "That's a decline in dollar volume of 20.3 percent," Mr. Henckels said.
North of Central Park, said R. Kenyatta Punter, president of the Greater Harlem Board of Realtors, "We are starting to see the effects of a slowing economy."
Mr. Punter cited a one-family, five-bedroom brownstone with six fireplaces on Convent Avenue that "came on the market in October 2000 at $850,000, and recently closed at $775,000." A three-bedroom condominium on St. Nicholas Avenue was listed in September at $375,000 "and the owner recently took it off the market because she could not get her price," he said. "These are telltale signs that purchasers are starting to be affected by the economy and, as a consequence, we're seeing resistance to prices that have risen significantly in recent years."

Brooklyn
Nuts-and-Bolts Areas Report Solid Sales
There was not much resistance when Al and Janice Alper put their house in Marine Park, Brooklyn, on the market in June. The Alpers and their children -- Kaitlin, 8; A. J., 6, and Alexandra, 4 -- needed a larger place, even though they bought their three-bedroom home on East 33rd Street only two years ago "for just over $220,000," Mr. Alper said.
"My wife and I were worried about what we would get in today's market," he said. "And I really thought it would take closer to six months. You see, we hadn't actually begun looking for a place, and then, inside of four days, we had 12 offers and three at our asking price" -- $335,000.
"I said, 'Oh, my God, we better start looking,' " recalled Mr. Alper, chief information officer for a financial management company. Over the next three weeks, the Alpers looked at two dozen homes.
They are now in contract, at "just over half a million," for a five-bedroom home in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, that also has a dining room "and a den!" Mr. Alper exclaimed, "with a lock on the door, because that's mine, make no mistake about it."
"You go into this anticipating having a couple of months to think about it, to research areas, to quietly decide over dinner which of five houses you might want to buy, and then it goes into this freneticism," he said. "I need a vacation from that; I go to work to relax."
There are three multiple listing services -- South Shore, Midcounty and Bay Ridge-Bensonhurst -- covering what might be called the nuts-and-bolts parts of Brooklyn, as opposed to the more affluent, Manhattanesque downtown Brooklyn.
Nuts-and-bolts Brooklyn has performed solidly so far this year, said Gerard Longo, president of the South Shore Multiple Listing Service, who compiled data in cooperation with the other listing services. 
In the first six months of last year, 3,771 contracts were recorded by the three services. In the first half of this year, 4,039 contracts were recorded -- a 7.1 percent increase. And while there were 1,911 contracts signed in this year's first quarter, there were 2,128 signed in the second quarter -- an 11.3 percent rise.
Mr. Longo was not able to gather price statistics covering all three listing services. So, as a barometer, he looked at numbers for his own company, Madison Estates Realty. In the second quarter of 2000, including the first two weeks of July, Mr. Longo's company had 132 deals in contract with a median price of $315,000. For the same period this year, there were 153 contracts with a median price of $330,000 -- a 16 percent rise in sales volume and a 5 percent increase in median price.
"I am a little surprised," he said. "Historically, real estate follows Wall Street by six months to a year. Fortunately, that has not been the case this year. As a matter of fact, if Wall Street is looking for where the bulls are, maybe investors should look to real estate. It seems like that's the best bet outside of Pamplona."
The picture is a little less clear in downtown, or brownstone, Brooklyn.
According to Christopher Thomas, vice president for Brooklyn at the William B. May Company, which specializes in the area, the average sales price for deals brokered by his company in 2000 was $579,238. So far this year, the average is $563,242 -- a 2.7 percent slip. "I have to say that I don't consider that statistically significant because it's perfectly possible that we sold one more $2.5 million house in 2000 than we have so far in 2001," Mr. Thomas said.
Reluctant to disclose precise sales numbers, Mr. Thomas did point out that "dealing with only closed deals, we are, to date, off by 5 percent from the year 2000." More encouragingly, however, "in terms of contracts pending as of June 30, we are up by 36 percent, 2001 versus 2000," he said.
"I really see buyers and sellers coming together," Mr. Thomas said. "Finally, after several years of just a strong sellers' environment, we're coming to a greater balance; available listings as a function of the number of people who want to purchase."
"Buyers now are able to make more informed decisions with more product to choose from," he said. "Sellers are able to find buyers at what are still historically record levels, and interest rates remain low. From my point of view, this is smooth, blue-water sailing."

Queens
A Jump in Sales And Also in Prices
In Queens, said Joseph E. Mottola, chief executive of the Long Island Board of Realtors, "The story is the magnitude of the increase."
And a parallel between contracts and closed deals lends credence to that assertion. While the 388 contracts and their $245,000 median price this June represented jumps of 18.3 percent and 22 percent respectively over June 2000, there were 320 transactions that actually closed in June 2001, or 17.6 percent more than in June 2000. And the median price for those closed deals was $235,100, 23.4 percent higher than the $190,500 median in June of last year.
"That's significantly more than the increase in Nassau County," Mr. Mottola said.
Asked to offer some site-specific examples, James F. O'Kane, president of ERA O'Kane Realty in Maspeth, said: "We closed one on July 13, a one-family frame in Maspeth, three bedrooms, finished basement, garage, and it sold for $399,000 -- full asking price. Now a year ago, if this house sold for $300,000, $310,000, it would have been a good price." 
"There's no slippage," Mr. O'Kane continued. "Mortgage companies and banks have the money, and they want to lend it."
Walter Messina, vice president of Glenjay Realty in Forest Hills and president of the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, pointed to an attached stucco, three-bedroom home on Fleet Street in Forest Hills. "It's in contract, as of early July, for $365,000," Mr. Messina said. "A year ago, it would have been $300,000."

Staten Island
Seeing a Shift From Stock to Houses
Likening the housing market in her borough to a peculiar traffic pattern, Sophia Gibaldi, president of the Staten Island Board of Realtors, said: "Sometimes you're on a highway, the traffic slows and you wonder if there's an accident up ahead. Then you just proceed and there was no accident, and you move full speed ahead. My opinion is that people got scared, started selling their stocks. They passed that intersection where the traffic slowed down, but haven't stopped going into houses."
Data from the Staten Island Board of Realtors compared the second quarter of 2000 -- about the time that the Nasdaq bubble burst -- with the second quarter of 2001. There were 937 contracts with an average price of $226,133 signed from March 1 to June 30 of last year, and in the same period this year, there were 1,092 contracts with an average price of $252,221 -- increases of 16.5 and 11.5 percent respectively. 
In the first half of this year, the Staten Island board reported, the average price for a single-family home in the West Brighton section was $166,852. In Huguenot, it was $219,751; and in Heartland Village, $238,196.

Bronx
Prices and Sales Holding, Agents Say
The Bronx Board of Realtors does not gather sufficient data to provide a profile of the borough. But Susan Goldy, president of a Riverdale brokerage firm that bears her name, offered her impression: "We would have more sales if we had more houses to sell, and prices have held their own."
Ms. Goldy cited a three-bedroom row house on Liebig Avenue that was listed in June for $388,000 and sold for $375,000; and a six-bedroom, five-bath stucco home in Fieldston, built in 1899 with a 1920 addition, that listed for $1.1 million and sold for $995,000. "I think they both would have sold for a little less last year," she said.
In the less tony Williamsbridge section, said Floyd Cooper, president of the Cooper Group on the Grand Concourse, a two-family house on East 225th Street sold in June for $265,000 after being listed for $285,000. And on Pond Place in Kingsbridge, a one-family, four-bedroom sold for $160,000 in June. "They were asking $170,000," Mr. Cooper said. "And a year ago, I think, it would have sold for $140,000."
Two weeks ago, Tamar and William Greeley moved into a three-bedroom condominium in Riverdale, after getting a taste of the current market. "We sold in Manhattan, a one-bedroom condo in Murray Hill," Ms. Greeley said. "We have a 16-month-old girl, Gabriella, and needed more room."
The Greeleys -- she a printing company executive, he a futures trader -- bought the Manhattan apartment in 1997 for $216,250. "We sold for $385,000; it's pretty ridiculous," Ms. Greeley said. 
"The problem was that for what we were looking for in Manhattan -- a two-bedroom doorman building in the same neighborhood -- the prices were close to $1 million," Ms. Greeley said. Instead, they got a three-bedroom apartment with a terrace in a high-rise building with 24-hour concierge service and a health club -- for $380,000.
"We have almost triple the space we had in Manhattan, beautiful views of the Harlem and Hudson Rivers from every window," she said. "Manhattan is just not affordable for us these days. We're just Greeleys, not Rockefellers."

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS; 
'Let's Go for the Bronze'

BYLINE:  By NEIL GENZLINGER 

 BODY:
Lucky New Jersey. Poor Connecticut. Or maybe it's the other way around.
 The Census Bureau disclosed last week that it had been determined that New Jersey had the highest median household income in the country, $54,226, while Connecticut, once the top dog, had fallen to No. 2, at $53,108. 
 The bureau admitted that the numbers might not be accurate and that the difference was probably statistically meaningless. But that did not prevent a storm, or at least a slight breeze, of reaction, from pride to wariness; from concern to indifference to outright befuddlement.
There was, for instance, Tammy Zazuri of Southport, Conn., who seemed a bit skeptical that much-maligned New Jersey outranked her state.
"Oh my God, that's definitely wrong," said Ms. Zazuri.
Mel Braverman, who was standing outside a jewelry store in Greenwich, Conn., also showed signs of disbelief.
"This is where the 400 live," Mr. Braverman said, referring to the legendary list of the social elite. "You've got some of the richest families in America here. Nobody brags about New Jersey. It's famous for its mosquitoes. Garden farms. Chicken farms. The image is quite different. This is where the gentry live."
Mr. Braverman, it should be noted, qualified as a disinterested party, since he lived in Melville, on Long Island, and he offered this prediction for the home state of Joseph I. Lieberman, Al Gore's running mate last year: "Connecticut is going to ask for a recount. They're not going to accept this."
Oddly, a recount was also on the mind of at least one New Jersey resident, Edward Tenner of the department of English at Princeton, whose book "Why Things Bite Back" is all about the bad side of seemingly good things.
"New Jersey's ranking is frightening news," Mr. Tenner said, tongue slightly in cheek. "It's not just that it makes most individual citizens feel poorer rather than richer. It's also that media superlatives -- Person of the Year, Most Respected Company -- so often are followed by a close encounter with some malevolent, headline-scanning, tall-poppy-lopping force.
"How much better to be known as second or third -- not haughty One or envious Two," as New Jersey's own Nathaniel Burt put it. "Let's hope some people merely punched the wrong census chad and that the error will be corrected in due course. When it comes to gold, let's go for the bronze."
Indeed, becoming No. 1 did not produce the kind of in-the-street celebrating in New Jersey that might greet a national championship for the Rutgers football team. Seth McLaughlin, a New Jersey real estate agent, suggested why.
"Someone in Morris County who makes $54,226 has a very slim chance of even buying a small condo or house," Mr. McLaughlin said. "Unfortunately, the average people are being forced to move west, south or north and commute excessive distances. We lucky ones who have a house already are benefiting, but our area is turning into an area where only the rich can live."
Still, Fred Kelly, dean of the School of Business Administration at Monmouth University, said high real estate prices did have their advantages if one happened to be about to retire, sell and flee. ("That's money you can take with you to Florida," he noted.) But for anybody else, Mr. Kelly said, having a high income in a high-cost state is a dubious blessing.
"It's good for your bragging rights and it's probably good for people who will be spending a lot of time here and are looking toward retirement," he said. "But for most workers, it's going in one hand and out the other."
Karen Plunkett-Powell, who is currently peddling the new paperback edition of her book "Remembering Woolworth's," sees bad things ahead for New Jerseyans, and for her dream of bringing back the glory days of the 5 and 10.
"Once national retailers get wind of it, they'll institute a special, higher New Jersey price for everything," Ms. Plunkett-Powell said. "A stampede of out-of-state entrepreneurs will head to the suburbs to open boutiques featuring $25 designer paper clips and $100 bags of saltwater taffy. In five years the motto of the Garden State will change from 'N.J. and You -- Perfect Together' to 'N.J. and You -- Broke Together.' "
So it is not as if the Garden State is gloating. Yet in Connecticut, there is resentment in the air.
"It's Jersey," said Al Ojeda, assistant manager of Sunglass Hut International at the Connecticut Post Mall in Milford. "We're always going to be compared to Jersey now, which is probably not going to be cool."
Chris Carletti of Greenwich, though, at least gave New Jersey credit for helping itself by going after small entrepreneurs and technology companies. 
"I don't see that as much in Connecticut," Mr. Carletti said. "What do we have in Connecticut? We have people who work on Wall Street and come here for tax reasons. We have defense spending, and there's old money. What else do we have here?"
Connecticut, he added, "is living in the past."
A less involved theory of how Connecticut fell from highest-income grace, was offered by Jim Cullen, a truck driver of Trumbull.
"Did Paul Newman move out?" Mr. Cullen asked.
And then there was Chris Moriarty, who grew up in relatively well-off Cheshire, Conn., but jumped to New York City years ago for the not-so-lucrative life of a cabdriver (a career he will soon be trading in for the even less lucrative life of a public school teacher). Mr. Moriarty has always felt a tad ridiculous for leaving the big-money state. 
"It is such a pleasure to see New Jersey take over the reins," he said. "It makes leaving Connecticut a little less painful. Now if only all the rich people from the suburbs of Jersey would consider taking my nice, air-conditioned taxi home from the city for a cozy $100 fare . . . "
As for the outside world, the battle for household-income dominance seems not exactly to have captured its full attention. Told of the news of New Jersey's triumph, Gerry Flahive, a film producer and humor writer in Toronto, had this to say: "I once changed planes at Newark, and the people there seemed very nice. I was not aware that there was an entire state that went with it. Congratulations, Governor Cuomo."

GRAPHIC: Photo: When not counting all of its money, New Jersey welcomes visitors to the state -- in this instance at Washington's Crossing. (Jill C. Becker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Schoolyard Solutions for Crown Hts. Youths

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
AS the days get hotter and the new school year looms, the fretting starts for Richard Green, chief executive of the Crown Heights Youth Collective in Brooklyn. He faces a shorter list of diversions to lessen the temptations of drugs and gangs on blocks where youth unemployment stands at 85 percent and some young men see prison as a rite of passage.
 Simple things work best. Mr. Green recently put up a basketball hoop on a block near the collective at 915 Franklin Avenue. The neighbors complained about the noise, so he took it down. Then he attached a hoop to a fence at a nearby school, but the school custodian complained and asked that he remove that hoop, too. 
 After the failure of his hoop dreams, it occurred to Mr. Green that a good place for young people to congregate on summer nights might be the schoolyards. They already have hoops and other equipment and plenty of space. But Mr. Green noted in frustration that most of the neighborhood schoolyards are locked in the evening.
"Everything is locked up in New York: the school, the churches, the bathrooms," said Mr. Green, a dreadlocked former marine, as he sat in his cluttered office the other day. "There are four schoolyards in a two-block radius. Where do young people hang out? On the corner, on the block."
And on the streets, he said, those young people are bait for all manner of trouble.
"There is no place now where people can come together to be friends," he said. "The schoolyards should be open all the time. During the school day they should be off limits, but during the evening they should be open to anyone's use."
When Richard Green talks, people listen. In the last decade he has emerged as an important figure in Crown Heights, getting people from different communities to talk and keeping young people from harm's way. Next Sunday is the 10th anniversary of three days of street battles between blacks and Jews in Crown Heights, after a car accident in which a black child was killed by a Jewish driver and a Jewish man was killed by a black mob in apparent retaliation.
Race relations in Crown Heights are a different story these days. But Mr. Green is perturbed by all those locked schoolyards, because a dreary constant is how disfranchised the neighborhood's children are, as reflected in high rates of infant mortality, overcrowded schools and long waits for day care.
In August 1991, young people were the bulk of the rioters, and some said their frustration with life in general was a reason they took to the streets.
Some neighborhood youth advocates said services have not improved enough since a 1992 report by a group called the Crown Heights Coalition found that fewer than 9 percent of youth agencies offered organized recreational or sports facilities, and that there was one youth service worker for every 2,300 youths.
Mr. Green is smart enough to know that unlocking schoolyard gates is the proverbial drop in the bucket, even though he hopes to sit down with some principals this fall. It's just one idea, he says, a symbolic open door.
Others who work with young people in the neighborhood also deplored the paucity of services, but had a mixed reaction to open schoolyards.
Citywide, there is no hard and fast policy on locking schoolyards, said Kevin Ortiz, a Board of Education spokesman. Some are locked and some not, based mostly on the wishes of the principal and the community. If crime is a problem in the area, or if the sounds of late-night basketball bother neighbors, the gates are locked, Mr. Ortiz said. 
"Generally, the yards are closed at dusk and they are locked," he said.
The other day, at a Police Athletic League play site at a playground on Sterling Street between Nostrand and New York Avenues, some children and adults said they liked the idea of unlocked schoolyards. But others thought they would be a magnet for gangs and vandals.
"Any diversion from the stuff out there is needed," said Lance Johnson, an auxiliary police officer with the 71st Precinct and the play site's program director. "I think I'd rather do it in the schools than in the schoolyards."
"She just became a mother," he said, pointing to a 15-year-old girl strolling into a nearby building. "Maybe when that gentleman came knocking on the door she would have been busy with other things, like a step class, if we had it to offer."

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
LAYOFFS INCREASE

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
 New Jersey companies eliminated 26,378 jobs last month, the second highest number in the nation, according to a monthly survey released by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago job placement firm. 
California topped the list with 45,095 jobs lost. The cuts are attributed to the state where the company headquarters is located even if the workers do not live in that state. New Jersey's total job loss was attributed in large part to the announcement by Lucent Technologies that it would cut nearly 20,000 jobs. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Wall Street Still Sees No Wolves In Its Midst

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
The future always seems to look the same.
 In January 1990, with the American economy on the verge of slowing, Wall Street economists predicted growth would accelerate in about six months. When Iraq invaded Kuwait that August, they quickly lowered their forecasts but predicted the economy would pick up in another six months. By October, when a recession was well under way, they further downgraded their estimates -- but again they said the economy should be growing in six months. 
 If you were to look only at Wall Street's long-term forecasts, you might never know that the recession of 1990-91 occurred, says Ethan Harris, an economist at Lehman Brothers. Think of it as the Street's version of the boy who cried wolf.
The ever-optimistic prognostications have returned during this slowdown. First, the recovery was going to begin in the second quarter. Then it was the third quarter. Now -- any minute now, it will begin in the second half of the third quarter.
And it might. The prediction, by its nature, will be correct eventually, much as it turned out to be in October 1990. These days, companies' inventories are shrinking. A $38 billion tax rebate is in the mail. Interest rates are falling. For all those reasons, optimism is the consensus.
But the very consistency of the predictions means that the other view deserves a hearing, too. The contrarians are rare on Wall Street and, apparently, in the White House. They are more common in Washington research centers -- both conservative and liberal -- and in academia.
"It is time for economists to quit touting a second-half recovery," John H. Makin, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, wrote recently in an article on its Web site. "An unbecoming chorus of denial is only making a bad situation worse."
The rose-colored view, he says, results from a long expansion that has made a recession seem unthinkable. It also does not help that many Wall Street economists are paid partly based on how much stock their firms sell and so have an incentive to appear bullish, Mr. Makin added.
The pessimistic argument consists of more than psychology. A crucial part of the optimists' story is the idea that companies are making decisions more quickly as a result of computer systems that give them up-to-date information about their business. According to conventional wisdom, companies have used this knowledge to cut jobs and hours more rapidly than in the past, laying the groundwork for a fast recovery.
The story sounds plausible, and that probably accounts for its popularity, but the government's statistics do not support it. 
SINCE private employment peaked in March at 111.9 million jobs, it has declined 0.34 percent, according to the Labor Department. That is more significant than it sounds, but it also is nearly identical to what happened in the four months after employment peaked in June 1990. At that point, jobs had declined 0.37 percent, and they still had seven more months to fall. 
Look at hours worked, too. Over the last year, the average workweek for nonsupervisory employees -- about 80 percent of the work force -- has declined to 34.2 hours from 34.4 hours, the Labor Department said. It is down from a peak of 34.7 hours more than three years ago. But guess what? In January 1991, when the recession still had two months left, the reduction in hours was slightly more severe.
Most troubling, perhaps, corporate profits continue to sink, despite the cuts so far. Without the revenue to support their costs, companies are unlikely to stop dismissing workers or start investing in new computers and equipment again. Already, such investment is in a free fall, having dropped 1.1 percent, 4.1 and 14.5 percent, respectively, the last three quarters, after 38 consecutive quarters of growth. "In order to get a recovery, the investment slowdown has to at least level out," Mr. Makin said in an interview last week, "and I don't see any compelling evidence that that's happening."
Mr. Makin does not doubt that consumers will spend some of their tax rebate, giving the economy a lift of perhaps one-half of a percentage point, on an annual basis, in the second half. The interest rate reductions should help, too.
But skeptics think that the still-deteriorating labor market and large consumer debt load will end up being more significant. Add it all up, and the third quarter will actually be worse than the second. A meaningful recovery begins next year.
Who's right? Check back in six months. By then, Wall Street will probably be very excited about the summer of 2002.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Treasury Officials Reluctantly Become Global Firefighters

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
TREASURY Secretary Paul H. O'Neill is not going to be asked to be an honorary member of the International Association of Fire Fighters. In his first seven months on the job, he has made it abundantly clear that he does not like fighting fires, which is the way he characterizes running to the rescue of emerging market countries that have gotten into financial trouble, as Argentina has right now.
 He has said repeatedly that he wants to reduce the time and money that international financial institutions, led by the International Monetary Fund, spend on firefighting. "Certainly, there will always be unexpected events that we and the institutions will have to deal with, but firefighting should be the exceptional cases for these institutions, not the norm," he said in April. All these comments were a rebuke of the Clinton administration's hands-on firefighting, from the rescue package for Mexico in 1995 to aid for Brazil in 1998. 
 The Bush administration was in lock step with the O'Neill approach as Argentina, in mid-July, teetered near the brink of default. Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, told reporters that "Argentina is trying to take some steps to deal with its economic and financial situation and that is really the best course of action." A spokesman for the International Monetary Fund said there was no plan on the table to speed up the release of future aid for Argentina or consider additional aid.
But that was theory and Mr. O'Neill and the Bush administration are now facing the real world, where events can overtake the best of intentions. Already in April, the administration backed a $10 billion emergency aid package to Turkey. 
Now it seems that Argentina's problems may force the administration back into the fire trucks. Nine days ago, the administration supported a new $15 billion loan for Brazil, the Latin American neighbor that is suffering from the fallout from Argentina's crisis.
Argentina may not have to go it alone. John B. Taylor, the Treasury under secretary for international affairs who as a Stanford professor once proposed the abolition of the I.M.F., met with Argentine officials the first weekend in August and said he was "impressed" by their efforts and supported the speed up of the delivery of $1.2 billion to Argentina from the monetary fund.
Argentine officials are now pressing the fund for as much as $9 billion in additional new assistance. A Treasury official denied one Argentine press report last week of an agreement on new aid but said the Treasury was "monitoring the situation."
Michele A. Davis, assistant Treasury secretary for public affairs, said limiting rescue packages is a goal, not a new policy. "We want to get to where we are not fighting fires. In the meantime, there is a lot of dry kindling lying around and you have to deal with that."
Pointing to an interview with The Financial Times in July, she argued that Mr. O'Neill has made this distinction clear. "The fact that this is not picked up in the press accounts, I can't do anything about," she said. "When you give a speech you are laying out where you want to get too," she said, explaining why Mr. O'Neill's distaste for firefighting has received all the notice.
Geoffrey Dennis, Latin American equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, explained the administration's drift toward firefighting this way: "Whatever the theoretical model is, it is hard to let these countries default on their watch."
BUT because this adjustment is being made without clear enunciation, it is giving the impression that the Treasury Department is being rolled by events. It is adding uncertainty and volatility to emerging markets. And it may be contributing to a quick change in expectations for Argentina, which if dashed now could make its troubles even worse.
"We all came in Monday thinking that Argentina had been cut loose," said Mr. Dennis. The $1.2 billion speedup of aid was not considered to be enough help to satisfy Wall Street, which, of course, would like a bailout that would reduce or even eliminate its recent losses in Argentina and other emerging markets. 
Now, Mr. Dennis said, "it will be a huge surprise if they don't get more funding" in the $6 billion to $9 billion range. And that, he said, "would be firefighting."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
The Perils of Planning One's Own Prepaid Funeral

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
LIKE most people, Louise A. Underwood was used to getting frequent solicitations at her home in Orange, Calif., from just about every type of business, except maybe funeral homes and cemeteries. Only on rare occasions would she find a pamphlet from, say, a cremation company in her mailbox.
 But several weeks ago, she started receiving phone pitches from a cemetery trying to persuade her to prepay her funeral costs. With such plans, the entire cost of a funeral is paid in advance at today's dollars, and the money, or a part of it, is put into an annuity, an insurance policy or a funeral trust. 
 Ms. Underwood, who did not want to saddle her three children and five grandchildren with burial costs, said the prepaid plan sounded tempting, particularly after the saleswoman told her the cost of a funeral could more than double over the next 15 to 30 years. "For every negative concern that I brought up, this woman had an answer," said Ms. Underwood, 49, a grant writer for the Blind Children's Learning Center in Santa Ana, Calif. She passed on the offer. 
There was a time when cemeteries and funeral homes relied primarily on word of mouth, when marketing meant taking out a small ad in a church bulletin or stamping their names on free calendars or pencils. 
But death care, a $15 billion business that includes casket sellers and monument makers, has become increasingly aggressive at promoting itself. Analysts who follow the business say the shift is the result of an industry that is still in debt after a number of acquisitions in the late 1990's as well as the growing popularity of less expensive cremations and the fact that people are simply living longer.
To attract customers, especially to the prepaid plans, some companies are offering new types of services and promotions, like online memorials, which are simple Web sites that honor a deceased loved one. Others are giving prepaid customers a year's worth of access to 24-hour "compassion" help lines or coupons worth thousands of dollars in funeral expenses if a child or grandchild should die before age 21 (the coupon carries the name of the child). A few companies have even changed or adopted names that sound more like a memorial society and less like a business, like the Ohio Cremation & Memorial Society, which is a network of 10 cremation companies.
Several trade groups like the National Funeral Directors Association and the International Cemetery and Funeral Association have been trying to help consumers sort through the marketing melange. Their Web sites (www.nfda.org and www.icfa.org) contain consumer tips and pricing information. (The funeral directors' group noted that the average adult funeral, excluding cemetery charges, costs $5,800.)
Still, some consumer advocates complain that people are being inundated with products and services that they neither want nor need, and at prices that are often questionably high. Other efforts, they say, have come close to violating federal marketing laws that require companies to fully disclose their prices.
SOME companies have engaged in affinity marketing, which usually entails selling discounted services through an umbrella organization. Last March, for example, Service Corporation International of Houston, the world's largest funeral and cemetery company, sent letters to veterans in California and Connecticut who belong to the Veterans of Foreign Wars. Service Corporation hoped to interest veterans in its Dignity Memorial prepaid funeral, which costs $3,295, or its cremation plan, which costs $1,995. 
But some consumer advocates have objected to the company's enrollment form, which asks people to send in a payment before providing pricing information.
Lisa Carlson, the executive director of the Funeral Consumers Alliance in Hinesburg, Vt., (www.funerals.org) said the form violated the federal Funeral Rule of 1984, which requires companies that sell funeral goods and services to first provide an itemized price list and a statement of the goods and services selected.
Jerry Norman, a managing director of marketing at Service Corporation, said that the Dignity Memorial plan is set up so that consumers who sign up have 30 days in which to cancel. Besides, Mr. Norman said, because the company has more than 1,500 sites in North America, it is unable to give consumers itemized price lists unless the company first knows which funeral home has been picked. Consumers are free to get the lists from the homes, he added.
The Internet has turned into an especially potent marketing tool for the funeral industry. Many companies are linked to Internet portals like HeavenlyDoor.com or Forethought.com, as well as the online memorials that offer families and friends many services, including chat rooms and photo galleries of the deceased. 
At LifeFiles.com in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the memorials cost $295 for two years, and are set up so that visitors can gain access to hundreds of other services for funerals, including an online card and flower shop. The sites are renewable annually for $29.95.
Not all consumers are taken with such efforts. After calling the Funeral Consumers Alliance, Ms. Underwood discovered that the local cemetery saleswoman was offering services that cost almost twice as much as those available elsewhere. For example, the saleswoman told her that cremation would cost at least $1,000, when Ms. Underwood knew that her mother and father had recently bought such services from their local cemetery for $650 each.
Cemeteries, unlike funeral homes, are not covered by the federal Funeral Rule, and are required to provide price lists only if they handle the remains. Yet many cemeteries also sell prepaid funerals, and some of those arrangements are falling short.
Last October, the family of Gladys L. Bohn of Modesto, Calif., filed a lawsuit against a mortuary company in Santa Cruz, accusing it of ignoring the specific details of a prepaid plan that Mrs. Bohn had bought in 1989, and which eventually cost $1,866. The suit said that in her contract, Mrs. Bohn had asked for amenities like a light-colored "Princess" casket, the services of a professional cosmetologist and a car and driver for transporting flower arrangements.
But according to the lawsuit, after Mrs. Bohn died at 96 in January 2000, the mortuary could not find her body for three days, then buried her in a particleboard box, without honoring any of her wishes. Her family claims that when her remains were disinterred six months later, she was in a body bag, still wearing her hospital gown.
In June, the AARP Foundation, an affiliate of AARP that provides educational services to older Americans, decided to help represent Mrs. Bohn's family in the lawsuit, which is pending in a California state court.
"We're hearing a lot of complaints about cemeteries," said Stacy J. Canan, a lawyer for the AARP Foundation. "A lot of them run roughshod over consumers because they are in such a vulnerable position and often have no ability to seek recourse."
John Carmon, president of the funeral directors association, said he was aware of the aggressive marketing by certain companies. His group, he says, opposes the telemarketing of any funeral product.
In 1999, the Federal Trade Commission began reviewing the Funeral Rule to assess whether its price disclosure requirement should be expanded to include cemeteries, mortuaries, monument dealers and casket sellers; the agency hopes to decide by fall. 
Eileen Harrington, associate director of marketing practices at the F.T.C., said the prepaid plans were the agency's main concern when it came to the funeral industry.
Ms. Carlson said she had concerns about how the money in the plans was invested. Money that goes into funeral insurance generally does not grow at the same rate as money paid into a trust, she said. And it may not keep up with inflation because a certain amount is used to pay administrative costs, she added.
As for refunds, she said, if consumers change their funeral plans or need to withdraw the money, they generally lose from 5 percent to 30 percent of what they paid in premiums and possibly accrued interest.
Funeral trusts, on the other hand, generally allow the money plus interest to be withdrawn.
Ms. Harrington said individual states, and not the commission, had jurisdiction over insurance policies. 
Another concern, she said, is the lack of authority that her agency has over prepaid policies that are sold by nonprofit entities like churches. 
At least eight states, including New Jersey, now have legislation that either partly or completely bars most funeral homes and cemeteries that are selling prepaid plans from making uninvited contact with consumers, Ms. Carlson said. And even some funeral homes now seem to think that the marketing has gone too far. 
DURING a recent discussion on the Internet, a Florida funeral director complained about a saleswoman at her funeral home. After receiving a call from a man whose father was dying, the saleswoman rushed to the hospital to sell the son a prepaid funeral, and get a $50 commission. The man died hours later.
Ms. Carlson said her organization would like to see prepaid plans sold only by licensed funeral directors.
Ms. Underwood, meanwhile, says she thinks she knows how her name appeared on a phone list. In May, she and her family attended a veteran's memorial at the cemetery, just as they had for the past three years. This time, Ms. Underwood filled out a card that asked for her address, so that she could receive a small American flag stickpin for her 4-year-old grandson, Dane. Within two weeks, her family received its first call.

LENGTH: 3113 words

HEADLINE: The National Pastime Falls Behind in the Count 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
THERE are places where baseball games last just two and a half hours, where batters spend most of their time at home plate trying to hit the ball rather than fidgeting with their equipment. There are also places where the fans of every team legitimately dream of a championship. There are even places where the teams that do fall to last place continue to inspire passion until the final weeks of the season.
 And then there is Major League Baseball. 
 In its world, games stretch beyond midnight, past the school-night bedtimes of the people who should be its most fervent fans. Only the richest of the sport's teams win even a single World Series game. Every September, when many also-ran teams have long since given up hope, their stadiums are empty and at-home fans turn their televisions to other channels. 
It is a strange time for the $3.3 billion business also known as the national pastime. Overall revenue has almost doubled since 1996, and ballparks like Yankee Stadium and Fenway Park are fuller today than they have ever been.
But average attendance for the league still has not recovered to the levels it reached before the 1994 labor dispute -- despite a long economic boom, the construction of 10 stadiums, a doubling of the number of playoff teams and the addition of interleague games pitting, say, the Mets against the Yankees. Meanwhile, the fall of television ratings for games makes the National Football League look good, and the number of children playing organized baseball is plummeting.
All in all, it is enough to make the sport's commissioner sound as if he is living in a Lewis Carroll story. "Baseball is in the midst of an incredible renaissance," said Bud Selig, the sport's top executive -- later acknowledging, "the economic problems are so pervasive that all options should be on the table."
At times like this, companies often seek outside help. So Money & Business has turned not to the usual experts for inspiration, but to the world beyond Major League Baseball -- from the sport's own minor leagues all the way to baseball-agnostic Europe. These are the places where well-paced games are the norm or where even miserable teams can keep fans interested. 
Now is the time to be creative. In less than three months, after the World Series, the current labor agreement between major-league owners and players will expire. Each time the deal has come up for renewal in the last 30 years, there has been either a strike or a lockout. If baseball is going to flirt with that pain yet again, it might as well see what can be gained.
Here are four ideas:

Remedy One
Copy Bush Leagues, Bring Back the Fun
Name one of the nation's largest metropolitan areas, and it probably has a thriving baseball team. It may even have three or four.
The BlueClaws in Lakewood, N.J., playing 60 miles from Philadelphia, have already broken the all-time attendance record for the Class A South Atlantic League, and their inaugural season still has a few weeks left. The Brooklyn Cyclones have sold almost every seat -- about 7,500 a game -- in their first season. In the outer suburbs of Chicago, the Kane County Cougars built a new deck of seats last winter to accommodate their ever-growing crowds.
Every night, thousands of people who could see Cal Ripken Jr. or Sammy Sosa instead choose to watch error-prone 21-year-olds.
"We kind of got laughed at when we started," said Jeff Sedivy, the general manager of the Cougars, who opened for business in 1991. "People were saying, 'Why would anyone be interested in minor-league baseball with two major-league teams in the market?' " But attendance for the Cougars -- four notches below the majors -- has more than doubled in the last 10 years, to 7,500 fans a game. 
Of course, that is far less than the average crowd of 30,000 at a big-league game. On a typical midsummer night, 500,000 people are at major-league parks, compared to the 350,000 watching minor-league games.
But the gap is narrowing. Between 1993 and last year, when per-game attendance fell 4 percent for the major leagues, it rose 19 percent in the minors. At the minors' lowest levels, where the stadiums are smallest, tickets cheapest and players youngest, attendance has risen the most. 
"It's accessible and easy, and it's all fun," said Steve Rogers, who was watching the Cougars beat an Ohio team, the Dayton Dragons, 11 to 2 on a recent Wednesday with his wife and three children. "There's an excitement in the air here. The kids can really see the players." Mr. Rogers said he stopped attending Cubs games after the 1994 lockout.
The majors have copied a few gimmicks from the minors, like having entertainment on the field between innings. On the whole, though, the big leagues have become less like the bush leagues.
Major-league games now last an average of almost 3 hours, about 10 minutes longer than they did in the early 1990's and about 15 minutes longer than a minor-league game does. In the playoffs, they often drag on even longer. 
"You can't have the most important games of the year end at midnight on a school night and not have that come back to bite you," said Bob Costas, the NBC broadcaster and author of "Fair Ball: A Fan's Case for Baseball" (Broadway Books). Watching highlights on ESPN, he added, "can't replace the drama of seeing it as it unfolds and remembering where you were the instant the balls hits the bat."
Shortening games need not involve the one move baseball has made -- its controversial attempts to expand the strike zone -- or the dream fans have about the eliminating the designated hitter. Baseball could, for instance, simply order batters and pitchers to stop wasting time. 
"After every pitch, Chuck Knoblauch" -- the Yankees' left fielder -- "steps out of the box, straightens his helmet, fixes his batting gloves, takes three or four swings," said Geoff Brown, the general manager of Lakewood's BlueClaws, whose home games are averaging 2 hours and 32 minutes. "You don't have guys doing that in the minors." 
Guys weren't doing it 30 years ago in the majors. Just watch an old baseball video.
In a typical minor-league park, fans can also carry on one of baseball's most cherished rituals: a conversation. They don't have to out-shout the music and commercials that dominate so many big-league parks. 
At least one major-league team has seen the virtue in this. The San Francisco Giants recently canceled a team-sponsored "scream off" between fans on opposite sides of the ballpark and turned down the volume on songs played during the game. "It gave everybody a headache," Larry Baer, the team's chief operating officer, said. "We found that by dialing it down a little bit, we have not lost the casual fan."
Two other big differences between the majors and the minors are more complicated. Since 1993, the average ticket price in the big leagues has increased 61 percent on an inflation-adjusted basis to $19, according to Team Marketing Report, a newsletter in Chicago. A typical minor-league ticket costs $6.
Meanwhile, the growing number of luxury skyboxes, which have the best views, has pushed the location of many major-league seats nearly into the clouds. That has stopped John Forni, a Cougars fan, from attending Chicago White Sox games. "Last time I went down there, do you want to know how far up I was? I was so far up, I got seasick," he said. "I'm not kidding."
Roger G. Noll, a Stanford economist who has studied sports business, says there is good reason to reconsider the emphasis on selling to the top end. "The real problem with baseball is that it is increasingly marketing itself to the top 25 percent of the income distribution," he said. That has helped baseball sell more $100 jackets, but he added, "over the long run, it probably undermines building a fan base." 

Remedy Two
The Worst Teams Go to the Minors
It was the final day of the soccer season in Huddersfield, England, where the local team was mired near the bottom of the standings. But odd things -- to American eyes -- were happening all around. Not only was the stadium almost full, but some of the fans had brought radios to keep tabs on a rival.
Far from being unusual, though, similar scenes happen every spring all over Europe. To stoke interest, soccer leagues there "relegate" the worst teams at the end of each season to the minor leagues. They are replaced the following year by the most successful minor-league teams. The demoted teams -- usually three or four, depending on the country -- can return to the top-ranked league only by finishing at the top of the lower league during the next season.
The battle to avoid relegation unfailingly captures attention. "It keeps the season alive," said Russell Thomas, a sports editor at The Guardian in London. "There's sort of a gruesome interest in the grimness of their plight." 
Compare this to the grimness that will take place in Kansas City, Tampa Bay and other downtrodden baseball cities at the end of this season. 
"The thing people are really keen to avoid in Europe is meaningless games between two teams who really don't have anything to play for," said Dan Jones, a consultant with Deloitte & Touche Sport in Manchester, England. "You tend to get a lot of those in baseball."
In fact, the perpetual weakness of some franchises has led Mr. Selig, the commissioner, to say that Major League Baseball should consider disbanding a few teams. "There are many owners who strongly believe we have too many teams," he said. The relocation of one or two teams, to wealthy areas without one, however, is a more likely outcome.
But suppose baseball let the free market solve the problem, as Europe's soccer leagues do. It would be more exciting than contraction or relocation, and maybe more efficient. Baseball would start by deciding how many teams to have in the majors -- say 26, four fewer than currently, to reverse the dilution of talent caused by recent expansion. Baseball would then relegate the two worst teams to the minors -- and, for the first two years, not replace them.
Suddenly, a dreary September game in Montreal between the Pirates and Expos, which now draws maybe 5,000 fans, would bring a Coliseum-like excitement: the loser would be facing the baseball equivalent of death.
At the same time, baseball could award four new franchises to cities that want a major-league team: Charlotte, N.C., Portland, Ore., San Jose, Calif., and Washington come to mind. These teams would join the relegated teams in a new minor league that would soon promote its top two teams to the majors at the end of each season.
In the new league, "everybody who was playing above .500 would have promotion as part of their marketing in the second half of the season," said Mr. Noll, the economist, who has studied English soccer teams.
The markets with the biggest fan bases and television audiences would generate enough money to remain in the majors consistently. Others would find a comfortable place in the lower league or would bounce up and down between the two. Owners who seek profit but not wins would have to the face the consequences of the terrible teams they put on the field. In future years, those teams would no longer be able to play against the game's stars.
This plan may be radical, but it has another advantage over contraction: If baseball had decided to eliminate some teams in the 1980's, Atlanta and Seattle, two of the worst, might have gone. Today, both are in first place, and among baseball's richer teams. If they had been disbanded, they never could have staged their resurrection. 

Remedy Three
Find New Customers In Other Countries
When American companies absolutely, positively need to increase profits, they often go overseas for new consumers and cheap labor. Major League Baseball has figured out the second tack. Rosters are filled with Latin-American players, who command small signing bonuses, and proven Asian stars, like Seattle's Ichiro Suzuki, are becoming more common, too.
Now baseball is trying exports. It has sold broadcast rights to more foreign television stations, pushing international revenue to $60 million last year, from $2 million in the early 90's. But the strategy is hardly aggressive. When McDonald's moves into a new market, it doesn't sell frozen Big Macs in supermarkets; it opens restaurants. Baseball, though, sells only a derivative of its product -- broadcasts of the games.
The sport has not always been so tame in its exports. In 1954, Cincinnati moved its top minor-league team to Havana. The team was called the Cuban Sugar Kings, and their slogan was, "One more step, and we'll get there." It referred to the major-league ambitions of both the players and the city itself, according to Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria, the author of "The Pride of Havana: A History of Cuban Baseball" (Oxford University Press).
The team's high point came in 1959, when it won the Triple A championship. The final games in Havana drew 30,000 fans, including Che Guevara in a box behind home plate and Fidel Castro, who threw the ceremonial first pitch. The following season, as tensions between the United States and Cuba rose, the league moved the team to Jersey City.
These days, several cities within a short flight of the United States are again intriguing possibilities for new minor-league teams. When Major League Baseball played its opening game of the 1999 regular season in Monterrey, Mexico, tickets sold out within hours. The same happened in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in April, when the Texas Rangers played the Toronto Blue Jays.
Monterrey has three million people, and President Vicente Fox has called it a model of economic development. San Juan is a typically baseball-loving Caribbean city and has already had one brush with the minors.
In the mid-1990's, David Hersh was planning to move the team he ran in Nashville, Tenn., to San Juan, which he considered to be the largest untapped market in the United States. But the Seattle Mariners, whose up-and-coming players were on the team's roster, blocked the move, saying they wanted the team within the continental United States, Mr. Hersh said. 
Yes, Monterrey and San Juan are quite poor by American standards. "There are the sponsorship dollars for a Triple A franchise" in San Juan, Mr. Hersh said. "There are not the ticket-buying dollars," because the island has a small middle class. 
Yet both cities are within reasonable flying distance of the double-A Texas League. Just as most companies enter new markets without expecting immediate profitability, baseball would probably need to view new foreign franchises as an investment in their initial years. 
But it would be an investment almost certain to create new fans of American baseball. The teams might even become part of the big leagues one day, as the Sugar Kings hoped to.

Remedy Four
Can't Beat 'Em? Share the Wealth
The Oakland A's seem to be the perfect rejoinder to those who think baseball's richest teams dominate the sport. Playing a short drive from the more popular Giants, the A's generate relatively little revenue and have a small payroll. Yet, with talented young players, they won their division last year and could make the playoffs this year as a wild card. 
Oddly, though, their fans don't seem particularly moved. Only 25,100, on average, go to a game -- leaving the A's 20th, among 30 teams, in attendance and well below the pace they set in the late 1980's, when they were last up-and-comers. 
It's hard to blame the fans. When the A's were stumbling at the beginning of this season, its executives began talking about trading Jason Giambi -- last year's American League most valuable player -- because he was expensive. Giambi remains in Oakland, but no clear-thinking A's fan can expect the core of the current team to stay together for the next few years. And this version of the A's still has not won a single playoff series.
"What matters to a fan," Mr. Costas said, "is the perception of a team's ability to contend."
By every measure, fewer teams have that ability today than just a decade ago. The gap between the richest team's local revenue and the poorest has grown to almost 20 to 1, from 4 to 1 a decade ago, driven by the big differences in television rights fees across the country. 
"The disparity is so large," said Paul Volcker, the former Federal Reserve Chairman, who served on league-appointed committee to study the game, "that it leads fairly directly to a chronic inability on the playing field of a considerable number of clubs ever to get on the winning side of things."
"Presumably, that weakens interest in baseball," he added.
True, wealthy teams, like the Yankees, dominated the sport in earlier eras, but the problem has not always afflicted the sport. In the 1980's and even the early 1990's, when the difference between a small and large payroll was much less, more frugal teams -- like the 1990 Cincinnati Reds or 1985 Kansas City Royals -- regularly played in and even won the World Series. Since 1995, no team with a payroll ranked lower than 7th has won a single Series game.
The National Football League offers an alternative. In the 1960's, on the eve of their first big television contract, football's large-market owners agreed with their colleagues and Pete Rozelle, the commissioner, to split revenue almost evenly.
Football is now the most-watched sport on television, and in the last five years, New York, St. Louis, Nashville and even Green Bay, Wis., have all had teams appear in the Super Bowl.
Baseball and football may seem to be opposite in many respects. George Carlin even wrote a stand-up routine about their differences. ("Baseball begins in the spring, the season of new life. Football begins in the fall, when everything's dying.")
But changing its financial structural would hardly threaten baseball's romance. "We have not served our long-term problems well," Mr. Selig said. "It's one thing I'll give Pete Rozelle and the owners of the N.F.L. a lot of credit for."
Like almost everything else in baseball, this issue is tied up in the rocky labor situation. The owners are using the revenue gap to try to force a salary cap on players. The players scoff at the owners' complaints that many teams are no longer profitable.
Few people question that the issue is the biggest one now facing baseball, however. In the upcoming negotiations, "we expect it likely that the most signigicant topic will be revenue sharing," said Don Fehr, the head of the players' union. 
Whatever specific form a new system takes -- a salary cap or a steep tax on rich teams, perhaps phased in gradually -- many fans just want a return to the days when anything seemed possible. After all, what is the point of watching a sport if a good part of the outcome is already clear?

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Modern Preservation; 
It's Still All About Form and Function

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY VIDLER; Anthony Vidler, just named dean of the Cooper Union School of Architecture, is author of "Warped Space: Art, Architecture and Anxiety in Modern Culture."

 BODY:
THE word "preservation" evokes images of cathedrals and chateaus, colonial homes and Civil War sites, historic monuments that have a fixed place in the local or national heritage. But as historical research and shifting public tastes identify more and more recent buildings as worthy of conservation, the public is being asked to weigh the intrinsic cultural value of somewhat more ephemeral structures, built for commercial or public use over the last century and now threatened by pressures on real estate and changing business practices.
 The current debate about proposed alterations to Eero Saarinen's dramatic icon of 1960's aesthetics, the Trans World Airlines Flight Center at Kennedy International Airport, with a public review set for Tuesday, points to an increasing problem in our culture of obsolescence: what to do with buildings that have outlived their original purposes. 
 Thus neighborhoods like the meat-packing district on the West Side of Manhattan, office buildings like Gordon Bunshaft's elegant Lever House on Park Avenue and not-so-old structures like Edward Durrell Stone's museum for Huntington Hartford at the southwest corner of Central Park, join the T.W.A. terminal as environments radically different in form but with the same interest in survival. All are at the center of battles over preservation, restoration or adaptive re-use now common in urban politics. 
As increasing numbers of relatively recent buildings are seen to have historic and aesthetic value, these battles will only intensify. The organization Docomomo, established in 1990 for the worldwide "Documentation and Conservation of the Modern Movement," has brought to public attention structures from Brazil to Sweden that, 10 years ago, were not thought worthy of preservation yet represent the heritage of modernist design. 
Preservation is not a new issue. It has been a battle cry in expanding metropolitan areas since the early 19th century, when lovers of Gothic architecture were angered by the perceived "vandalism" of the French Revolution.
But the recent cases refocus the issue in two new ways. First, these are buildings designed in an era when "modern" architecture was seen as the ultimate answer to the problems of technological society -- when architecture proclaimed itself free of the burden of history. The aim was not to design monuments, but "machines" for living and working, mass-produced for mass society. The shock is realizing even modernity has a history with its own monuments. Second, the special nature of functionalist designs -- "form follows function," as modernists kept repeating -- often created buildings that seem resistant to change.
The problem is compounded when opinion is divided over a building's merits. The lattice-facaded museum by Stone is a good example of a work derided from the outset, but that many historians now feel warrants preservation. Or consider if Walter Gropius's Pan Am Building, now the MetLife Building, atop Grand Central were at risk. How to evaluate a building castigated at its inception for blocking the vista of Park Avenue, but that remains a significant work of an important architect? Like the T.W.A. terminal, it represents a historic moment in the aspirations for flight as an aid to global communication. What criteria -- aesthetic, historical, functional -- are to be used for so recent a monument?
What Victor Hugo called "The War of the Demolishers" in 1832, is still without clear issue. Indeed, it has become evident that there are no real winners in these preservation debates. Wholesale preservation and restoration of buildings and districts has tended to turn them into species of theme parks, where the activity of looking has replaced the activity of original use. "Adaptive reuse" often destroys a building's original character. Comprehensive demolition and redevelopment usually wipe out all traces of a district's historic past. 
The issue seems divided into two opposing solutions. Should we adopt the premise that nothing should alter an architect's original intention, even if it means preserving a structure no longer useful save as a large museum object? Or should we be blind to historic value, transform at will, and let later generations sort out what was good, bad or indifferent in modern architecture?
The discussion of the T.W.A. terminal poses the problem starkly. Its dynamically sculptural form, inside and out, where the curves of the roof shells merge gently into the walls, and smoothly join with the floors and ramped levels, and these again into the building's very furnishings -- benches, ticket counters and information stands -- seems to have been cast from a single mold. Such total unity calls for total preservation. The terminal is a perfectly self-contained object -- anything subtracted or added necessarily "spoils" this perfection. To cut off one of the access tubes that once led to the planes would be like cutting off an arm from a sculpture of a figure. 
Here, perhaps the solution is not to transform the building to fit new functions but rather to reverse the process, and imagine new functions for the old form. Where one activity has ceased to inform a space, another might give it new meaning. This epitome of 60's symbolic modernism, once the expression-filled instrument of seamless flow between curb and aircraft, may take on new significance as the iconic anchor to the new high-tech hangars for the masses. As a center of business exchange and elegant restaurant service, it could serve today's travelers.
What is needed is less a costing out of one obsolete structure against its apparently more efficient replacement; less the measuring of an old form against new demands; less even the fierce debates over the aesthetic worth of older buildings, than a creative assessment of a building's formal values and spatial qualities, in relation to a gamut of possible new uses, followed by a reshaping of these uses themselves. After all, even a new building like Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, has demonstrated that buildings alone can provoke significant economic and cultural renewal. The concept of "adaptive reuse" might then be applied to function, not to form. 
BUT even with inventive solutions, the basic question remains. To what extent should cities or areas become "museums" of their own past, set in amber for the delight of future generations, as opposed to dynamic centers of growth?
The answer will affect economic development, but will also reflect the shifting values of communities with changing ethnic and cultural identities. It will bring many new kinds of structures -- everything from freeway intersections to industrial constructions -- within the purview of preservationists.
How to manage this heterogeneous heritage without indiscriminately subjecting it to the wrecker's ball or blocking needed development is a problem of public policy that requires an equally heterogeneous range of solutions. The outcome of the T.W.A. terminal debate will, in this sense, be a measure of our society's ability to confront its history.

Diggs for The New York Times); Saarinen's T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy International Airport seemed to epitomize the glamour and aspirations of flight. (Ezra Stoller/Esto)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA; 
600-Foot Office Tower Is Proposed In an Area Where Lofts Abound

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
In 1961, when TriBeCa was the butter-and-eggs district and Washington Street was a desolate fold of raw warehouses and leftover markets, the city created a 25-block urban renewal area to spur development.
 Four decades later, the city is planning a 32-story office tower on the last open parcel, an L-shaped site known as 5B, which is bounded by West, Greenwich, Warren and Murray Streets. And residents say this is just too much development in what has become a heavily residential area. 
 The building would be two blocks shy of the World Trade Center and the World Financial Center. But across the street are Public School 234 and the Greenwich Court condominiums, as well as numerous converted lofts.
"It's hard to imagine a more inappropriate location for a commercial building of this size and bulk," said Bernard D'Orazio, president of Save Our Space, a community group formed to fight development.
The developer chosen by the city, Edward J. Minskoff Equities, has proposed a 600-foot-tall granite-and-glass building with a landscaped plaza, a ground-floor retail pavilion and one million square feet of offices. It was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Rick Matthews, a spokesman for Minskoff, said the building would satisfy a huge demand for downtown offices.
The proposal must pass environmental review as well as win city approval. If approved, it would be the first new office building in lower Manhattan in a decade, and among the first without tenants already committed since the 1980's.
Some real estate experts say the project's timing makes sense, even with a softening market. "Assuming Minskoff gets financing, it would be shrewd to be contrarian," said Robert L. Billingsley, vice chairman of Colliers ABR, a commercial real estate firm. "In another three years, it will be a brave new world." DENNY LEE
