HEADLINE: Travel to Exotic Places and Buy, Buy, Buy 

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
FLUTED columns and an outsize copy of Michelangelo's "David" dominate the Forum and the Appian Way, the shopping arcades at Caesars Palace. But they were fleeting distractions to Rebecca Bennett, who toured the resort hotel on a summer day with only one object in mind. "Since I got here this afternoon, I've done nothing but shop, said Ms. Bennett, 24, a student from San Diego. She burrowed into a gilt-embossed shopping bag and produced a pair of leather sandals. "I have 10 more bags in my hotel room," she gloated, "all shoes, all sandals, and I have even more CD's and a gorgeous chamois-colored leather jacket. I've been to Las Vegas six times, maybe seven. Each time, the only reason was to shop."
 For travelers like Ms. Bennett, this city founded on legalized sin has improbably morphed into America's premier shopping destination. Today, Las Vegas Boulevard, the fabled Strip, is a mile and a half of theme-park-style casino hotels, synthetic volcanos and more retail stores than Madison Avenue, including all the luxury names: Tiffany, Gucci, Neiman Marcus. With so many temptations in the paths of tourists, it was perhaps just a matter of time before they were bypassing slot machines in favor of malls, their pursuit of the perfect tank top or stiletto heel eating into ever larger chunks of their vacation time. 
 Four years ago, gambling was the No. 1 priority of Las Vegas visitors. Now, the city's Convention and Visitors Authority says, gambling ranks No. 2 behind entertainment, which includes dining out, floor shows and shopping. Visitors spend more on shopping, $166 on the average trip, than on shows or sightseeing. Every major designer and mass merchant is represented, including Versace, Banana Republic and F. A. O. Schwarz. 
Vacationers have always shopped, of course, picking up mementos wherever they stayed. But now, shopping, once a byproduct of travel, has moved to the top of vacation agendas, competing with and sometimes superseding activities like museumgoing, theater and sports. "For many Americans, shopping has taken over not just Sunday afternoons, but entire family holidays," said Candace Corlett, a partner at WSL Strategic Retail, a New York consulting firm. 
Shopping -- long viewed by students of retail as entertainment in its own right or as consumer self-expression -- has lately emerged as the primary reason for many Americans to take to the road. A study by the Travel Industry Association of America this year reported that shopping was the No. 1 or No. 2 reason for taking a trip, according to 51 percent of those surveyed. "It can be submitted," the study said, that "shopping is a cause, not effect of the decision to travel." 
The study also corrected the impression that travelers mostly buy T-shirts and souvenir mugs. The average shopping traveler spent $333, with one in five spending $500. The most common purchases were clothes or shoes. 
On both coasts and in between, well-stocked shops and boutiques often draw bigger crowds than historical sites and landmarks. "Increasingly, stores are tourist destinations in and of themselves," said James Gilmore, the author with Joseph Pine of "The Experience Economy" (Harvard Business Press, 1999), which argues that Americans are likely to place a greater value on the experience of shopping than on what they buy. 
Catering to that mind-set, malls and cut-price outlet centers aggressively blur the distinction between shopping and tourism. 
One of the best known, the Mall of America in suburban Minneapolis, with a seven-acre theme park in its midst, attracts 43 million visitors a year, more than a third of them tourists. By contrast, Graceland draws 650,000.
Since opening a decade ago, the Mall of America has offered vacation packages that include a stay at one of the hotels within walking distance. In partnership with Northwest Airlines, the mall offers "Shop Til You Drop" bargain airfares to day-trippers from nearby cities like Fargo, N.D. and Des Moines. 
These days, malls have learned to compete with museums and other traditional tourist attractions by including shops that masquerade as theaters, learning centers or gyms. At the same time, museums and restaurants, with their inevitable expanding gift shops, have come to resemble stores. 
"We have reached a moment when culture and retailing can no longer be separated," said Jeffrey Inaba, one of the editors, along with the influential Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, of the essay volume "Harvard Design School Guide to Shopping," to be published in October. The book argues that shopping now defines the modern city, influencing all aspects of its design. 
"Churches are mimicking shopping malls to attract followers," the introduction states. "Airports have become wildly profitable by converting travelers into consumers. Museums are turning to shopping to survive."
Culture, entertainment and commerce began converging in the early 1990's in retail extravaganzas like REI (Recreational Equipment Inc.) in Seattle, a store that offers a trail loop for bicycle test drives; and Niketown, whose first megastore in Chicago had three-story video screens and sports memorabilia. It became Chicago's top tourist port of call. That city is also home to the American Girl Store, where visitors pay $25 to dine and to see a live stage show, and cap their visit by buying one of the company's popular period dolls, for about $80.
In the hope of inducing shoppers to extend their stays, some new malls are anchored not by traditional department stores, but by skateboard parks and multiplex theaters. The Mills Corporation, a developer based in Arlington, Va., also includes Bass Pro Shops for fishing demonstrations and Gibson guitar showcases at its malls, which are expressly designed to attract tourists. The company says it is a leading tourist draw in every state where its 12 malls are found. Its Ontario Mills in Ontario, Calif., east of Los Angeles, has 24 million visitors a year, more than Disneyland, the company says. (Disney does not make attendance figures public.)
In New York, the Guggenheim Museum and Radio City Music Hall would have to wait for Rachel Turner, 22, a law student from Stuart, Va., shopping in the city. She sifted the racks at Bloomingdale's looking for the perfect pumps. She had missed a trip to the Metropolitan Museum of Art while she did the stores. She did not mind, though she did have one regret: "By the time I got to Tods, the sale was over."
On Fifth Avenue, Terry Hutchison, 48, a homemaker from Newport Beach, Calif. was combing the H&M fashion emporium, with three children. "We've been here about eight days and spent about four of them shopping," she said blithely. "We've hardly done anything else."
No wonder that museums and other cultural institutions feel the pressure to expand into retailing. A new Guggenheim branch designed by Frank Gehry for Lower Manhattan has two shops in its plans. 
But it is Las Vegas, perhaps more than any other city, that has become a magnet for the storestruck. 
"Twenty years ago, the vistor was primarily gambling and looking for the $1.99 all-you-can-eat buffet," said Terri Monsour, the general merchandise manager of the Neiman Marcus branch at the Fashion Show Mall in the middle of the Strip. "Now many of them come with the sole intent of shopping." 
Optimistic that the trend will continue, the 140-store mall plans to double in size starting next year. 
The casino hotels along the Strip are stage sets, self-contained universes in which visitors can lose themselves. Nearly all of them include shopping arcades. The Bellagio Hotel has the Via Bellagio, a glass-domed retail ringer for the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele in Milan. The Desert Passage at Aladdin's Resort Casino is designed to evoke a Middle Eastern souk, with more than 130 stores, among them Tommy Bahama, Billy Martin's and Aveda. 
Amanda Welch, 20, a student from Pittsburgh, held a reserve of $200 from her vacation budget for shopping. She stood rapt at the window of Gucci in the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace. 
"There is a watch here I really covet, but its costs $450," she said with a sigh. "If it was half of that, I might consider it."
At the Venetian Hotel, 70 or so retailers in the Grand Canal Shoppes include Burberry, Jimmy Choo and the Gap, strung like pop beads along a quarter-mile of brick and stone streets. Next month, the Venetian will add two outposts of the Guggenheim Museum, both of them close to the stores. 
It also has plans to expand its "streetmosphere" program, a kind of traveling troubador show of mimes, jugglers, strolling opera singers and warbling gondoliers. 
Such efforts may be lost on Kelly Kinser, 12, of Carbondale, Colo., who visited the arcade with her mother and grandmother, its waterways and Moorish storefronts serving as a backdrop for a spending spree. 
"Shopping, that's the reason I'm here," Kelly said, as her mother beamed approvingly.

LENGTH: 2486 words

HEADLINE: Street Fighter 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
DON'T you love it right after the rain?" Elizabeth Barlow Rogers asked, pointing delightedly at a pair of ducks as she walked through Central Park one misty morning. "Look! Mr. and Mrs. Mallard!"
 Ms. Rogers not only knows almost every inch of the park, but loves it as if she were its mother. Many are glad she does, crediting her with its revival under the care of the Central Park Conservancy, which she founded in 1980 and led until 1995. 
 At least that's what they tell her, and she finds the idea amusing. She knows her efforts have sometimes been met with skepticism. She remembers her first news conference as Central Park Administrator, a post she was appointed to in 1979. When she referred to "my park," a newspaper photographer interrupted her. 
"Lady," he said, "it's everybody's park."
Still, to a large extent it is her park, a reflection of her relentless drive to turn what had become a dusty, dangerous wasteland into an emerald miracle, the urban gem that Frederick Law Olmsted envisioned more than a century earlier. Though its work has been criticized, the conservancy became a national model for saving urban green space through the marriage of private and public money.
Ms. Rogers had hoped for similar success in her next project. In 1995, she founded Cityscape Institute, a group devoted to beautifying New York's sidewalks and street furniture: benches, telephone booths, trash cans, street lights, traffic signs and stoplights. She wanted to start with Central Park North, then infiltrate the city with classier pedestrian designs.
Her enemy, she said, was the "general indifference to the visual blight that has grown with the progressive coarsening of the environment as it has been allowed to become dominated by highway engineers and commercial interests."
More simply, she recalled the adage of her Texas mother: "Honey, looks matter."
But Cityscape has made only fitful progress in achieving its goal, as Ms. Rogers concedes. The institute and its founder have become mired in dozens of messy battles with city bureaucrats over designs for light poles, plans to reroute traffic and other issues. The one accomplishment may be on Central Park North where it abuts Central Park. The rebuilding of the street according to the institute's design began in mid-July, and is scheduled to be completed by the end of the year. But there are still many unresolved issues.
Ms. Rogers has recently taken on other projects. In April, she became head of a new postgraduate program on the cultural significance of landscape at the Bard Graduate Center for the Decorative Arts. Her new book, "Landscape Design: A Cultural and Architectural History," will be published by Harry N. Abrams this fall.
Yet the question is: Why has Ms. Rogers, who is lionized by city planners and whom Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern recently called "the woman who saved Central Park in the 20th century," been unable to work her magic on city streets?
 THE answers are not clear cut. Ms. Rogers says she has had little support from the Giuliani administration, saying that since she founded Cityscape, she has not once met with the mayor. She says most of her efforts have been lost in the haze of bureaucracy, as she has battled with one low-level official after another about minute matters.
But even those who admire her achievements raise concerns about her work with Cityscape.
"We applaud what Betsy's doing, but she has to understand the mandate various agencies have in protecting the public," said Iris Weinshall, the city's transportation commissioner, who says that in Ms. Rogers's zeal to beautify Central Park North, she has neglected practical matters like safety.
Others find fault with her aesthetics. On Central Park North, though Ms. Rogers's efforts are largely supported, some residents fear that she wants to turn the area into a theme park, criticizing Cityscape's plan to adorn light poles with portraits of famous Harlem personalities. One member of the Arts Commission, which regulates public art, called the design kitschy.
Others say beautifying sidewalks is different from rescuing Central Park. The park was a pre-existing feature of the city. The sidewalks have changed drastically over the years.
For one thing, there used to be more of them. Early in the last century, hundreds of miles of sidewalk were amputated to make way for traffic lanes. Greenery and other adornments became a frill in a world ruled by the automobile, and were removed. What sidewalks were left have become increasingly cluttered with traffic signs, trash cans and newspaper boxes.
Tony Hiss, a visiting scholar at the Taub Urban Research Institute at New York University, said few New Yorkers were old enough to remember when the city cared about how its sidewalks looked. "We've reached the point where we don't even know what we're missing," he said.
Another difference between the two projects is that Ms. Rogers had raised a substantial amount of money from New York's wealthy to save Central Park, an international symbol of the city, before she took on city government. So far, she has been unable to inspire the same generosity from private donors to beautify sidewalks.
"You can't equal the success she had in Central Park," said Raymond Gastil, director of the Van Alen Institute, which tries to improve public spaces. "You're not going to build a conservancy for every street."
Ms. Rogers, 65, is an unlikely savior of Central Park. Born into privilege in Texas, she grew up knowing which fork to use and she married well, twice. She lives a life of elegance, with an apartment on the Upper West Side and houses in the Hamptons and Santa Fe, N.M. She is sometimes criticized and admired for the same qualities. What some say is elitism and ambition, an attitude that only she knows what is best, others call drive and strength of purpose. Some remark on her attention to detail, but others view her as a crank, she said, obsessed with minutiae. 
Yet few dispute her credentials as a city planner or her devotion to her causes.
Ms. Rogers was born Elizabeth Browning in San Antonio, and fell in love with nature while chasing salamanders by the creek near her home. Her father was a general contractor.
Her family's plan was that she would go to a nice Eastern women's college for a couple of years, then return to the University of Texas, marry well and become a respected matron. She went to Wellesley College and discovered art history. One night she had an epiphany: "I don't have to go back to Texas!"
After graduation, she married her college sweetheart, Edward Barlow. He went to work at the Pentagon and his young wife busied herself with their baby, Lisa, and a writing course. She wrote about the importance of parks.
"It was like the blind finger of destiny was leading me along somehow," she said.
Her husband then went to Yale Law School and she got a master's degree in city planning. In 1964, they moved to New York and she volunteered with the Parks Association, a precursor of the Parks Council. She wrote a book, "The Forests and Wetlands of New York City," published in 1971.
Then, she fell in love with Olmsted and was curator of an exhibition on him at the Whitney Museum in 1972, the year her son, David, was born. The catalog she helped write was published as a book, "Frederick Law Olmsted's New York."
Ms. Rogers became seriously interested in Central Park. She volunteered with the Parks Department and joined the Central Park Task Force, which was organized in the mid-70's when the city could not afford to maintain its greatest park.
In 1979, the year she and Mr. Barlow were divorced, she became Central Park administrator. This was a new position, and she had to raise her own salary from private donations. But she got an office in the Parks Department's headquarters. It was a basement cubby next to the pesticides.
At the same time, she founded the conservancy to raise money for the park.
The early days were hard, especially since few people took seriously her dream of a revitalized Central Park. One of her ideas was to seek money for the park as if it were one of the city's cultural institutions, turning to New York's wealthiest companies and families, from Exxon to the Rockefellers. The symbol of the conservancy became the rich ladies in big hats at the springtime luncheon in the Conservatory Garden that Ms. Rogers dreamed up.
Another idea was to bring interns into the park, first to run children's programs and then do horticultural work. Unions seethed, but Ms. Rogers persisted. Today, conservancy employees outnumber civil servants, and the conservancy provides more than 80 percent of the park's operating budget.
In the next two decades, the conservancy raised $150 million. The park had other heroes, but few people dispute Ms. Rogers's achievements. 
Still, her work in the park has been criticized.
"The problem with a public-private partnership on this scale is that with every ingenious new mechanism, the city disinvested a little more," said Tom Fox, former president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, the precursor to the Hudson River Park Trust.
Others ridiculed some of her ideas: wanting to remove ball fields and cut down trees in the Ramble. But most praised her efforts.
"Betsy set the benchmark for what a park can look if properly maintained and managed," said Tupper W. Thomas, administrator of Prospect Park in Brooklyn.
The idea for Cityscape grew out of the conservancy's work in the northern part of the park. But it also had its roots in Ms. Rogers's increasing concern about the city's streets.
She said that she had become horrified at the ugliness of the streets, which she calls hardscapes, and sees as another form of landscape. She said she began to see people's indifference to the streets as a kind of visual illiteracy.
Referring to the great parks and avenues of Paris, she said, "We should make places out of public spaces."
Ms. Rogers was ready for a new challenge, anyway. "I don't want to be just Mrs. Central Park," she said.
IN 1992, the conservancy gave $1,000 to residents on Central Park North to clean up graffiti. By 1995, the conservancy got federal money to study Frederick Douglass Circle at the park's northwest corner.
A large design workshop was held, as were scores of meetings with neighbors. The outcome was a plan for a traffic rotary at the intersection and an array of improvements. Ms. Weinshall said the Transportation Department is studying the proposals.
Ms. Rogers began to wonder: Could the north edge of the park become a template for thousands of other blocks?
Because of her urban planning background, she knew how the streets used to look. Architects once designed street lamps to illuminate pedestrians, not vehicles. With the onslaught of the auto, engineers and the mass production of street lamps took over. Green patches on the streets were slowly eliminated. Even Park Avenue's park, which took up the middle of the street, was reduced to flower gardens. People got used to an increasing amount of street clutter.
Ms. Rogers asked questions like: Why do traffic signal poles have to be yellow? Why can't they be a tasteful black?
"Betsy has this crackpot idea that the life you find in the streets of the city doesn't have to be ugly," said Hugh Hardy, the architect whose work includes restorations of the New Victory and New Amsterdam Theaters and Radio City Music Hall.
Ms. Rogers pursued her vision with the panache that has become her hallmark. But she met with frustration at every turn. She imported mayors and experts from other cities to describe how they made their public spaces more beautiful. She took a group of city officials to Paris in 1997 -- on her own money -- to inspect the streets. They had "a swell trip," she said, but nothing tangible came of it.
City Hall encouraged her to develop a model stretch of sidewalk on West 55th Street, she said, then dropped the idea. She wanted to choose the design team for the new City Hall Park, and for new lights for Battery Park in Lower Manhattan, but never got permission to do so. She had a trash can designed, hoping it could become the new city standard. So far, the city plans to use it only on Central Park North and Battery Park.
Several spokeswomen for the mayor declined to comment on these proposals, saying that many of the people involved in the decisions had left the government.
Ms. Rogers said she also wanted to work on Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn and with business improvement districts in Manhattan. Again, she got nowhere.
About the best she can say of her efforts is, "Nobody said, 'Drop dead and get lost.' "
Daniel Biederman, president of the 34th Street Partnership and other business improvement groups, said people were so used to cluttered sidewalks it was hard to imagine a change. "There aren't huge numbers of people who understand this," he said.
Meanwhile, even when Ms. Rogers applauds what the city has done, like building the Duke Ellington memorial at the northeast corner of Central Park, she finds fault with the details. She asks why the metal fasteners that hold the base of the Elligton statue not hidden by granite? Why is Duke not facing north toward Harlem?
CITYSCAPE'S one apparent success is Central Park North, where its plan includes new signs for parking and other regulations, new streetlights and landscaping. The light fixtures, Ms. Rogers said, were designed to "complement the architecture of most historic neighborhoods and provide appropriate light levels for both pedestrians and motorists."
But in addition to the conflict with some residents, she has also argued with the Transportation Department.
Ms. Weinshall ordered that streetlights designed by Mr. Hardy pass safety tests before installation. Because the tests may not be completed before the mayor dedicates the new street, Ms. Weinshall plans to put up quaint-looking temporary lights. Ms. Rogers worries that they will become permanent, as temporary things often do. She would rather have utilitarian cobra lights to ensure temporary means temporary.
Ms. Weinshall said cobras were not what she had in mind for a mayoral dedication.
Ms. Rogers's supporters say it is too early to judge her work with Cityscape a failure, even as she prepares to devote more time to teaching and writing.
"She's accomplished more than she thinks," said Larry Condon, chairman of the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, which gave Cityscape $1.2 million.
Ms. Rogers said she understood that city government is "a big old lumbering dinosaur." She is patient and determined. Walking through Central Park, she pointed to one landscape feature that took a decade to accomplish, another that took 15 years.
"Being married to Betsy is like being married to a tank in creep gear," said her husband since 1984, Ted Rogers, a businessman who heads American Industrial Partners, a private investment firm. "You can barely see it moving, but before you know it, you've been run over."

Though she has turned her attention to city streets, she is still passionate about the park. (Photographs by Richard Perry/The New York Times, above and center); (Above, below right and left, Edward Keating/The New York Times; right and bottom, Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)(pg. 8) Chart: "IN HER OWN WORDS: Five Targets"Cityscape Institute was founded to combat what Betsy Barlow Rogers calls "the coarsening of the public environment." Here are a few examples of items found on city streets that Ms. Rogers thinks are particularly objectionable. "In the age of cell phones, our public telephones are a marginal public convenience; their chief purpose is to serve as sidewalk billboards, a source of advertising revenue." "Cobra-head lights such as are used on highways may illuminate the roadway, but they do little to make the night time sidewalk safer and friendlier for the pedestrian." "These flimsy litter receptacles get easily bent out of shape, and the bandage on the side with a usually illegible message admonishing the public not to litter is itself a bit of visual litter." "Promulgating park rules is important, but this should be done in a less messy and more verbally economical and graphically coherent manner." "In a city where there are already many newsstands, these bulky little curbside news boxes are redundant; they constitute both a pedestrian impediment and a visual eyesore." (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: New Economy, Same Harassment Problems 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN E. REED

 BODY:
ALMOST from the moment she started her new job as a software engineer at Juno Online Services Inc. in 1997, Lori Park had been intrigued by the tall and wiry Matthew Battles. After they met at a party, they wound up in a hip-grinding dance in the wee hours of the morning at Au Bar, a nightclub on East 58th Street in Manhattan. Over the next couple of weeks they ate meals together, went to museums and got to know each other.
 But the young man with the long blond hair was not only a friend and not just a colleague -- Mr. Battles was a senior vice-president of the company. As they decided how intimate they would become, the propriety of an executive dating an employee became an issue. 
 "He said if I don't get involved in a relationship with him he can be like my No. 1 fan in the company," said Ms. Park, recalling their conversation. "If I date him, then he won't be able to help me out at all." 
But in the insouciant world of Internet companies, where old economy conventions were disdained and rule books rejected, office romances and other corporate taboos flourished. The medium itself, the Internet, commingles the intensely private with the openly public, and this idea suffused the relationships that developed among high-technology workers. Many believed that they were building a new world, with new ways of doing things, and with that conviction came a sense that many of the old verities -- about management techniques as well as office protocol -- no longer applied.
But less than two years after Ms. Park began dating Mr. Battles, she sought redress from this new world and sued him, as well as her former supervisor, Mark A. Moraes, and Juno itself, for $10 million. It was one of the first publicized sexual harassment suits against an Internet company, and it shocked the industry because harassment, sex discrimination and retaliation were supposed to be diseases of the old economy. The new economy was supposed to be better for employees, but in some ways it turned out to be worse.
In her suit, filed in November 1999 in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Ms. Park alleged that Juno created a hostile work environment in which Mr. Battles and other male supervisors considered women to be "sexual objects," discussed which female employees they wanted to have sex with and referred to others with vulgar terms such as "slut" and "whore." 
Juno's lawyers denied these charges in a written response to Ms. Park's subsequent demand for arbitration. They also contended that Ms. Park herself routinely indulged in profanity and sexually charged language.
At the peak of the Internet boom early last year, disgruntled new economy workers rarely tried to settle differences through the courts. They simply quit and got a couple of job offers from other start-ups as they walked out the door. "People wanted to get on with their jobs, and in a red-hot economy they could," said Garry G. Mathiason, a partner with Littler Mendelson, an employment-law firm based in San Francisco with no stake in the case.
If a woman went to the trouble of hiring a lawyer to formally protest her treatment, said Mr. Mathiason, a check for $10,000 or $15,000 might have been issued, apologies made and the matter closed. But this year alone, Internet companies have already shed more than 80,000 jobs, according to the outplacement firm of Challenger, Gray & Christmas. As new jobs became harder to find, former employees began to couple claims of wrongful termination with unequal treatment, harassment and other charges.
Littler Mendelson, which has represented more than a thousand Internet-related businesses, estimates that two out five managers at such companies will be the targets of lawsuits in the coming years, twice the rate of the managers of bricks-and-mortar businesses, mainly because they didn't have the policies and procedures in place to handle employee complaints.
Although many Internet businesses tried to limit their liability by requiring workers to sign employment contracts agreeing to settle disputes through arbitration, some still wind up in protracted legal battles. In Ms. Park's case, the court compelled arbitration because she had signed such an agreement at Juno. But the suit nonetheless dogged the company for a third of its existence: from just after the company first sold its stock to the public in May 1999, to its recent announcement that it planned to merge with another Internet service provider, NetZero Inc. Juno would not say if settling the suit was a condition of the merger. 
THIS summer, the suit was finally settled for an undisclosed sum between $75,000, the figure offered by Juno, and $300,000, the amount demanded by Ms. Park before negotiations began.
Ms. Park's suit was "resolved without any admission of liability or concession by any of the parties," according to Terri Ross, a lawyer who represents Juno. Although none of the parties was allowed to comment on the case once settlement talks started, Ms. Park had earlier described her experience with the company and her relationship with Mr. Battles. Several interviews with her over the course of almost a year show how this young couple, who grew up with the values of the women's movement, came to be involved in charges of sexual harassment, and how Ms. Park was at the center of many forces -- management inexperience, a new old-boy network and rampant office intimacy -- that to one degree or another ravaged the Internet industry.
Ms. Park came to Juno at the end of 1997, lured by a salary of $70,000, a signing bonus of $25,000 and the promise of a year-end bonus of perhaps $20,000 -- all told, more than twice what she had been making as a software engineer for Sun Microsystems Inc. at its site in Chelmsford, Mass. At that time, Juno had been providing free e-mail to people without Internet access. She was hired to help write the server software needed to enroll paying customers in the company's new Internet-access service.
As part of the free-spending Internet culture, Juno put her up in what she described as "this really huge, nice apartment" on West 86th Street and Broadway in Manhattan while she looked for a place of her own. Less than two weeks after arriving, Ms. Park, who was then 23, celebrated her good fortune by throwing a party; among the guests was Peter D. Skopp, a Juno senior vice president who had interviewed her for the job. Mr. Skopp brought along Mr. Battles, who was then 24.
When the party broke up, Ms. Park and several guests went to Au Bar. She said she started dancing by herself and was joined by Mr. Battles, who began "dirty dancing" with her.
"I just stood back from him and I said, 'You are so bad,' " she said. "And he was like, 'No, you are so bad,' and I was like, 'No, you are so bad' and I said, 'You are a senior vice president' and then he like ran away." Mr. Battles, she said, left the club. Mr. Battles did not respond to requests for an interview. According to his Web site, he is currently in Mexico City studying Spanish.
Nonetheless, she continued to see Mr. Battles, and the two became romantically involved. There were half a dozen couples in the office, and the president and chief executive, Charles E. Ardai, dated and later married a woman who had worked there. Juno's corporate policy only prohibits managers from dating employees they supervise. Ms. Park, a programmer, never reported to Mr. Battles, who worked on the business side.
To understand how a consensual relationship wound up in a sexual harassment charge, it helps to know how Ms. Park viewed harassment. She said she thought Anita Hill was lying about sexual harassment during her testimony at the Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Clarence Thomas in 1991. Ms. Park was 17 then, and said she did not believe that sexual harassment existed. She said she had not experienced it growing up near Lansing, Mich., or later while studying at Harvard.
In fact, Ms. Park said she didn't think she had experienced sexual harassment at Juno until she read a sexual harassment complaint filed by a former Juno employee, Lisa Bongiorno. It was then, Ms. Park said, that she realized "the same thing had happened to me."
In August 1999, Lisa Bongiorno, a former marketing manager at Juno, filed a $10 million lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan against the company, claiming she was pressured into having sex with a vice president, Jordan S. Birnbaum, and then fired when she stopped sleeping with him. Juno said Mr. Birnbaum no longer worked there, and Mr. Ardai, the chief executive, declined to be interviewed for this article. But on the Web site of The Industry Standard, a magazine about the new economy, and in Glamour magazine, Mr. Ardai has been quoted denying this allegation. Neither Ms. Ross, the lawyer for Juno, nor Robert Levy, who represents Ms. Bongiorno, responded to requests for interviews. The case is in arbitration.
Reading the complaint's depiction of a hostile work environment and descriptions of retaliation educated Ms. Park about harassment. At the time, Ms. Park no longer worked at Juno and was negotiating a settlement with the company because she felt she had been forced out for "being a woman in a man's role," she said. 
Ms. Park's sexual harassment charge against Mr. Battles and the firm arose after a more protracted struggle she'd had with her former boss at the company, Bruce Zenel. Mr. Zenel managed a technical group of four, and then five programmers, of whom Ms. Park was the only woman.
She said that almost from the start he would look over her shoulder and tell her what keystrokes to make. "He would like try double-checking every little thing," said Ms. Park.
Ms. Park said she thought her work was more closely scrutinized than that of the male programmers. "I'm telling you, I never messed up," she said. As time went on, she said, Mr. Zenel stopped inviting her to meetings with the other programmers, and did not give her technical specifications on a timely basis, although she needed them to do her job. 
Mr. Zenel did not respond to requests for an interview. He has since been promoted to vice president at Juno. Lawyers for Juno, in their response to Ms. Park's charges filed with the American Arbitration Association, said she had "received supervision appropriate for a junior programmer with limited work experience," and acknowledged that she "was not included in some design meetings," and "was told that she did not have strong communication skills."
Mounting research on the failure of women to thrive at work indicates that they have good reason to be concerned about the kind of communication problems that Ms. Park experienced. 
In her book "Why So Slow? The Advancement of Women," Virginia Valian, a psychology and linguistics professor at Hunter College, wrote, "A woman who aspires to success needs to worry about being ignored; each time it happens she loses prestige and the people around her become less inclined to take her seriously."
SEEKING advice on how to resolve the problems with her supervisor, Ms. Park said she turned to Mr. Battles, who told her that the technical area preferred to resolve problems on its own, without involving other departments such as human resources. She then sought guidance from Mr. Skopp, the senior vice president who had hired her. But Mr. Skopp, she said, acknowledged that because he and Mr. Zenel were friends from graduate school at Columbia University, it was hard for him to be impartial. (Mr. Skopp did not respond to requests for interviews.)
As communications with Mr. Zenel deteriorated, Ms. Park said she sought help from Merrily Sturcke, the head of human resources. Initially, Ms. Park said she had resisted Ms. Sturcke's suggestions that Ms. Park meet directly with Mr. Zenel, fearing he might retaliate against her. But in December 1998, she agreed to participate in a meeting with Ms. Sturcke, Mr. Zenel and Mr. Moraes, who was Juno's executive vice president of technical services.
During the eight-hour meeting, when Ms. Park tried to argue that she was treated differently than the other members of the team because she was female, she said Mr. Moraes demanded to know, name by name, whom she was accusing of discrimination. Ms. Park was "harangued and abused" at the meeting, according to the complaint.
In their response to her arbitration demand, lawyers for Juno said there was frustration on both sides during the meeting because of Ms. Park's "continual refusal to accept that her role in the department was that of a junior programmer and her failure to accept responsibility for failing to follow the work directives of her supervisor." They also said that the human resources department and her managers investigated her "speculation" that the "complained-of treatment" might relate to her sex, but concluded that it did not and that "she received direction and compensation commensurate with her status as a junior programmer."
The length of the meeting shows how underdeveloped Juno's human resource procedures were, experts said.
"Anybody who is skilled in H. R. would tell you that any part of that kind of arrangement was dead wrong," said Mr. Mathiason, the Littler Mendelson lawyer whose firm represents employers. "Putting the two antagonists in a room, putting them there together for eight hours, just invites all kinds of claims." Such an arrangement, he said, could easily lead a judge or jury to conclude that the manager became angry at the employee for bringing the charge instead of patiently and dutifully conducting an investigation.
Such situations demonstrate the inexperience of young managers, said Kerry J. Sulkowicz, a psychiatrist and president of the Boswell Group, a consulting firm in Manhattan that often advises young entrepreneurs who are having difficulty managing their staffs. "Without understanding the tools of leadership, the managers adopt a very authoritarian style like the way adolescents, who are feeling very insecure, become bullies," he said.
At a meeting the day after that marathon meeting, where they were supposed to design a better way of working together, Ms. Park said Mr. Moraes yelled and snarled at her.
In its response to Ms. Park's demand for arbitration, a copy of which was made available to The New York Times, Juno rejected her characterization of this meeting, saying that she and Mr. Zenel, who also attended the meeting, had a constructive dialogue about how they would work together in the future.
By this time, another employee might have given up and left, but Ms. Park felt she had done nothing wrong, and saw the issue as one of equal opportunity. Her mother, Carol Park, encouraged all three of her daughters to take calculus in school because she herself had been afraid to take it. She gave Lori, the eldest, a halter-top that said "Anything boys can do, girls can do better." Lori Park said she became accustomed to competing in mathematics, mechanical engineering and computer science, areas traditionally dominated by men.
Following the December meetings, Ms. Park scored a 2.8 in her year-end review, lower than her midyear review of 3.0. "They made a special new category for me called "Relationship with Management" and I got a special low score on that. They said I was a technical superstar but I have such bad behavior problems," said Ms. Park, who interpreted the review as retaliation for her complaints. She requested a transfer out of Mr. Zenel's programming group and said she was demoted to the mail-server group. In the arbitration documents, Juno's lawyers denied that this was a demotion and said she received a negative performance review because "her difficulty interacting with her co-workers and her continual refusal to follow her manager's instructions was a drain on management resources."
Perhaps the Juno environment sent mixed signals about her expected contribution. By putting her up in an expensive apartment on the Upper West Side, casually attending her party and becoming very friendly with her, senior managers seemed to give the impression that she, a subordinate, was welcomed among the decision makers. While Juno officers, like those at many other Internet startups, sported the image of an egalitarian organization, Ms. Park saw it as a rigid, even club-like hierarchy.
HER ordeal strained Ms. Park's relationship with Mr. Battles because she said she increasingly saw him as part of the hierarchy that no longer wished to hear about her problems. "He thought they were treating me badly, but he didn't do anything about it, and it was his responsibility as a senior officer to do that even if it is his girlfriend," said Ms. Park.
Just after 1999 began, Ms. Park said she wanted to break up with Mr. Battles, but feared she would be fired if she did. The way Ms. Park saw it, women at Juno who ended relationships with co-workers -- who were often senior to the women -- had to leave. Mr. Battles' previous girlfriend had left the company, and there was Ms. Bongiorno, who had been fired.
When she asked Mr. Battles whether she would lose her job if they broke up, she said he told her, "You know you're not in the club like I am." She said she tried to meet with the human resources representative several times to tell her about her fears, but was not taken seriously. In its response to Ms. Park's charges, the company asserted that Ms. Battles "never influenced or sought to or threatened to influence Juno's personnel decisions concerning" Ms. Park, and that she never complained of sexual harassment. The couple broke up in the spring of 1999.
When Juno first sold shares to the public, the stock opened at $13 and fizzled to $11.64 at the close. That evening, staffers gathered to mark, if not celebrate, the event at Citron 47, a bistro on West 47th Street. Ms. Park said she asked Mr. Battles to leave the party and escort her to his apartment to retrieve some of her things. Outside the restaurant, she alleged in her lawsuit, he dragged her down the street, punched her in the stomach and slapped her. In its response to her demand for arbitration, Juno said that Ms. Park was intoxicated and had provoked the incident by "verbally and physically assaulting" Mr. Battles.
Ms. Park filed an assault complaint with the New York City Police Department, but did not press charges. When asked if there were any witnesses to the incident, Ms. Park said she was trying to find a waitress at the restaurant.
After the incident Ms. Park said she started taking the antidepressant Paxil, which had been prescribed by a psychiatrist she had been seeing, to reduce her anxiety. That spring, she said she lost 13 pounds.
Ms. Park's personal and professional worlds were wrapped up in Juno. When they unraveled, she again sought a solution to her problems from the firm. She said she met with Mr. Ardai, the chief executive, and told him she was being driven out of the company. She said they discussed giving her a year of severance pay if she would quit and Mr. Ardai asked her to have her lawyers get in touch with the company's lawyers. In a subsequent meeting with Mr. Ardai, she said she informed him of the alleged assault by Mr. Battles.
"He said that it wasn't clear that I should have told him and that it does not really relate to Juno," Ms. Park said. "I said I disagree."
Ms. Park said Juno offered her only $10,000, instead of the year's severance she had discussed with Mr. Ardai. She refused the offer and filed her suit.
Ms. Park said she first embraced the culture of Juno because it was filled with young people she thought she could trust. During her last interview with a reporter before settlement negotiations began, she said that she regretted getting involved with Mr. Battles, but was proud of her effort to stand up to the company. "If I don't stand up for myself," she asked, "who else will?"
Since her experience, Ms. Park said she had been informally counseling other young women who believed they had encountered harassment and discrimination at work on how to build a legal case against their employers.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Anonymous Interbrew Takes on the Kings of Beer

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER

DATELINE: BRUSSELS 

 BODY:
YOU might have expected beer connoisseurs to shudder when the family-owned brewer of Beck's, Germany's best-known export beer, agreed to sell it to an anonymous-sounding multinational corporation called Interbrew.
 In fact, it was the financial community that seemed most critical of the $1.58 billion acquisition announced last week, one of the most expensive purchases in the history of brewing. Knowledgeable beer enthusiasts appeared unruffled. 
 Interbrew has been unobtrusively amassing dozens of brands around the world for years, a strategy that has let it rival Heineken as the second-biggest brewer after the Anheuser-Busch Companies of the United States. And Interbrew likes to boast that drinkers have noticed no change in what they are drinking. Many are not even aware their brew is owned by somebody new. That may help explain why drinkers who quaff a Labatt, Rolling Rock, Bass, Dos Equis, Leffe or Hoegaarden, just to name a few, are sometimes surprised to learn they are patronizing Interbrew, which now produces beer in 19 countries and sells it in 110. 
Even beer drinkers in Interbrew's home market in Belgium are not fully aware of how many small local breweries are in fact owned by Interbrew. Some think Leffe, a popular beer whose label depicts an abbey, is brewed by monks. In fact it is made at a technologically advanced brewery in Interbrew's home town of Leuven, near Brussels. 
Similarly, some people in the business of selling regional beers are surprised to learn of Interbrew's scope. "We stock Interbrew beers like Leffe, Stella Artois, but I never looked at the company in a global sense," said Bobby Wong, beverage manager of the Wall Street Kitchen and Bar, a raucous restaurant in Manhattan's financial district that carries 50 beers on tap. 
Interbrew's corporate anonymity is part of the secret behind its rapid growth. The company describes itself as "the world's local brewer," and for the past 10 years it has been acquiring small breweries in eastern Europe, Russia, China, South Korea and Canada and turning them into market leaders or No. 2 brands in their local markets.
Just last month, Interbrew won an auction for the Bosnian government's 53.9 percent stake in the Banja Luka Brewery, owner of a brand called Nektar.
But with the Beck's purchase, Interbrew's 5th acquisition this year and 30th in the last decade, Interbrew faced tough questions by investors in the beer industry. Not only was the price expensive, they said, but Beck's could compete with Interbrew's flagship brand Stella Artois -- meaning Interbrew would essentially be competing against itself. 
Hugo Powell, Interbrew's chief executive, said Beck's 2.5 percent share of the fragmented German market was only a minor reason for Interbrew's purchase. "Our primary motivation for the deal was to acquire a world trademark," he said in an interview. "An opportunity like this won't come around again in the next five years." 
He said Beck's would not cannibalize sales of Stella Artois because their markets did not overlap. And to fend off criticism that he overpaid, Mr. Powell said that if Interbrew had not bought Beck's at that price, "another brewer would have." 
A Beck spokeswoman, Ulrike Gruenroch-Kern, confirmed that Anheuser-Busch, Scottish and Newcastle and South African Breweries had all competed against Interbrew for Beck, which had been family owned since 1873.
Beck's is "a brand that already has a high profile in the premium sector of the market, and that's where the real growth lies," Mr. Powell said. 
ADDING Beck's as a global brand, however, is only a part of Interbrew's growth strategy.
"We start with the premise that our local operations should be strong, and we maintain a high respect for local culture," Mr. Powell said. "Then we introduce our international brands and our local operations treat them as their own brands." 
In the United States, Beck's is the seventh-largest imported beer, while Stella Artois does not even make it into the top 10, according to the Association of Brewers, a trade group in Boulder, Colo.
Beck's strongest United States markets are the New York area, Florida and California. Mr. Powell said Interbrew will use Labatt USA for its sales force in the United States, to build the brand beyond these core markets. Beck's local strengths, he said, will help the other Interbrew brands.
None of Interbrew's beers sells as well as Heineken in the United States, but together, even without Beck's, Interbrew's range of brands dwarfs sales of Heineken's distinctive green bottles.
Heineken also has a cluster of specialty beers and a second mainstream brand, Amstel. But it has focused most of its marketing energies on promoting Heineken above all else. That strategy, to Mr. Powell's apparent irritation, appears to be winning more favor from investors.
"We will work hard to deepen investors' understanding of us as a corporation," Mr. Powell said, calling the company's operating performance "second to none."
The rivalry between Interbrew and Heineken has grown intense, and in fact both now claim to be the No. 2 global brewer. Tom Beyers, a beverage industry analyst at KBC Securities, a Brussels-based brokerage firm, said Interbrew would surpass Heineken in volume if Bass brands were included in its totals. Based on 2000 sales, however, Heineken is bigger: Its revenue last year was 8.1 billion euros or about $7 billion, compared with Interbrew's 5.7 billion euros.
Mr. Powell, not unexpectedly, called his company the better performer, pointing to the company's strong growth rates not only in beer volume but earnings. Interbrew's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, a common barometer of profitability in the industry, rose 59 percent in 2000 to 1.2 billion euros, after a 16 percent increase in 1999.
Yet Interbrew's stock, which was listed on the Euronext exchange last year, has fallen 13 percent percent from the initial public offering price of 33 euros a share.
Opinions vary over why. In addition to Interbrew's low corporate profile, analysts say too few of the shares are publicly traded -- 70 percent of the company remains in the hands of a holding company owned by a cluster of Belgium's richest families. 
The stock has weakened further as a result of Interbrew's prolonged effort to acquire Bass and, most recently, the Beck's deal. The stock has fallen about 5 percent since the Beck deal was announced, largely because Interbrew's price was 13 times Beck's earnings before interest and tax. Many analysts consider eight times earnings a more reasonable price.
To some degree, the price Interbrew paid reflected the competitive pressure on all big brewers to expand, which is reducing the total number of brewers and raising the price of those seen as the most attractive takeover candidates.
Alex Genart, an analyst with the Belgian brokerage Petercam, who downgraded his rating of Interbrew stock to neutral after the Beck's deal, called Interbrew "a victim of asset inflation, which is being fueled by consolidation in the industry."
Mr. Powell agreed. "Other brewers are acquiring, too," he said. "We know this because most situations are auctions between a small group of big brewers." Germany, Europe's largest and most fragmented beer market, with about 1,200 breweries, is in the throes of consolidation.
"People who say consolidation is still a long way off in Germany are wrong," Mr. Powell said, adding that he has had "many phone calls, many conversations" with German brewers that might become takeover targets. "The Beck's acquisition will only accelerate the process, and we hope for further opportunities there," he said.
So how come such as acquisitive corporation is not seen as the evil multinational parent by lovers of local beers? "We see Interbrew as the least worst option," said Iain Loe, research manager at the Campaign for Real Ale, a Britain-based advocacy group fighting against what it considers the trend toward homogeneity in beers.
"We oppose consolidation in the business, and there is no question that Interbrew has become a very dominant player in the U.K. as well as in its home market," Mr. Loe said. But to its credit, he said, the Belgian brewer, which traces its roots to a Leuven brewery called Den Hoorn founded in 1366, "has retained the diversity in beer styles, and it remains a pure brewer, unlike many of the other brewing majors that have diversified into other activities."
LAST year, British competition authorities blocked Interbrew's acquisition of Bass Brewers because of fears that Interbrew would come to dominate the British beer market. Interbrew successfully appealed that decision in the British courts. Although Interbrew will likely have to sell some properties of Bass, regulators have not yet specified which ones.
Mr. Powell said the Beck acquisition was unlikely to arouse regulatory opposition in Europe or the United States. "Consolidation of regional and national beers still has some way to go," he said. 
But at some point, he said, the takeovers will diminish, and "there could be one or two mergers among the big groups."

HEADLINE: The World: First Things Last; 
Argentina and the Aid Next-Door

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO 

 BODY:
WITH Argentina's economy in meltdown and Brazil's straining under growing market pressure, the Bush administration is now facing its first full-fledged international economic crisis. Thus far, it has acted with so much reluctance, hesitancy and awkwardness that it risks leaving both countries more vulnerable than ever.
 The International Monetary Fund on Aug. 3 offered Brazil a $15 billion credit line but told Argentina no new money was coming. The "reward Brazil, punish Argentina" approach, prompted by mixed signals from the United States, the fund's main contributor, has perplexed Latin American analysts. 
 "The Fire Department has been called into South America, but instead of attacking the source of the conflagration, they've gone to the apartment on the next floor and given the people there a fire extinguisher," Gustavo Franco, an ex-president of Brazil's Central Bank, said. "By ignoring the blaze on the floor below, they're allowing it to worsen, which is going to make it all the more difficult and expensive to put the fire out."
Mr. Bush and his team came to the White House with reservations about the role of the monetary fund and the notion of bailouts. That is a sharp contrast with the Clinton administration, which worked with the fund to design emergency rescue packages for Mexico in 1994 and for Brazil in 1999. 
This time, the United States and the fund seem to have decided that Brazil, the world's eighth largest economy, cannot be allowed to founder. But Argentina is seen as far less conscientious, and far less important. (That isn't new: Henry A. Kissinger is said to have once dismissed Argentina as "a dagger pointed at the heart of Antarctica.") 
Initially, the Bush administration appeared determined to keep its distance from the mess in Buenos Aires altogether. In mid-July, Condoleezza Rice, the White House's national security adviser, said that no new assistance was in the works for Argentina. And another administration official argued: "This is a problem the Argentines can resolve, and they are taking the right steps to do so. They have a plan, it's a workable plan, and now they have to cut spending and put policies into place that will attract investment. Nobody can do those things for them."
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, though, was telling a more damaging story to investors. With an extraordinarily blunt assessment of Argentina's troubles most remarkable, his Latin American critics say, for its lack of sympathy and knowledge, he has helped torpedo investors' interest.
"They've been off and on in trouble for 70 years or more," Mr. O'Neill said in the British magazine The Economist. "They don't have any export industry to speak of at all. And they like it that way. Nobody forced them to be what they are."
Argentina's supporters have counterattacked, noting that the United States, for all its talk of free trade in the Americas, continues to placate domestic lobbies with high tariffs on many Argentine products. 
But there is also a feeling of political betrayal. No Latin American country's foreign policy has been more aligned with that of the United States over the past decade than Argentina's. The country participated in the Gulf War and has even been designated a "non-NATO ally."
As a candidate and at a hemispheric summit meeting in April, Mr. Bush vowed to make the region a top foreign policy priority, saying that the days of American neglect of Latin America were over. 
But his inaction suggests otherwise. "Whether in Latin America or the Middle East, the instinct of this administration is to back away any time there is a crisis," said Michael Shifter, a fellow at the Inter-American Dialogue, a research group in Washington. "The initial attitude is 'we don't want to become involved -- it's messy, it's complicated.' Then things deteriorate further, and they end up in a worse situation." 
THE administration's tone may have begun to shift slightly. Former President Clinton visited Argentina and Brazil on a lecture tour last month and called the White House to express his concerns. Earlier this month, Treasury Undersecretary John Taylor was dispatched to Buenos Aires, and said he was "impressed" with Argentina's determination. But he also said he could not offer any new money.
To Wall Street, which former Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has accused of "dancing on Argentina's grave," the waffling seems to say that the Bush team still does not recognize the gravity of the situation. And that only feeds market nervousness about the rest of Latin America. 
EVEN with the $15 billion in "armor plating" that the monetary fund has offered as a morale booster, Brazil's credit outlook was lowered from stable to negative last week, and its currency, which has declined in value by 25 percent against the dollar this year, gained back no ground. In Chile, which has openedits economy wider and faster than any country in Latin America, the peso sank to a record low.
The betting here is that Argentina's troubles will eventually force the fund to step in. An Argentine delegation arrived in Washington on Friday to urge the fund to act, but the fear is that any aid may come too late, not only for Argentina but also for Brazil.
"At the moment, the Bush administration doesn't have a policy and lacks the political will to put the money that is needed on the table," said Mr. Franco, the former bank chief. "Without those two things in tandem, I don't see a solution. We're thankful here in Brazil for the $15 billion we've been offered, but it doesn't resolve anything."

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
It's Not the Heat, It's the Economy

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The record heat that smothered the Northeast last week was not the problem on Wall Street. Stock market investors had a different worry -- the health of the economy in general and technology issues in particular. 
 Downgrades of Intel and other semiconductor makers led to selling through much of the week that pushed the Nasdaq composite index to end a week below 2,000 for the first time since April 12. The uncertainty spread to other technology companies including Oracle and Siebel Systems. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 96.53 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,416.25. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 109.86 points, or 5.3 percent, to 1,956.47. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 24.19 points, or 2 percent, to 1,190.16. 
 New evidence of economic weakness, notably an unexpected decline in industrial commodity prices to the lowest level in 15 years, raised expectations that the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee would cut interest rates again at its Aug. 21 meeting to stimulate the economy. 
 The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, a barometer of interest rate trends, fell to 4.98 percent from 5.16 the week before. ROBERT HURTADO

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
First-Half Bond Fever Cools

BYLINE:  By Jeff Sommer

 BODY:
Spurred on by lower interest rates, United States corporations have already issued more investment-grade debt this year than in all of 2000, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. 
 The total for 2000 was $353 billion, itself a record, according to Thomson. 
For the year through Aug. 6, the total was $364.5 billion, the agency said. 
 The torrid pace of debt issuance this year came as the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates by a total of 2.75 points, reducing borrowing costs for corporations and adding to investors' return. 
Debt issuance appears to be slowing down, though, several analysts said. Corporations have already refinanced much of their expensive short-term debt, Salomon Smith Barney said in a report last week. Mergers and acquisitions, which generally trigger the issuance of debt, are proceeding slowly, the report said. Salomon expects debt issuance to drop by about 40 percent in the second half of the year, and Moody's says the drop-off is likely to be 35 to 40 percent. Capital expenditures by American businesses have declined, and companies appear to be adopting more conservative financial practices, both factors that tend to reduce corporate borrowing, according to Moody's.
To be investment-grade, bonds must be rated at least Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- by Standard & Poor's and Fitch. Jeff Sommer

HEADLINE: Repricing Stock Options 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re the Market Watch column, "Dispelling the Myth That Options Help Shareholders" (July 29), which challenged the assumption that repricing stock options helps retain valuable executives: 
 Companies that reprice their stock options do so for one reason -- the options are under water and now have lost their ability to motivate and retain valuable employees. 
In general, this happens when a company or industry has experienced problems with its business. This could be due to many factors such as a recession, poor industry conditions or poor management.
Shareholders should object to the repricing of options if the stock price has fallen due to poor management but not if the problems are a result of a recession, stock market drop or poor industry conditions.

J. BRITT HUGHES
Stratford, Conn., July 30

PERSON: James A. Corbett 

HEADLINE: James A. Corbett, 67, Is Dead; A Champion of Movement to Safeguard Illegal Refugees 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
James A. Corbett, a rancher and Harvard-educated philosopher who helped start a movement to guide Central American refugees illegally across the United States border, died on Aug. 2 at his home in the Arizona desert, about 30 miles from Benson. He was 67.
 The cause was a rare brain disease, paraneopalpic cerebellar syndrome, his wife, Patricia, said. 
 Mr. Corbett's crusade to help the illegal immigrants, most of them from El Salvador and Guatemala, came to be called the sanctuary movement. Its adherents believed that the Central Americans streaming to the United States to escape political oppression were equivalent to slaves escaping their masters in the years preceding the Civil War, and likened their effort, which involved hundreds of churches, to the Underground Railroad. 
"After the Second World War, the U.S. government bound itself by law never again to expel or return refugees to any country in which they would face persecution," Mr. Corbett wrote in an essay in 1988. "Consequently, our transporting of refugees is not an act of civil disobedience."
But prosecutors insisted that the Central Americans were economic refugees, not political ones. In a trial in 1986, in which Mr. Corbett was one of 11 people charged with breaking immigration laws, Judge Earl H. Carroll said, "Good motive is not a defense to intentional acts of crime."
Mr. Corbett and two others were found not guilty on all charges. Six of the defendants were convicted of conspiracy and two of lesser charges. They were sentenced to probation. 
"The work of sanctuary will continue exactly as it has," Mr. Corbett said immediately after the verdict. "We'll stand trial as often as we have to. It'll continue as it has because the refugees and their needs actually set the agenda."
As the Central American refugees dwindled, the sanctuary movement gradually faded. 
James Albert Corbett was born on Oct. 8, 1933, in Casper, Wyo., a descendant of Blackfoot Indians, Kentucky pioneers and Ozark Mountain mule traders. 
His father had given up a law practice in Missouri and gone to Wyoming to teach in high school. His mother brought in extra money by substitute teaching. In the summer they moved to an Indian reservation, where they kept food on the table by foraging for berries and fishing for trout.
Mr. Corbett won a scholarship to Colgate University and graduated in three years. He went to Harvard on a Woodrow Wilson fellowship and completed a master's degree in philosophy in a year. He married and took his wife to live on a Wyoming ranch. She did not like ranch life, and they divorced after a few years of marriage and three children.
He joined his parents at a ranch they had bought near Tombstone, Ariz., hoping to recover from his marital breakup and the first signs of the arthritis that would eventually almost cripple him. He decided to study library science at the University of Southern California.
There, he met Patricia Collins, married her, and moved to Douglas, Ariz., where Mr. Corbett was head librarian and a philosophy instructor at Cochise Junior College.
When college officials censored a book on an instructor's reading list and a work by a visiting artist, he notified the American Civil Liberties Union. His contract was not renewed.
Mr. Corbett took several teaching jobs in California, became a Quaker in the early 1960's and organized efforts against the Vietnam War. He then returned to Arizona to ranch and work on projects like the development of a bee hive and goat husbandry techniques for use in poor countries. 
By 1977, his arthritis had worsened, and the couple moved to Tucson, near where a fence had been built to deter illegal border crossings. At first, Mr. Corbett had no interest in immigration issues.
"I took the fence for granted and had never been particularly interested in border problems," he wrote in an essay in 1988. "The only time I had ever gone over the fence was to stop a grass fire in Mexico."
But on May 4, 1981, he heard about a Salvadoran refugee who had been caught by the Border Patrol. Mr. Corbett found the refugee in jail in Nogales, Ariz., then followed him to an immigration detention center in California, where he said he discovered hundreds more Central Americans who had fled wars and persecution in their home countries.
Mr. Corbett was soon housing two dozen refugees in his home. Fluent in Spanish, he would sometimes lead groups from the Guatemalan border all the way to Arizona. He mailed 500 letters to Quaker groups throughout the United States, asking for their help.
Mr. Corbett realized his home and his finances could not accommodate the flood of Central Americans. He went to John M. Fife III, pastor of the Southside Presbyterian Church in Tucson, who agreed to harbor refugees and helped organize a system for passing illegal immigrants from church to church across the country.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Corbett is survived by his daughters, Laurie Longtin and Megan Schaefer, both of Casper; his son, Geoffrey Corbett of Buffalo, Wyo.; and three grandchildren.
In recent years, Mr. Corbett devoted himself to providing simple housing for those seeking solitary retreats in the Arizona desert. He was also active in the Saguaro Juniper Corporation, a group of property owners and leasers in southeastern Arizona interested in wildlife protection and other environmental concerns.
He and his friends had been discussing the possibility of a new sanctuary movement for Haitian refugees, Ms. Corbett said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Aug. 12 about James A. Corbett, a founder of the sanctuary movement for Central American refugees, misspelled the name of his illness. It was para neoplastic cerebellar syndrome, not paraneopalpic.

HEADLINE: All Aboard, Vladivostok! A Dream Is Growing 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory Aug. 10 

 BODY:
The motorman of a tourist trolley near the Klondike-era train depot here dreams of a day when passengers and freight roll out of this old rail terminus destined for such places as Fairbanks, Shanghai and London. 
 "If the Panama Canal was physically feasible, this one would be a snap," said Mike LaForet, of the century-old dream to link Asia and North America by steel rail. "With the Soviet breakup, the Americans and the Russians are not enemies, they are customers." 
 Although the narrow-gauge gold rush line, the White Pass & Yukon Route, stopped running here from the Pacific Coast in 1982, railroading is again the talk of northern North America. 
This week, a proposal to build 900 miles of track linking Canada and Alaska was debated in Calgary at a two-day meeting attended by business and political leaders from Alaska and western Canada. The meeting built on a bill, the Rails to Resources Act, signed into law in December by President Clinton. The bill authorized spending $6 million to study the creation of a northern rail link and called for establishing a binational commission to study establishing a line from northern British Columbia to Fairbanks. 
"The rail link was very enthusiastically received here in Calgary," Jeannette James, an Alaskan State Representative, said by telephone today after the two days of talks. Now, Ms. James said, the idea is winning new momentum as engineers discuss using a railroad right of way to bury part of a natural gas pipeline that oil companies plan to run from Alaska to Alberta, tapping the gas reserves of the Prudhoe Bay region.
In Calgary this week economic development officials said that joining Yukon and Alaska with southern Canada and the lower 48 states would cut prices of goods sold in the north and would also open up certain mineral and energy deposits for development.
With railroad talk turning serious in this old rail town, conversation turns to what people here call "the second stage": drilling a tunnel below the Bering Strait to link Alaska and Russia by rail. The Yukon's lone member of Parliament and a backer of a Yukon-Alaska link, Larry Bagnell, cautioned against loose talk about a Russia link, saying, "It would get the guys who are against the railroad to Alaska to say you are dreaming in Technicolor." 
But with Canadian newspapers publishing maps showing how a rail link could arc from British Columbia to Siberia, railroad people in Russia and North America are seriously mulling the idea.
On the Russian side, Viktor Razbegin, director of the state-run Center for Regional Transport Projects in Moscow, has endorsed the proposal in several interviews. Mr. Razbegin estimates that a Russia-North America rail link would cut trans-Pacific shipping times by up to two weeks and could carry 30 billion tons of cargo a year. He has estimated that the overall cost, including a tunnel under the Bering Strait, would cost $50 billion. On the Russian side, 2,000 miles of track would have to be laid from the Baikal-Amur Railroad to the Bering Strait. On the Alaskan side, about 750 miles of track would have to be laid from the strait to Fairbanks. 
Overall, Russia's government increasingly sees its continental land mass as a lucrative transportation corridor. 
In February, Russia embarked on a liberalized over-flight policy, hoping to garner $300 million annually by 2010 in fees for commercial jets on transpolar routes between North America and Asia. In addition, Russia is promoting a summertime shortcut for ships through the Arctic that links the Barents Sea with the Bering Strait. 
On the Alaskan side, caution is the official watchword.
"Linking Asia and North America by a transportation route under the Bering Strait has tremendous appeal, but there is no infrastructure linking either side," said Robert King, spokesman for Alaska's governor, Tony Knowles, a Democrat. Recalling a visit to the Trans-Siberian Pacific terminus in Vladivostok, Mr. Knowles added, "One can sense the allure to such a link, but it's a lot of track to lay between Vladivostok and British Columbia."
