HEADLINE: Outlooks Vary at Europe Ad Companies 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
Two large European advertising companies reported first-half results today that offered starkly different views of the sharp downturn in ad spending.
 The Cordiant Communications Group of Britain, whose clients include Heineken and Hyundai, said there were few signs that ad spending would soon recover as the slowdown in North America spread to Europe and Asia. 
 By contrast, the Publicis Groupe, the French company that created a campaign to introduce the euro, offered a more bullish outlook, saying that ad spending could pick up late this year. 
Analysts tended to take Cordiant's more cautious view of an industry that has been bludgeoned by a steep decline in spending.
"We're not seeing any turnaround yet," said Neil Blackley, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "We don't expect to see year-over-year growth until the second quarter of 2002."
Some analysts noted that Cordiant, in offering a more bearish outlook, might be trying to regain credibility after previously setting targets that were too aggressive. Cordiant had originally forecast 5 percent revenue growth this year. In June, it advised analysts to lower their estimates, and it said today that it expected revenue for all of 2001 to be flat. Excluding acquisitions, revenue grew 0.2 percent in the first six months of the year, to $:209 million ($298 million).
Cordiant, which owns Bates Worldwide in the United States, also said it would take a $14.3 million charge this year to cover the elimination of hundreds of jobs.
"We're telling it how it is," said Michael Bungey, Cordiant's chief executive. "There is no upturn as far as we can see this year, and there is increasing evidence of softness in Europe."
Helping insulate Publicis is an aggressive push for new business; United Airlines and VoiceStream are among its new clients. So far this year, Publicis lags only the WPP Group in net new billing dollars, according to Credit Suisse First Boston.
For the first six months of the year, Publicis reported $1.3 billion in net new business, compared with $300 million at Cordiant.
Moreover, Cordiant has greater exposure to some volatile markets in the Asia-Pacific region. It is, for example, the leading agency company in Australia, a market that has had a severe downturn the last year. 
Publicis, by contrast, derives less than 10 percent of its revenue from the region. The company, which owns Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide among other agencies, said that billings, excluding the effect of acquisitions, grew 6.3 percent, to 7.5 billion euros ($6.7 billion), in the first six months of the year, outpacing the 2 percent average growth for the industry. Billings include the total amount of money spent by clients; revenue is only the portion of billings directly attributable to the agency.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Delusions of Prosperity

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; Thomas L. Friedman is on vacation.

 BODY:
Three years ago, after the collapse of Long Term Capital Management, U.S. financial markets were in crisis. For a few weeks it looked as if the economy would succumb to panic, to self-fulfilling pessimism. Then the Fed surprised the markets by cutting rates without waiting for its next scheduled meeting. Confidence was quickly restored, and Alan Greenspan was promoted to demigod status. 
 But it has been more than seven months since Mr. Greenspan tried to work his magic a second time, again surprising the markets with an inter-meeting cut. Since then he has cut again and again. Yet the Fed's latest survey of the economy offers few signs that a turnaround is imminent. 
 This slowdown, it turns out, is different. We are not in the midst of a financial panic, and recovery isn't simply a matter of restoring confidence. Indeed, excessive confidence may be part of the problem. Instead of being the victims of self-fulfilling pessimism, we may be suffering from self-defeating optimism.
 The driving force behind the current slowdown is a plunge in business investment. It now seems clear that over the last few years businesses spent too much on equipment and software, and that they will be cautious about further spending until their excess capacity has been worked off. And the Fed cannot do much to change their minds, since equipment spending is not particularly sensitive to interest rates. 
 Still, as former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers says, you don't have to refill a flat tire through the puncture. To reflate the economy, the Fed doesn't have to restore business investment; any kind of increase in demand will do. 
 How might demand increase? Consumers, who already have low savings and high debt, probably can't contribute much. But housing, which is highly sensitive to interest rates, could help lead a recovery. Even more important would be a turnaround in the U.S. trade balance. America's deficit has lately been running at 4.5 percent of G.D.P., three percentage points higher than it was as recently as 1997. Reversing that trend -- which would mean both exporting more and buying domestic instead of imported goods -- could deliver a big boost to the economy.
 But there has been a peculiar disconnect between Fed policy and the financial variables that affect housing and trade. Housing demand depends on long-term rather than short-term interest rates -- and though the Fed has cut short rates from 6.5 to 3.75 percent since the beginning of the year, the 10-year rate is slightly higher than it was on Jan. 1. The trade balance depends on the value of the dollar -- and the dollar, which usually falls when the Fed loosens monetary policy, has actually risen over the past seven months. 
 There are, I would argue, three reasons that the dollar and long-term interest rates have not moved in the right direction. First, for what it's worth, Bush administration officials have been saying all the wrong things. I don't know if anyone in the financial markets still takes Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill seriously, but his extravagant statements on behalf of a strong dollar -- he recently declared that if he changed his mind on the subject, he would hire Yankee Stadium and a brass band to announce it -- are the opposite of helpful.
 Second, the Bush tax cut -- which offers only small tax cuts in the near future but promises much bigger cuts in the more distant future -- is exactly the kind of fiscal policy that you would expect to drive up long-term interest rates and have a depressing effect on the economy. 
 Most important, however, is the way both long-term interest rates and the dollar have been sustained by investor optimism -- by the belief that Mr. Greenspan can do again what he did in 1998. This belief deters investors from buying long-term bonds, because they expect interest rates to rise again; it induces investors to keep buying dollars, because they are still bullish on America. And so optimism, paradoxically, helps keep the bad times rolling.
 Sooner or later, of course, investors will realize that 2001 isn't 1998. When they do, mortgage rates and the dollar will come way down, and the conditions for a recovery led by housing and exports will be in place. But for the time being delusions of an instant return to prosperity stand in the way of a real economic turnaround.

HEADLINE: From Alberta, Energy's Good Guy (And Bad Guy); 
The Premier Is Happy To Supply U.S., but Insists On Key Role in Decisions

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: CALGARY, Alberta 

 BODY:
The oil industry here was still in its infancy when Ralph Klein was growing up. So instead of working on oil rigs, as many young Calgary men do nowadays, he spent time laying concrete sidewalks with his father, Phil, a part-time masonry contractor who also wrestled on the professional circuit under the name "Killer Klein."
 "Sometimes he was the good guy," Mr. Klein said of his father's wrestling persona, "but usually he was the heel." 
 Now that the younger Mr. Klein is the premier of Alberta, Canada's leading energy-producing province -- a chunk of mountains, prairies and forests larger than France that holds vast amounts of oil and natural gas -- he spends a fair amount of time visiting the oil rigs that have become the symbol of Alberta's economic success. And like his father, he has developed dual identities, at least when it comes to exploitation of the province's natural resources. 
Usually, he seems to be one of the good guys, the friendly fellow with cowboy boots and a big grin who dropped out of high school but went on to become premier. That was the face he wore when he recently visited Washington and told Vice President Dick Cheney that Alberta was ready to sell as much energy as the United States wants to buy. He then invited Mr. Cheney to fish the Bow River.
Although Mr. Cheney has not yet decided whether to cast a line in the Bow, Washington welcomed Mr. Klein because his willingness to deal fits well with President Bush's plan for a continental energy policy aimed at reducing dependence on oil from outside North America.
But when he needs to, Mr. Klein, 59, is ready to play the heel. He has made clear that he will try to block future energy deals with the United States if Alberta's interests are not taken sufficiently into account. And he has the power to do so.
Canada's Constitution makes Mr. Klein a kingpin of Canadian energy. Provinces, not the federal government in Ottawa, control most natural resources. And Alberta has most of Canada's energy resources.
"We would intervene," Mr. Klein said in an interview. For instance, he said, he wants any natural gas pipeline from Alaska that passes through his province to give local refineries the chance to strip away some byproducts used to make petrochemicals. That may be, he acknowledged, "a self-serving interest," but it is one on which he would not give an inch.
In recent years, Canada's energy wealth has been spread around a bit. Atlantic provinces have started producing offshore oil; a natural gas pipeline has been built from Sable Island off Nova Scotia to Massachusetts, and demand is rising for electricity from Quebec's dams.
But Alberta remains the mother lode of Canadian power. The province produced 65 percent of Canada's crude oil, 80 percent of its natural gas and 100 percent of its bitumen, a usable oil made from Alberta's inland sea of oil sands -- the largest such deposits in the world.
In some respects, Alberta is already the equivalent of a North American energy sheikdom. The province supplies more than 900,000 barrels of oil to the United States every day, and sends 2.4 trillion cubic feet of natural gas a year across the border, some of it going as far as Brooklyn.
Mr. Klein, as Alberta's leader, has been eager to keep open the valves that allow energy to flow across the border to the United States.
But if he disagrees with decisions made elsewhere, he could become one of the biggest roadblocks to Canada's participation in a continental energy policy. He recognizes the right of the Canadian government to sign international agreements, he says, but insists that Alberta and the other provinces be closely involved in negotiations from the beginning.
"Not including the provinces would be like Joe and Peter talking about selling Ralph's house without Ralph's involvement," Mr. Klein remarked.
Canadian officials -- used to wrestling with the provinces over jurisdictional matters -- have so far been careful but firm in responding to Mr. Klein's demands for a seat at the energy-policy negotiating table.
"When it comes to representing Canada in any international forum, obviously that is the responsibility of the government of Canada," said Ralph Goodale, the federal minister of natural resources, "and we will discharge that responsibility on behalf of all Canadians." Mr. Klein's anxiety about being excluded from the negotiating table is misplaced, he said, because at this time there is no table.
"There is no continental energy policy as such," Mr. Goodale said. "What we're pursuing is an expansion and the proper functioning of the North American energy markets."
Whatever the effort is called, the United States is intent on securing further stable sources of energy to help ease potential shortages like the one that disrupted California early this year. A task force led by Vice President Cheney concluded that one of the best ways to enhance the United States' energy security is to increase the flow of oil, natural gas and electricity from Mexico and Canada, partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement that already provide a significant portion of American energy needs.
Canada was the United States' largest source of foreign oil last year, providing 15 percent of imports. Mexico, which provided roughly 12 percent, was not far behind the second- and third-leading suppliers, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela.
In natural gas, Canada -- and Alberta -- dominate. The United States imports about 15 percent of the natural gas it uses, and most of that comes from Alberta.
Mr. Klein, of course, is not the only public official involved in pursuing a continentwide energy policy. After meeting in April, President Bush, President Vicente Fox of Mexico and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada agreed to form a North American Energy Working Group, made up of senior officials from each country.
The group convened for the first time in Washington at the end of June and set an agenda for a number of issues including pipeline construction, cross-border power regulation and research into new technologies.
Of all those involved, few will occupy a more prominent position than Mr. Klein. Yet, unlike Mr. Cheney and Mr. Bush, who have worked extensively in the energy industries, most of what Mr. Klein learned about energy comes from his time in office and before that as a local television and radio reporter.
"It's impossible to be in the news business here without knowing something about the oil industry," he said.
After 11 years as a popular local television personality, known to haunt Calgary night spots and show up late for work, Mr. Klein ran successfully for mayor of his hometown. He was re-elected twice, in 1983 and 1986, and played host to the 1988 Winter Olympic Games here.
In 1989 he moved to the provincial legislature, and became Alberta's environment minister. His style of governing is often described as laid-back, and voters seem to find it easy to identify with him. In 1992 he was elected leader of the provincial wing of the Progressive Conservative Party, and later in the year was sworn in as premier of Alberta.
He has been re-elected twice; in fact he has never lost an election. Mr. Klein is now Canada's senior province leader, and one of the country's most popular politicians.
In his approach toward government and public spending, Mr. Klein is considered a close cousin to fiscal conservatives in the United States. He was the first of Canada's province leaders to successfully attack government spending, whittling down the deficit and reducing taxes. Alberta is the only province without a local sales tax, and its personal income taxes are the lowest in Canada.
"He understands this province very well, and he knows what works and what doesn't work in politics," said David Bercuson, a professor of political science at the University of Calgary. "Ralph has the knack of listening to people."
For instance, when an energy-deregulation bill took effect early this year and prices spiked, Mr. Klein pushed a $4 billion rebate through the legislature to cover the added costs and then some. The rebates helped a number of Albertans avoid paying anything for energy this past winter.
Not everyone was pleased. "Investing $4 billion in energy efficiency initiatives would have been a better use of the money than dishing out checks," said Robert G. Hornung, policy director of the Pembina Institute, an environmental research center in Alberta. "But there was a provincial election this spring, and the two events were unquestionably related."
Mr. Klein's budget-roping skills owe plenty to the energy boom in Alberta. Rising prices for oil and natural gas have produced a flood of revenue.
And recently, American oil companies have scooped up Albertan producers, taking advantage of the weakened Canadian dollar to secure a position in the further development of Canada's energy resources, as was the case with the $4 billion purchase by Conoco of Gulf Canada.
"There's no question that the industry is pleased with the direction the Alberta government has traveled," said Brian C. Dutton, an oil and gas analyst with UBS Warburg in Toronto. 
Of Canada's 10 provinces, Alberta is in many ways the most like parts of the United States. In attitude and approach to business and to taxes, Alberta has more in common with Texas than with neighboring Saskatchewan.
"The oil industry quite frankly wouldn't have evolved and wouldn't be where it is today, had it not been for American companies," Mr. Klein said. "When you go to the Calgary Petroleum Club, you think you're in Texas."
The continued influx of Americans into Calgary has even forced the Petroleum Club's general manager, R. J. Thomas, to relax the dress code, allowing open-neck shirts all week instead of just on Fridays. The club recently added a stage and Las Vegas lighting to the upper-floor dining room.
"It's the big look, American-style," Mr. Thomas said.
Mr. Klein's attitudes are a far cry from the National Energy Program of the 1970's (when Mr. Chretien was Canada's energy minister and tried to keep American hands off Canadian energy.)
Nobody in Ottawa is now thinking of reviving the National Energy Program, but federal officials are wary of wildcat provincial leaders. They are also sensitive to efforts to overhaul the regulatory process on Canada's side of the border in any way that appears to undermine Canadian sovereignty. And all plans to expand Canada's energy exports will be reviewed by environmentalists.
Mr. Klein's name is regularly heard as a potential leader of the national Progressive Conservative Party, but he says he is happy to remain in Alberta.
And while his predecessors have sometimes been called "blue-eyed sheiks," Mr. Klein said he preferred to avoid any of the obvious nicknames.
The Sultan of Oil Sands? The Prairie Potentate?
"Call me Ralph," said "Killer" Klein's plain-speaking son. "Just Ralph."

HEADLINE: Russians Resist Rumsfeld Effort To Set Aside ABM Treaty 

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld met President Vladimir V. Putin and his defense minister today for talks that threw into sharp relief the disagreements over whether to deploy missile defenses, how to slash nuclear arsenals and whether arms control talks can even be the tool to bridge their differences.
 It was a day when Mr. Putin spoke of negotiations and Mr. Rumsfeld spoke of consultations to create a new relationship in which treaties are unnecessary. 
 When Defense Minister Sergei B. Ivanov said any missile defense deployment would have to be tightly linked to reducing warheads, Mr. Rumsfeld only agreed that the two issues were related.
"We still think that the ABM treaty is one of the major important elements of the complex of international treaties on which the international stability is based," Mr. Ivanov said.
Later, Mr. Rumsfeld urged again that "the Antiballistic Missile Treaty be set aside, and new arrangements between our two countries be established, so that we will in fact be able to take steps to no longer be vulnerable to handfuls of ballistic missiles."
But in welcoming Mr. Rumsfeld to the Kremlin, Mr. Putin said that the treaty was unequivocably a part of the security relationship between the two countries and that it was bundled with current treaties that limit nuclear arsenals. "For us, it is unconditionally linked with both the Start II and Start I Treaties," he said, referring to strategic arms reduction treaties negotiated between Washington and Moscow. "I would like to underline that."
If the two countries are to move forward in their talks, Mr. Putin said, Russia requires specifics on proposed levels of offensive weapons, a timetable for cuts, understandings on verification and transparency and confidence-building. In essence, Mr. Putin was demanding detailed and formal negotiations. 
Mr. Rumsfeld demurred. Afterward, he said, "With respect to how these discussions and consultations will evolve, I think that's an open question." The absence of cold war hostilities simply makes arms talks unnecessary, he added.
President Bush, after meeting Mr. Putin last month in Genoa, ordered his national security team to begin consulting with Russia on missile defenses and reducing arsenals. The president envisions a framework of relations that would dispose of treaties and seek to bind the United States and Russia more broadly and more loosely through trade and economic and military ties.
A senior Pentagon official said, "The dialogue is proceeding as we expected it would." Mr. Rumsfeld stressed that he would not discuss specific proposals for shrinking the offensive arsenal because a strategic Pentagon review will be completed "in the next month or two." Asked to describe the direction the study would push the arsenal, Mr. Rumsfeld said, "There is no doubt in my mind that we'll be able to go down to substantially lower numbers." 
Mr. Rumsfeld also said the United States could not possibly brief the Russians on its exact plan because it is in initial research, development and testing. The tentative schedule for testing is widely expected to violate ABM limits by late next spring.
Mr. Rumsfeld's mission was to illustrate the administration's broader approach to security ties with the Russians, and he trumpeted the virtue of investment.

HEADLINE: Bush Says He Will Veto Any Bill Broadening His Stem Cell Policy 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would veto any legislation that tried to push federal support for embryonic stem cell research beyond the parameters he has specified, which confine public financing to stem cell "lines," or self-sustaining colonies, already derived from embryos.
 Mr. Bush said his speech on the issue last week, in which he opposed government financing of research on any additional stem cells and the further destruction of embryos that extracting them would entail, outlined "what I think is right for America, and any piece of legislation that undermines what I think is right will be vetoed." 
 "I spent a lot of time on the subject," Mr. Bush added as he spoke to reporters after a ceremony on his ranch for the signing of legislation giving agricultural businesses and farmers $5.5 billion in additional federal aid this year. "I laid out the policy I think is right for America. And I'm not going to change my mind." 
Since Mr. Bush announced his decision, in a television address on Thursday night, it has been questioned by advocates on both sides of the issue.
Opponents of any federal support for the research, including many social conservatives, have said that Mr. Bush must not go a millimeter further than he already has, and his words today offered them reassurance, which may prove unnecessary. Although a bill in the Senate would allow federal financing for the extraction of more stem cell lines from frozen embryos that are to be discarded, such legislation is unlikely to gather momentum this year. Research supporters, in Congress and among patients' advocacy groups, say they want to see if scientists find the existing stem cell lines sufficient before mounting any new campaign.
But many lawmakers and scientists hope that Mr. Bush might take a broader approach in the future than he has so far. In his speech, he articulated such strong sympathy for the view that frozen embryos be used that it seemed, until the end of his remarks, that he might endorse it.
Administration officials have said over the last several days, however, that Mr. Bush meant to close off that possibility, and his own comments today were an emphatic confirmation.
They also amounted to a pledge that, in the opinion of many scientists, he may ultimately be tempted to break. If the research on stem cells progresses quickly enough, then it is possible that by 2004, when he would be running for re-election, discoveries based on private research using newly derived embryonic stem cells could lead to clinical trials of new therapies. And Mr. Bush could find himself in an uncomfortable position if he refused to let federally supported scientists participate in those studies.
"People have got all kinds of opinions," Mr. Bush acknowledged today, later adding: "Understand that there's a moral issue -- moral issue, plus there's a chance that we can save people's lives. And I've laid out the path to do that."
As Mr. Bush signed the farm legislation today, and mused yet again about the meaning of his month away from the White House, he repeatedly spoke of the American heartland and the "values" it represented. That word, which he used at least a dozen times, is music to many social conservatives' ears.
"We want our families to be on the farms and ranch," Mr. Bush said from a podium set up amid the 1,600 acres of his property. "After all, farm families represent the best of America. They represent the values that have made this country unique and different -- values of love and family, values of respect for nature."
Before he spoke, country music blared from speakers as an audience of more than 40 Texas farmers and their families sat on stacks of hay and watched Mr. Bush drive toward the podium in a white pickup truck. He emerged in an outfit of brown boots, blue jeans and a green open-collar shirt.
The bill he signed provides $5.5 billion for agricultural businesses and farmers beyond the regular appropriation for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. 
"It's necessary," Mr. Bush said, asserting that agriculture was "part of our national security mix," because not producing enough domestic food for Americans would "complicate our foreign policy."
But what Mr. Bush was providing with a stroke of his pen was $2 billion less than Democrats had wanted. It was also less additional aid than Congress had appropriated and President Bill Clinton had approved in each of the last three years.
Administration officials said it was nonetheless sufficient, citing increases in livestock and crop prices in recent months that eased what had been a crisis for many farmers.
Mr. Bush has billed his monthlong hiatus from Washington as a journey "home to the heartland." His activities and remarks here, as well as those planned for a trip he will take to Colorado and New Mexico in coming days, consistently allude to what he casts as solid, steadfast American values.
All of that is intended to turn a month away from Washington into a continuing political statement. 
"To me, to be out on the land helps a president keep perspective," Mr. Bush said today. "You know, I haven't been a president all that long, but I can assure you, perspective is important."
Mr. Bush's plentiful oratorical gumbo of "heartland" and "values" references has at times forced him and his aides to answer questions about whether they are extolling some regions of the country over others.
"Washington is a great town," Mr. Bush said. But, he added, "the strength of the country is in our heartland."
Then, seemingly backpedaling a bit, he said, "There's a lot of people, wonderful people, that live on the coast of the country."
As the president mingled several times with reporters today, he also said he was monitoring various world events from his ranch. Asked about Argentina's economic woes, he said that administration officials were holding meetings about it "every single day" and that his administration's message to the government there was that it must "implement the reforms that recently passed through their legislature."
He also applauded the signing today of a political settlement in Macedonia. In fact, he mentioned it at first as a way of changing the topic of discussion from stem cell research, which he indicated that he had, for now, said everything about that he cared or planned to say.

HEADLINE: Remembering a Tax Cut, And Revisiting a Debate 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: GOLETA, Calif., Aug. 13 

 BODY:
On a fogbound summer morning 20 years ago today, at a simple leather-topped table outside his mountain ranch house here, Ronald Reagan signed the landmark package of tax and budget reductions that he hoped would be a centerpiece of his administration and a cornerstone of his White House legacy.
 Today, on a cloudless California afternoon, with checks from the biggest federal tax cut since Mr. Reagan's landing in mailboxes nationwide, his son Michael and a few dozen fellow keepers of the flame came here to celebrate what the younger Mr. Reagan, in a live broadcast of his nationally syndicated radio talk show, called "the largest tax cut in the history of mankind." 
 "Because Ronald Reagan did this in 1981, you're able to get your tax cuts today," Michael Reagan, 56, said in a brief ceremony before the broadcast on the lawn of Rancho del Cielo, his father's beloved ranch in the sky. "Because somebody followed up in the future, G. W. Bush."
Politicians debate the costs and benefits of President Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut, with Republicans and Democrats worrying about the ways in which it will force curbs on spending for their pet projects from missile defense to health care.
And partisans of both camps have never stopped debating the effects of Mr. Reagan's 1981 tax cut, and the deficits it helped spawn when promised spending cuts failed to materialize.
The Young America's Foundation, the conservative group that bought the Reagan ranch three years ago to use in its mission of inspiring conservative values in college students nationwide, sponsored today's events, and left little doubt about its view. It issued handouts crediting the Reagan tax cut with prompting the economic boom of the past 20 years and with creating so much new wealth that, when the cold war ended, a windfall in tax revenues turned budget deficits to surpluses.
"We feel this is where Ronald Reagan's ideas came to life, and this was the most important day here," said Floyd G. Brown, the foundation's executive director and a former Republican political operative best known for creating the Willie Horton television commercial used against Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 presidential campaign. "That's why we bring young people up here to keep his ideas alive."
Mr. Reagan's first guest on his radio program today, former Representative Jack Kemp, the legislative author of the tax bill, telephoned from a meeting in Aspen, Colo., to praise the current tax cut as fine, as far as it goes. But he noted that it was to be phased in over 10 years and that, "I think we should have cut capital gains taxes in half."
For their part, Democrats are quick to note that by as early as 1982, President Reagan himself was forced to ask Congress for a tax increase to help offset what could have been disastrous budget consequences, and subsequent tax increases under George Bush and Bill Clinton undid most if not all of the rest.
Now, as they have for most of the past 50 years, total federal, state and local taxes stand at more than a quarter of the gross national product, a reality that the Reagan cuts only briefly dented.
But marginal income tax rates remain capped at 40 percent, well below their past highs, and there is little support in either party for raising them.
"Without putting too much emphasis on '81, one thing that did come through was an emphasis on lower rates as the primary way to improve the efficiency of the tax system," said C. Eugene Steurele, who was a top tax policy official in the Reagan Treasury Department and is now a senior fellow at the Urban Institute in Washington. "The push toward lower rates in exchange for a broader base was a relative improvement."
Economists may debate the relative size of the Reagan and Bush tax cuts, with some contending Mr. Reagan's was much bigger and others arguing they were about the same, but historians may have little trouble deciding who had the better ranch. Mr. Bush's spread is 1,200 acres near dry and dusty Crawford, Tex. But Mr. Reagan's 688 acres here are lush, shaded by glens of live oaks, with mountain and ocean vistas sweeping away from every bend in the road.
For Michael Reagan, whose 90-year-old father is confined to his home in Bel Air in Los Angeles by Alzheimer's disease, today was bittersweet.
It was his first broadcast since the death of his older sister, Maureen, of cancer last week, and he choked up at one point in recalling that it was she who "made me a Reagan," by urging her parents, Ronald Reagan and his first wife, the actress Jane Wyman, to adopt a boy.
It was also only his second visit to the ranch, the scene of family Thanksgiving dinners, since his stepmother, Nancy Reagan, decided to sell it.
"For such a long period of time, I just didn't want to come up here," Mr. Reagan said in an interview before the broadcast in the enclosed porch of the ranch house, surrounded by the family's furniture, his father's Secret Service baseball cap, and many memories. "I was really hurt when it got sold. I was actually ticked off, because I just thought it was one of those things that would stay in the family for generations. So I stopped coming."
Then Mr. Brown, who himself once was a host on a conservative talk show in Seattle, persuaded Mr. Reagan to come take a look at the Young America's Foundation's preservation efforts, and Mr. Reagan said, "When I see it, I see Dad."
Some 100 college students nationwide, along with local Republican supporters, paid their own way to come to today's ceremonies and were shuttled up a winding 7-mile mountain road that leads from the Pacific Ocean to tour the simple white stucco ranch house, the oldest part of which was built in 1872. Mr. Reagan remodeled it extensively himself, laying paving stones and building wooden corrals and fences.
"You have to come out and see it to see how he actually lived," said Sean Clark, 21, a senior political science major who came with his friend Justin Wade, 22, an engineering major. Both said most of their fellow students and their professors "hate" Mr. Reagan, and both can barely remember his presidency, but they have come to admire him by comparison with current leaders.
"He was somebody you could look at and say, 'Wow, he's our president,' " Mr. Clark said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 16, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about a ceremony at Ronald Reagan's former ranch to commemorate the 20th anniversary of his tax and budget reductions misstated the size of President Bush's ranch in a comparison. The Bush ranch is about 1,600 acres, not 1,200.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
At a Hip New Hotel, Food to Write Home About

BYLINE:  By William Grimes 

 BODY:
SOME chefs are highly imaginative but can't quite seem to make their dreams come true on the plate. Others have a firm grasp of the fundamentals but don't have any brilliant ideas. (Type 2 is twice as valuable as Type 1.) Then there are the chefs, like Rick Laakkonen at Ilo, who seem to be effortlessly inventive but solidly grounded in the fundamentals of flavor, texture and harmony. No matter how wild his flights of fancy, they wind up seeming natural, even inevitable. Everything works in an understandable way. Ilo, a Finnish word meaning something like "bliss," is in a hotel. This, too, seems both natural and inevitable these days. New York's buoyant economy has translated into a hotel boom, which in turn has translated into a new generation of hotel restaurants that have redefined the category. As recently as a decade ago, a hotel restaurant was staid, formal and luxurious. It served French food to an elderly clientele. 
 The new boutique hotels and sharp entrepreneurs like Ian Schrager have changed the rules. To make an impression, a new hotel in Manhattan must be designed to the hilt. If downtown, it must transmit a supermodel vibe. Supermodels don't actually have to show up, but it is vital that the hotel's design suggest in every possible way that they might. There must be a slouchy lounge and bar. And there must be a serious restaurant on the ground floor. There is simply no other way. 
 A restaurant like Town, Olives, Thom or DB adds allure to a hotel. The hotel, if the right people stay there, adds allure to the restaurant. This may be a rare instance of genuine synergy. Whatever you call it, it has changed the face of dining in New York.
Ilo, in the Bryant Park Hotel, follows the script. Two sidewalk planters with long twigs bundled tightly into cubes strike a contemporary note of high-design desolation. A lounge scattered with low-slung settees and served by a small bar draws a dedicated afterwork crowd of an indeterminate age -- not too young, not too old. The transition from lounge to restaurant is minimal. Six stone steps run the breadth of the lounge. Ascend them, and you are in Ilo. It's as uneventful as walking from the living room into the dining room in a private home.
Ilo does not hit you over the head with its intentions. But there's an early tipoff. The restaurant pours a 1990 Pommery Champagne by the glass from a magnum bottle. This extravagant gesture, pure indulgence, sets the tone. The giggles and whoops from the lounge say "funny-colored martini." The soft pop of a Champagne cork in the restaurant, and tiny, civilized bubbles, says something very different.
Mr. Laakkonen, who cooked most recently at the River Cafe, and before that at Luxe and Petrossian, creates complex dishes that seem simple. He knows how to coax pure flavors from his ingredients, and how to keep those flavors clear and distinct. The traffic never gets snarled. Major ingredients bask in the spotlight. The busy supporting cast contributes a witty remark here, a colorful phrase there, but the actors manage not to step on each other's toes. Artichoke soup, despite an arresting bird's nest of sliced mushrooms and truffles in the center of the bowl, and cloudlike puffs of the soft Sicilian cheese called serro, remains deeply, profoundly, essence of artichoke. Grilled quail, as meaty and tender as any in recent memory, stand out heroically from their busy tableau, where a feather-light cheese flan is surrounded by spicy minced peppers, chilies, coriander and lime.
Mr. Laakkonen loves odd ingredients. His "tidal pool" may simply be an excuse to use percebes or goose barnacles, a tube-shaped Spanish delicacy, with a texture like octopus, which shares bowl space with Olympia oysters, sea urchin, wakame seaweed, and silver ear and wood ear mushrooms. A stunning broth, poured at the table, poaches the oysters and sea urchins. The pool, it turns out, is a teeming seafood fantasy, with each pristine tidbit afloat on a little ocean.
Ilo's rabbit shows that a dish can be rustic and rarefied at the same time. The rabbit is done country style, pan-roasted with olives and accented with oregano and preserved lemon. The slick addition here is cannelloni stuffed with sheep's milk ricotta that's flecked with bits of bitter dandelion. Every ingredient in the dish is as humble as a wooden shoe. The orchestration makes it perfectly at home on a white tablecloth. Sea scallops, seared to a crisp and then surrounded by artichokes, morels and pearl onions, are thoughtfully served with chewy chickpea pappardelle that are ideal for the mopping-up phase.
I often flinch at tasting menus, since everyone at the table eats the same thing, a critic's nightmare. But I made an exception when I saw the special beef menu at Ilo, and I was richly rewarded. The portions are mercifully calibrated to a normal appetite, and I was relieved to see the beef feast begin with a small but eye-catching terrine of oxtail wrapped in ribbons of beef tongue and topped with a concentrated beef gelee. Pickled green tomatoes and pearl onions made a tart, refreshing relish. When a steaming casserole of tripe arrived, thickened with black chickpeas and spicy chunks of chipolata in a fino sherry sauce, I was solidly behind Mr. Laakkonen on the beef question. And I thanked him silently for choosing a chilled apricot soup for dessert.
The soup is a regular on the dessert menu. It is a blazing slick of yellow, punctuated by a bright red stack of cherry sorbet disks topped with an orange tuile. Patrick Coston, who did the desserts at Mercer Kitchen, has a taste for bright, tart flavors, and he gives it full license in a multipart citrus showcase, intended for two diners, that includes blood-orange granite, warm orange cake, lemon layer cake and vanilla-lime parfait. I'm not sure that anyone needs quite that much citrus, although the components, taken individually, score high on the pleasure scale. Still, halfway through the plate, I began hankering after the almond and butterscotch gateau, glazed with caramel, and the strawberry and passion fruit tart, with its sweet pool of pistachio anglaise.
Ilo's cheese cart is a serious, well-organized but not overwhelming affair with some unusual, even quirky cheeses. One of the surprises is maccagnette alle noci, a flat, circular, walnut-crusted cheese from Lombardy that tastes a lot like salami. The wine list, as the Pommery might suggest, is well thought out, and the sommelier, Kim Anderson, presents it in an unusually informative and ingratiating way. She has opinions, and she doesn't waffle around when asked for them. It's worth waving her over, because the 250 or so wines on the list include many unusual grapes (gagliopo and negroamaro come to mind) and lesser known regions. Where, exactly, do you find a Cotes du Marmandais? Madeira needs a missionary, and it has one in Ms. Anderson, who is happy to pour an 1834 malvasia or a 1795 terrantez.
Manhattan has always specialized in culture shock. The new hotel culture may be the most powerful signal yet devised to tell visitors they have come to a different place. The restaurant off the lobby is no longer the place you avoid. It's the place you can't get into.

Ilo
***
Rating: Three Stars
40 West 40th Street, Bryant Park Hotel; (212) 642-2255

ATMOSPHERE: Inventive modern American and global cuisine served in a cool, modern hotel dining room.
SOUND LEVEL: Medium to medium-loud, depending on the crowd in the lounge.
RECOMMENDED DISHES: Artichoke soup with mushrooms, "tidal pool" seafood in broth, grilled quail with cheese flan, rabbit with cannelloni stuffed with dandelion and sheep's milk ricotta, scallops with artichokes and chickpea pappardelle, beef tasting menu (tongue and oxtail terrine, tripe stew with chipolata, roast marrow bone, grilled ribeye), chilled apricot soup, citrus tasting for two.
SERVICE: Very professional without being stuffy.
WINE LIST: An appealing, well-thought-out international list of about 250 wines, with attention paid to up-and-coming regions and varietals.
PRICE RANGE: Lunch, appetizers $8 to $16; entrees $19 to $29; desserts $10 to $22 (for two). Dinner, appetizers, $10 to $18; entrees $26 to $38; desserts, $9 to $22 (for two); beef tasting menu, $85 ($120 with wines); seven-course vegetarian tasting menu, $65; eight-course chef's tasting menu, $110 ($165 with wines).
HOURS: Lunch, Monday through Friday, noon to 2:30 p.m. Dinner, Monday through Saturday, 5:30 to 11:30 p.m.; Sunday, 5 to 10 p.m.
CREDIT CARDS: All major cards.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS: Six steps up from lounge to dining room; there is an elevator to the right of the staircase. Restrooms are down one flight, or by the lobby elevator.

HEADLINE: Japan Tries to Grease Economy Again 

BYLINE:  By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan said today that it would further loosen credit in an economy in which short-term financing can already be raised at virtually no cost.
 The move stunned analysts and investors, who expected the bank's governor, Masaru Hayami, and its policy board to continue resisting calls by politicians and others for looser money. The announcement came after a two-day meeting of the policy board. 
 To inject liquidity into the financial system and help fight deflation, the bank said it would step up its purchases of government bonds 50 percent, to 600 billion yen ($4.9 billion) a month. And it will increase the target amount of cash to be kept on deposit with it by the nation's commercial banks 20 percent, to 6 trillion yen ($49 billion). This money is reinvested in the short-term money markets. 
Both steps were taken to expand the money supply and the ability of financial institutions to lend and invest. They were the first by the central bank since March, when, somewhat reluctantly, the policy board reduced short-term interest rates essentially to zero and also increased the target for banks' deposits with it. Mr. Hayami had repeatedly said that those steps were adequate.
But evidence of deterioration in the economy has been accumulating, as are signs that the global economic slowdown is taking a toll in Japan, leading many economists here to conclude that an eventual loosening was inevitable. Few, however, expected it now. 
Speaking at a news conference, Mr. Hayami noted that Japan's production was falling, corporate earnings were dropping and capital investment was waning. Economic softness in the United States is likely to linger for a while, he said, while credit deterioration and worries about the soundness of Japan's big banks have beaten down bank stocks.
"One cannot help but think that the downside risks to the economy are becoming a reality," Mr. Hayami said, summing up the policy board's reasoning. "We judged that we are now in a phase that requires additional easing measures." 
Because Mr. Hayami had consistently said that new measures by the bank were unnecessary, most analysts expected no change in bank policy before autumn.
The surprise announcement sent stocks soaring, with the Nikkei 225-stock index rising 440.39 points, or nearly 4 percent, to 11,917.95.
But analysts doubted the moves would have any long-term effect on the markets beyond the shock value of a day or two.
Atsushi Mizuno, chief economist at Deutsche Securities in Tokyo, said the timing of the meeting had played a role in the decision. The board, which usually gathers every other week, had no more meetings scheduled until mid-September. "That," he said, "made the risk of waiting even greater."
But he, too, wondered how much practical impact would come from trying to pump money into the economy through the banks.
"Banks are writing off bad loans and lending less, so total lending is declining," he said. "The central bank is boosting lending to those who do not need money. The excess money has been flowing into government bonds." 
Mr. Hayami said he also was uncertain of the impact of today's moves.
"I don't know to what extent the measure will stimulate companies, generate greater demand and raise prices," he said. "But for the moment, this is all we can do."
Mr. Hayami denied that the board had given in to government pressure. But analysts said they detected a whiff of political compromise in his remarks.
Though there is no room left for interest rate reductions to help the situation, Mr. Hayami said the bank-reserve target could be raised further if necessary. 
But he ruled out setting an inflation target, a policy both politicians and investors have called for.
"Inflation targeting is something you do when you have inflation," he said. "I have never heard of it being carried out during times of deflation."
Perhaps more to the point, analysts said, Mr. Hayami wants the central bank to avoid being held hostage to too many numerical goals.

HEADLINE: School Vouchers Along the Color Line 

BYLINE:  By David A. Bositis; David A. Bositis is senior political analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a group that researches issues involving black Americans.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
For the past 10 years, African-Americans have been caught up in the school-voucher debate. Many black parents have become desperate for solutions to the problems of their children's schools. Vouchers are one solution being offered, and many black parents have grasped at them. But this is less an endorsement of vouchers than an indication of how bad some schools have become.
 Each year between 1996 and 2000, I conducted parallel national surveys of African-Americans and the rest of the population on education issues, including school vouchers. More African-Americans supported school vouchers than opposed them, and blacks consistently supported them more than whites did. In October 2000, 57 percent of blacks supported vouchers but only 49 percent of whites did. 
 But it seems clear that black support for vouchers is mainly a rejection of the status quo -- that is, poorly performing schools and students -- rather than an endorsement of this particular reform. Surveys by the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies over the past five years showed the dissatisfaction. Only 38 percent of blacks rated their local public schools as excellent or good, while 23 percent rated them as poor and the balance considered them fair. The 1998 survey also included a number of questions on the financial aspects of school vouchers, and the responses clearly indicated that many respondents had no concrete idea what a voucher program might look like.
There are other twists to this interesting story. Three-quarters of African-Americans younger than 35 supported vouchers, as did 62 percent of those between 35 and 50. However, blacks older than 50 oppose vouchers by 48 percent to 44 percent. Politically this is important, because older people are far more likely to vote than are younger people. And because most African-Americans are reluctant to vote for Republicans, Democrats who oppose vouchers may not risk losing many black votes as a result.
Whites have a somewhat different take on vouchers, though their generational differences about vouchers are similar to those of blacks. Older whites don't like the idea -- they are even more hostile to vouchers than are older blacks. In my most recent survey, 52 percent of whites over 50 opposed vouchers while 41 percent supported them.
But white suburbanites bring a very different perspective to the voucher debate. They like their local public schools. Over the past five years, the surveys I have conducted found 57 percent of whites rating their local public schools as excellent or good, while only 14 percent rated them as poor. While a plurality of whites (49 percent) favor school vouchers, that support is based more on partisanship and ideology than on a rejection of the education status quo.
So younger African-Americans support vouchers, and people over 50 -- white and black -- as well as white suburbanites are generally cool to them. With that juxtaposition, if you were to call Las Vegas for the line on this issue, I don't think there would be much question about the odds. And whenever school vouchers have appeared as a ballot issue, the public has said no.
Virtually all black leaders oppose school vouchers. Conservatives often suggest that these leaders are out of touch with the black public. That is certainly not true if you limit the black public to those who tend to vote, an older group.
It is also said that black leaders are in thrall to teachers' unions. However, I think concern about unions is a comparatively small part of their opposition. If white conservatives are pushing school vouchers, then black leaders are generally going to be suspicious. In their view, white conservatives, traditionally, have cared so little about the lives of black Americans that when they do manifest concern the black reaction should be to look for a hidden agenda.
Many white Southerners, for example, withdrew their children from public schools in reaction to desegregation. Many black leaders -- and older blacks who can recall the era of massive white resistance to desegregation -- believe school vouchers would represent a transfer of public money to subsidize those white parents who prefer that their children attend all-white schools.
However, as this generation passes, it is possible to imagine further growth in black support for school vouchers. The kind of thorough reform that would improve public schools -- for black children and everyone else -- still lacks real momentum and, with state budgets in distress, the necessary money. Politicians appealing to middle-aged and younger black voters might find vouchers a good way to promise change without having to find much money to pay for it. They might also attract white voters for the same reason -- with the additional, if unstated, appeal of school reform without integration.
Many white Americans today seem to be comfortable with segregation in schools (and elsewhere), though a line is drawn at intentional or explicit discrimination. Vouchers may be well suited to reinforcing this pattern. Older white conservatives and African-Americans, with their longer memories, can perhaps imagine this prospect more easily; but it would be younger Americans who would have to live with it. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES; 
U.S. Trade Deficit Worries I.M.F.

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund said today that the United States' broad trade deficit, the current account, was unsustainable and could put the dollar's value at some risk.
 In an annual assessment of the American economy, the I.M.F. did not reach a conclusion about its direction, saying that the outlook was uncertain and depended on several factors. 
 "Directors indicated that the size of the U.S. current account deficit did not appear sustainable in the longer term," the report said, "and that it raised concerns that the dollar might be at risk for a sharp depreciation, particularly if productivity proved disappointing." 
The current account is the broadest gauge of trade in goods and services, and reflects the reliance of the United States on inflows of money from abroad. It has been running at more than 4 percent of the gross domestic product for the last few years, a level some specialists say cannot be sustained. Despite the economic slowdown, the deficit has not substantially decreased.
On the currency markets, the dollar dropped against the yen and the euro today after the report was released. In New York, the euro settled at 90.23 cents, up from 89.79 cents on Monday. The yen strengthened to a rate of 121.74 to the dollar, from 122.48 late Monday.
"In the current environment, where the dollar is on the defensive," said Bob Lynch of BNP Paribas in New York, "they did catch the market a little off guard, and ended up weighing on the dollar." 
The I.M.F. report, without making forecasts, said that productivity and confidence in the consumer and business sectors were the keys to the future of the United States economy. 
It added that although evidence suggested a favorable outlook for productivity, a less optimistic outcome could pose a "significant challenge" for American policy. Business productivity rebounded in the second quarter, up 2.5 percent.
The I.M.F. said it welcomed the flexible policy stance that American authorities had taken, in particular the Federal Reserve's aggressive easing of interest rates. It said this easing might have to be continued if the economic data remained weak.

HEADLINE: S. L. Wolfbein, 85, a Manpower Expert 

 BODY:
Dr. Seymour L. Wolfbein, a federal economist and authority on employment, died on Aug. 7 in a nursing home in Potomac, Md. 
He was 85 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.
 Dr. Wolfbein joined the Department of Labor in Washington in 1942 and left it in 1967 for teaching. For years he was the department's senior specialist on manpower and spoke for the department on manpower trends. 
 He was chief of manpower and employment in the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics and later director of the department's Office of Manpower, Automation and Training. He was appointed to that post in 1962.
After leaving the Labor Department, he was dean of the Temple University business school and taught there. He held educational posts in Japan and Austria and lectured widely. He was also a consultant to business executives in the United States.
His many writings include the book "Manpower Policy: Perspectives and Prospects" (1973).
Born in Brooklyn, he graduated from Brooklyn College and received a doctorate from Columbia University. 
Surviving are his wife of 60 years, Mae; two daughters, Susan Morris of Washington and Deeva Garel of Bethesda, Md.; and four grandsons.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall a Bit, Despite Home Depot's Strong Earnings

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated slightly yesterday as an upbeat earnings report from the home improvement retailer Home Depot failed to erase concerns over the flagging economy.
 "Pragmatically, the best thing you can do is sit on your hands," said Donna Van Vlack, director of trading at Brandywine Asset Management, which oversees $7 billion. "There is just nothing compelling out there." 
 Better-than-expected retail sales in July fed the hope that the main engine of economic growth in the United States -- consumer spending -- is still holding up. Home Depot's earnings rose 10 percent, beating Wall Street estimates. 
But Wal-Mart Stores reported a scant 2 percent increase in profits. The company also warned that its third-quarter profits would land at the low end of forecasts.
The market has been trapped in a tight trading range in the last few weeks as skittish investors have demanded clearer evidence of an economic recovery before spending money on stocks. The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates six times this year to revive the economy and is expected to cut them at its next policy-setting meeting on Tuesday.
The Nasdaq composite index lost 17.72 points, or 0.89 percent, to end at 1,964.53. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 3.74 points, or 0.04 percent, to 10,412.17. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index was down 4.56 points, or 0.38 percent, at 1,186.73. 
"We are in a period of transition, and when you are in a period of transition, you are not going to get continuous direction," said John Davidson, the chief investment officer at Circle Trust, which has $8 billion under management. "I would advise people that if they wait, they are going to have greater certainty, but they will be getting in at higher prices. Ultimately, this market will drift higher."
Home Depot, a component of the Dow, rose $1.20, to $49.30. Wal-Mart, another component of the Dow index, rose 16 cents, to $52.36. The S& P retail index gained 0.93 percent, as retailers proved to be one of the few bright spots during the session.
The chip equipment maker Applied Materials fell $1.16, to $43.65. After the markets closed, it reported third-quarter earnings that beat analysts' estimates, and it rose to $44.88. The data storage company Network Appliance was off $1.23 at $12.76. It reported a small first-quarter operating profit after the close, and its shares rose to $12.90.
Mitchell Energy and Development rose 31 percent after Devon Energy said it would buy the company. The deal will make Devon the second-largest United States independent natural gas producer behind the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation. Mitchell jumped $14.18, to $59.83, while Devon added 50 cents, to $50.76.
Best Buy moved up $2.80, to $61.09. The retailer plans to buy the Canadian electronics retailer Future Shop for $377 million.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Flat
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bonds erased early losses as investors concluded that signs of stronger retail sales left intact the prospects for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut next week.
"The Fed is not going to stop cutting rates, and simply hope for the best," said Mitch Stapley, who manages $4 billion at Fifth Third Investment Advisors in Grand Rapids, Mich.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note was unchanged at 100 10/32. Its yield was also unchanged, at 4.96 percent. The 30-year bond was unchanged at 98 4/32. Its yield held steady at 5.50 percent.

HEADLINE: Budget Dispute Stalls a Plan to Build New Schools 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Battling overcrowded schools and a rapidly dwindling construction budget, the New York City Board of Education has been in need of some bright ideas.
 More than a year ago, the Schoolhouse Foundation, a nonprofit group, presented one. It proposed selling bonds to build new schools without using any of the Board of Education's construction budget, then leasing the buildings to the school system for 15 to 20 years before turning them over, debt free. 
 The proposal generated enthusiasm in City Hall and at the Board of Education headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn, and a presentation on the plan was put on the board's agenda for March 15, 2000. But the presentation was canceled, and more than a year later, the project has yet to be approved. The Schoolhouse Foundation has firmed up plans for raising up to $200 million from private investors to build three schools -- an elementary, a middle and a high school -- and has secured an option to buy several acres in Forest Hills, Queens, the area with some of the city's most overcrowded schools. 
The proposal remains on the drawing board, apparently caught up in a budget dispute between Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy and City Hall. For the lack of a few million dollars -- essentially the cost of starting the construction -- $170 million of new school construction is postponed, at least temporarily. 
Board of Education members said they had expected that the proposal would be ready for their approval at their Aug. 20 meeting. "I think it is a great idea," said Ninfa Segarra, president of the board and an appointee of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "Whenever we can come up with alternative ways to expand the number of schools built, we welcome it." 
David Klasfeld, the deputy chancellor for operations, said yesterday that the proposal was "a valuable project that we're trying to see if we can proceed with." 
The foundation is the brainchild of Kevin McCabe, who worked for more than two decades in city government, recently as chief of staff to the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone. He left that job in 1998 to run Mr. Vallone's campaign for governor. Since then he has been working in the entertainment field, developing amphitheater projects in Portland, Ore., Minneapolis and New York.
Mr. McCabe describes the foundation's purpose as more than just shaking up the field in New York City. It is also to inspire others, in the city and across the country.
"School overcrowding is a huge issue nationwide," he said. "We want to break the ice and be the people who set some precedents for a different way to build schools."
Turning the construction of public schools over to private companies or community groups has been done before, most recently in Niagara Falls, N.Y., where Honeywell similarly built a new school, which it has leased to the city.
But while those efforts have usually involved one building, the scale of Mr. McCabe's first project is much larger: three schools, serving more than 2,300 students from kindergarten through 12th grade, spread across a single campus at Metropolitan Avenue and 69th Avenue in Forest Hills. 
Leelai Demoz, executive director of the foundation, said that if the preparation of the land got under way this fall, construction could begin in the spring and the schools could open in fall 2003.
To pay for the construction without tapping the school construction budget, the Schoolhouse Foundation plans to raise up to $200 million by selling tax-exempt bonds to private investors through the city's Industrial Development Authority, with the help of J. P. Morgan Chase. The foundation would then lease the schools to the Board of Education for the term of the bonds, probably 15 or 20 years, using the lease payments of $12 million to $14 million a year to pay the interest and principal on the bonds. After the bonds are retired, the buildings will be sold to the board for $1.
The plans for the schools were already under development at the School Construction Authority. The use of the land has been approved by the City Council. The property is owned by Forest City Ratner, which several years ago had intended to build a multiplex theater on the site, a project that was vigorously opposed by neighborhood residents and ultimately by the Giuliani administration. It has granted an option, which runs through September, to the foundation to buy the property.
Even if it gets under way, the success of the project is by no means certain. For starters, the staff of the Schoolhouse Foundation is hardly crowded with construction experts. Its executive director, Mr. Demoz, is an actor and documentary film producer whose short subject about Ladysmith Black Mambazo, the South African singing group, was nominated for an Academy Award this year. 
But Mr. Demoz and Mr. McCabe said the project would rely on an experienced construction manager and was likely to be closely watched by the School Construction Authority. 
Though the Schoolhouse Foundation has been in the works for at least two years, it could hardly be getting under way at a more propitious time, it would seem. Last week, Mr. Levy announced that according to the latest estimates from the School Construction Authority, the Board of Education faces a $2.8 billion shortfall if it tries to complete all of the projects in its current five-year, $7 billion plan for school construction and renovation, which runs through June 2004. One likely solution is to eliminate or delay some new school projects. Given that prospect, Mr. McCabe said his proposal was particularly timely.
But Board of Education officials say that because of problems involving not the capital budget, but the board's separate $11.5 billion annual expense budget, they are not sure that the board can afford to make the lease payments required to get the foundation project going. 
The advantage of the Schoolhouse Foundation's proposal is that the Board of Education could use its annual expense budget to pay the cost of leasing the schools, producing schools that could accommodate 2,300 students but leaving the troubled capital budget unencumbered. But Mr. Levy has been fighting Mayor Giuliani and Mr. Vallone over the size of the expense budget. Mr. Levy asserts that the recently approved expense budget actually leaves the school system with $120 million less than it had in the school year that ended in June. The difference, Mr. Levy has said, comes from mandated salary expenses and other cost increases, including inflation.
The foundation's proposal would cost the Board of Education about $180,000 a month for the first few years, or $2.2 million a year, which represents the cost of leasing the land while construction gets under way. Thereafter, the annual cost would be $12 million to $14 million. But with a $120 million budget gap, that may be too much to spare, even for a project that would deliver $170 million worth of new schools.
Mr. McCabe is no stranger to the intrigues of city government. But he retains cautious optimism that the project will soon be breaking ground.
"We'd like to set the example for other people who might be discouraged by the size and scope of the system," he said, "and show there are alternative solutions to big problems."

Yee/The New York Times) Map of Forest Hills shows site of proposed school: A foundation has an option on a site for schools in Forest Hills.

HEADLINE: Cars and Fuel Kept Sales From Rising Last Month 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
Retail sales were flat for a second consecutive month in July, held back by slumping auto purchases and lower gasoline prices, the government reported today. But gains outside those sectors showed consumers were still willing to spend.
 The Commerce Department said retail sales apart from cars and trucks rose slightly, climbing 0.2 percent last month after declining 0.2 percent in June. Sales of motor vehicles and parts dropped 0.5 percent in July, reversing a 0.5 percent gain in June. 
 Analysts and the stock markets viewed the overall report as mildly bullish, reflecting an unbowed consumer sector. Stocks initially rallied on the numbers but then gave up ground on earnings concerns later in the session.
"While consumers are no longer spending every penny they have, they are still visiting the malls," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
Economists had expected retail sales to dip 0.2 percent in July. Without autos, they had forecast that sales would edge up 0.1 percent.
The overall figure was also dragged lower by the fall in gasoline prices. Purchases at gas stations fell 4.2 percent, the largest one-month drop since data collection began in 1992. Because retail sales are not adjusted for price changes, the effect was to depress the overall sales figure. Excluding sales at gas stations, total July sales rose 0.3 percent.
Economists watch retail sales closely because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Consumer spending has been one of the few bright spots in an otherwise lackluster economic picture recently. The economy grew at an anemic 0.7 percent pace in the second quarter.
Where the economy heads in the third and fourth quarters will heavily depend on how well the consumer sector holds up, and economists see some encouraging signs in the July report.
"It's marginally better than we thought," said Carol Stone, deputy chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. "Moderate increases in store groups other than autos and gas stations looked pretty good."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Earnings Beat Expectations, Applied Materials Reports

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, August 14 

 BODY:
Applied Materials, the world's largest manufacturer of chip-making equipment, reported third-quarter earnings today that beat Wall Street's expectations by 2 cents a share but said it could predict no end to the industry slump. 
 With a decreased need for semiconductors worldwide, sales at Applied Materials were cut in half over the last 12 months. Revenue for the third quarter, ended July 29, were $1.33 billion, down from $2.73 billion in the period a year earlier and $1.91 billion in the second quarter. 
 Tight controls over spending, however, allowed the company to edge past its own profit forecasts and analysts' grim predictions. Applied Materials reported earnings, excluding one-time items, of $41 million, or 5 cents a share. Wall Street had expected earnings of 3 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
In a conference call after the release, analysts congratulated the company's management team for offering a pleasant surprise -- a rare occurrence these days. But their expectations have been lowered significantly since last year, when chip makers, trying to keep up with record demand for their products, bought as much equipment as Applied Materials could build.
Applied Materials, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said its earnings declined 85 percent from the second quarter and 93 percent from the third quarter last year, when it earned $604 million, or 70 cents a share.
James C. Morgan, the chairman and chief executive, said the company was continuing to spend heavily on research and development in preparation for an eventual upturn in the business. But he could not predict when that might happen.
"The industry continues to bounce along at the bottom," Mr. Morgan said.
Indeed, Applied Materials booked $1.21 billion in new orders, an 11 percent decline from the second quarter, and 63 percent less than in the period last year. Joseph R. Bronson, the chief financial officer and executive vice president, said he expected orders to continue at roughly the same level during the current quarter.
Sue Billat, a senior analyst with Robertson Stephens, praised the company for reporting 40 percent gross margins and profit of 5 cents a share during such a steep slowdown, and doing it without major layoffs. The company's work force declined to 19,000 employees, from 20,000 in the second quarter. "These guys are warriors," Ms. Billat said. "I think they did a marvelous job in tough times."
Shares in Applied Materials lost $1.16, or 3 percent, to close at $43.65 before the earnings release. After hours, they rose to $44.90. 
The chip equipment industry is often the last and hardest hit in a widespread high-technology slowdown. When corporations and consumers stop buying electronic devices like cell phones and personal computers, those manufacturers reduce their purchases of chips. When that happens, chip makers slow their purchases of the manufacturing equipment. But analysts said that Applied Materials' strength has been its ability to gain market share during a downturn and maintain it when the environment improves, and many expect that to happen again.
The downturn comes at a time when chip makers are changing their manufacturing processes more drastically than usual, as they move from aluminum wiring to copper, from 8-inch silicon wafers to 12-inch, and from 0.18-micron circuit lines to 0.15 micron and less.
The slowdown, coupled with decreased efficiency as the company learns to make equipment for these new technologies, contributed to a decline in Applied Materials' gross margins, which fell to 40 percent, from 45 percent in the second quarter and 51 percent in the third quarter last year. Mr. Bronson, the chief financial officer, said he expected gross margins to improve as the company became more comfortable with the new technologies.

HEADLINE: Attacks Raise Fears in Haiti Of Uprising By Ex-Soldiers 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
Deadly attacks on the police by gunmen in military uniforms have raised fears here that remnants of the disbanded army may be preparing a bid for power a decade after ousting the country's current president in a coup.
 Five police officers were killed and 14 wounded on July 28 when the gunmen stormed police installations in the capital and in three provincial towns, shouting, "Long live the army!" 
 At the funeral for officers killed in the raids, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide urged former soldiers not to join any attempts to overthrow him.
"Don't let yourself be manipulated by people who are thirsty for power," President Aristide told the gathering. "In the first years of the 21st century, it's time not to militarize power but to democratize power." 
Haiti's army has been feared since it was founded in 1915, during a United States occupation that lasted until 1934. Before being disbanded in 1995, the army relentlessly pillaged the public treasury, overthrew governments and tortured citizens.
The army also trained some of the top leaders of the Tontons Macoutes, the paramilitary force employed by Francois Duvalier and his son, Jean-Claude Duvalier, to keep an iron grip on the country for nearly 30 years. Today the only national security force in Haiti is its police.
The army's return could bring a violent uproar to a poverty-stricken country that has been trying desperately to temper disorder and strengthen a nascent democracy.
Mr. Aristide and members of his political party, Lavalas Family, have frequently said that "certain sectors" are plotting a coup.
"They haven't gotten it out of their heads yet," the president of the Senate, Yvon Neptune, said shortly after the assaults last month, "and they still think that it is possible for the army to return."
Fueling those suspicions are public statements from some former military officers.
"In all countries the military has a role: ensuring stability in the country," said Himmler Rebu, former commander of a special unit that tried to overthrow President Prosper Avril in 1989. Mr. Avril himself had seized power in a coup and was charged in June with the torture and false arrests of opposition members in 1989 and 1990.
"Haiti needs a military," Mr. Rebu said in a recent interview. "The real security of the country is the army."
Haiti's army overthrew Mr. Aristide in a coup in 1991 and then, with the support of paramilitary forces, terrorized his strongholds. Thousands of Haitians are believed to have been killed in the turmoil.
After Mr. Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected president, regained power with the backing of American troops three years later, he disbanded the army and replaced it with a civilian police force.
The military's former officers are scattered through the police force and the government. Senator Dany Toussaint, a former police chief, and Richard Salomon, a close Aristide ally, are among those with military backgrounds.
The political opposition group Convergence, an eclectic 15-party alliance that includes some of Mr. Aristide's right-wing foes who aided his overthrow, now argues that the police force is corrupt, understaffed and controlled by Mr. Aristide.
In February, Convergence named Gerard Gourge "provisional president" of Haiti in a move to challenge President Aristide's authority. In March, Mr. Gourge rallied nearly 1,000 former soldiers in a demonstration to call for the army's return.
"In principle, we support the need for the military to return," said Jose Jacques Nicolas, a Convergence member who represents the National Christian Movement for Haiti. "It's a necessity for the country, for the country's political organization, for the country's development. A country without a military force is left to be destroyed."
But Mr. Nicolas said that he condemned much of the former army's behavior and that a new military would have to be better organized and more professional.
Convergence has not pushed for the army's return during its weekly news conferences, which suggests a division over the issue. Micha Gaillard, a member of the leftist National Congress of Democratic Movements, also a part of Convergence, said the army was not crucial to achieving Haiti's security goals.
"It's not necessary to bring back the army," he said, "but to integrate the former soldiers into the police to give security to the population."
Human rights workers agree. They say that Haiti is not an attractive target for a foreign military takeover, that there are no outside threats and that a military would succumb to the same political temptations as the police force. The answer, they say, lies in reforming the police force.
